content.title: Little pink dinosaur prayers
content.introtext:
Pray about everything... Tell God what you need' Philippians 4:6 NLT

The four-year-old son of a missionary family in Africa spotted a picture of a little pink dinosaur in a magazine and set his heart on having one. His mum knew it was impossible (the magazine was three years old), but her son never doubted God would come through for him. On Christmas Eve, a box from home arrived. It had been packed and sent ten months earlier. At first glance it seemed to contain something special for everyone-except a four-year-old boy.

Then they reached the bottom-and they were stunned. The lady who sent the box had no way of knowing God would use her to answer a little boy's prayer. Before taping up the box, at the last minute, she tossed in the one item impossible for his parents to provide-something so insignificant no rational adult would ever have been foolish enough to ask God for it: a pink plastic brontosaurus from a fast-food restaurant promotion.

Sometimes we don't bother God with the little things-but pink dinosaurs tell us we should. The Bible says: '...pray about everything. Tell God what you need, and thank Him for all He has done.' (Philippians 4:6 NLT) God is interested in every detail of your life; if something is important to you, it's important to Him. When you learn to trust God in little things, you'll be able to trust Him in big ones.



SoulFood: Deut 11-13, Matt 12:38-50, Ps 78:17-31, Pr 16:26-30

content.title: Platinum card prayer
content.introtext:
...be persistent in your prayers...' Ephesians 6:18 NLT

The trouble is, we just don't realise what we've got in our hands. We see prayer as some kind of inconvenient spiritual homework. We'd much rather tap fingers on the old console than clasp them in prayer. And so prayer becomes just like that overdue essay-left well past the deadline.

Imagine your rich uncle hands over his platinum card for some serious shopping. Do you hide the piece of plastic in your bottom drawer? Or do you taxi it down to retail rapture quicker than you can shout, 'Spend! Spend! Spend!' Our guess is your uncle will be re-mortgaging the mansion when he gets your bill!

So, why is it, that when our Almighty God offers to communicate with us anytime anywhere we file it with 'list of chores' to do? Yep, we enjoy an 'open heaven' with access to divine wisdom and guidance and a life-time supply of all we'll ever need-and yet we choose to spend all our time away from His presence.

Jeremiah 33:3 NIV says, 'Call to Me, and I will answer you, and show you great...things, which you do not know.' The answers you want are found on your knees. Luke 11:10 NLT says, '...everyone who asks, receives...' Jesus is clearly giving you permission to max out the prayer platinum. 1 Thessalonians 5:17 NIV says, 'Pray continually.' God isn't worried about the bill; He's expecting you to go a little crazy. Trouble is, you just don't know what you've got in your hands.



SoulFood: Lev 24:17-22, Deut 15:7-11, Matt 5:38-48

content.title: Strange Ways
content.introtext:
'...Strike the ground...' 2 Kings 13:18 NKJ

Sometimes God has people do the strangest things. In Hosea, God asked a holy man to marry a prostitute. In Ezekiel, a prophet was told to eat a paper scroll. And here in 2 Kings there's another bizarre request-a king is urged to throw a toddler's tantrum.

Jehoash-a lukewarm king, to put it kindly-is going head-to-head with their archenemies, the Syrians. But rather than dispatch a monster swarm of tanks or press the nuke button, Jehoash is told to win the war first by firing an arrow out the window and then by smacking the ground in a hissy fit. It's not exactly 'Call of Duty', is it?

Is God into big-time embarrassment or is something more going on? The clue comes later when the prophet Elisha fumes at King Jehoash's feeble efforts. The king, no doubt, felt a bit silly following God's strange instructions, and so he only obeyed half-heartedly. Elisha points out that because he only went so far, he will only get so far with his enemies. Sure, the king would have some success, but it wouldn't be until his son, Jeroboam, reigned that complete victory would come.

If you want to win battles in this life, you need to be fully committed in following God, not half-hearted. Even if you're being asked to do something that seems strange.



SoulFood: Deut 18-21, Matt 13:10-23, Ps 78:40-55, Pr 16:32

content.title: For Heaven's Sake
content.introtext:
'...I shall go to him...' 2 Samuel 12:23 NKJ

Life is hard. Nobody gets a written note from God excusing them from life's toughest moments.

In 2 Samuel we read about David, a man who had it all. Then he lost what was most precious-his child. Listen to the heartbreak in David's words: 'Can I bring him back again? I will go to him, but he will not return to me.' (2 Samuel 12:23 NAS) David came face-to-face with a harsh truth: his child won't come back to him, but one day he will go to be with the child in Heaven.

Maybe you can relate to David's grief. Perhaps you've experienced someone's life cut short and you've found yourself asking: 'Will I see them in Heaven?' David's words should comfort you: 'I shall go to him.' David, a man completely tuned-in to God, is confident he will once again see his son in Heaven. You can have that confidence too.

Maybe you're wondering: 'Will I actually know them in Heaven?' The answer is yes! The reason lies in the story of the Transfiguration. The disciples recognised Moses and Elijah, even though these two Old Testament heavyweights had been dead hundreds of years. Perhaps we may not see our loved ones for another eighty years or so, but we will still recognise them. And we'll have eternity to get to know them. Life is hard. But one day there'll be no more tears.



SoulFood: Deut 22-24, Matt 13:24-35, Ps 78:56-64, Pr 16:33

content.title: Check the Label
content.introtext:
'Then Pharaoh...clothed him in garments of fine linen...' Genesis 41:42 NKJ

Check the tag in your coat-what does it say? Maybe, 'Outer lining: 100% nylon; inner lining: 100% cotton'. Wouldn't it be good if it read: Outer you: '100% approved; inner you: 100% honest'?

That's the kind of tag Joseph carried around in his amazing Technicolour Dream-coat. Joseph came 100% approved: 'Now [Jacob] loved Joseph...and he made him a coat of many colours.' (Genesis 37:3 KJV) Like the sparkling coat, the approval of God will cause you to stand out from the crowd; it will open doors, protect and promote you. Psalm 5:12 NKJ says, 'For You, O Lord, will bless the righteous; with favour You will surround him as with a shield.'

Joseph also carried the label 'honest' in his coat. This is the same coat Joseph left in the hands of Potiphar's wife when she was trying to mess around with him. Joseph kept his honest head on, keeping his hands off what wasn't his: 'When Joseph went into the house to do his work...she caught him by his garment, saying, Lie with me. But he left his garment in her hand, and fled...' (Genesis 39:11-12 NKJ)

Be like Joseph. Keep your hands to yourself when you're presented with opportunity to sin, and keep your mouth zipped when tempted to have a good goss. When your '100% honest' tag itches the back of your neck, use it as a reminder to do the right thing.



SoulFood: Deut 25-27, Matt 13:36-46, Ps 78:65-72, Pr 17:1-2

content.title: A Pool of Money
content.introtext:
'...It does not worry in a year when no rain comes...' Jeremiah 17:8 NCV

Gap years. Not only will you be cleaning out toilets in Botswana for a year but you'll be charged three grand for the pleasure of doing it! Actually, maybe you secretly love the idea of serving the poor but the money aspect puts you right off. You have faith to believe that you could love an orphan out in India but when it comes to raising the price of the plane fare, that faith is suddenly AWOL.

If you're going to be dependent on God keeping you safe in some foreign land then why not start practicing now, by being dependent on God for the finance to get you there. Jeremiah 17:7-8 NCV should fuel your faith: 'But the person who trusts in the Lord will be blessed...He will be...like a tree planted near water...it does not worry in a year when no rain comes.'

'Nice verse,' you're thinking. 'But what's a tree got to do with my empty bank account?' Well, trees depend on rain to grow and produce fruit. A tree that can stretch out its roots to nearby water is no longer dependent on cloud-juice for its water. Likewise, you don't necessarily need to do ten years of extra shifts at Macca's to source the cash for your trip. God can supply if you'll just ask. So ask Him, then ask God's people.



SoulFood: Deut 28-29, Matt 13:47-58, Ps 119:1-8, Pr 17:3

content.title: Oncoming Traffic
content.introtext:
'I will instruct you...in the way you should go...' Psalm 32:8 NIV

You wouldn't walk into oncoming traffic wearing a blindfold, would you? So, why does walking with God often feel like something similar? It's almost as if you can hear life's challenges hurtling towards you, ready to run you down. Yet God still calls you to carry on, despite the accidents that could occur.

Walking with God isn't always a pleasant stroll in the park. Walking with God sometimes means heading into trouble. Jesus promises it: 'If people did wrong to Me, they will do wrong to you, too.' (John 15:20 NCV)

You'd think the closer you get to God, the easier things would become. But Paul found the opposite true: 'I don't know what will happen to me there. I know only that in every city the Holy Spirit tells me that trouble and even jail wait for me. I don't care about my own life. The most important thing is that I complete my mission, the work that the Lord Jesus gave me...' (Acts 20:22-24 NCV) What?! Paul is walking step-by-step with God and yet prison is the pot of gold at the end of his rainbow?

God never promised a bed of roses; in fact we all know the story...He promised crucifixion for the Author of our faith. Today's thought is not an easy one: are you willing to walk in faith with God despite the oncoming traffic?



SoulFood: Deut 30:1-32:28, Matt 14:1-12, Ps 119:9-16, Pr 17:4-6

content.title: God-gloss (1)
content.introtext:
'The lips of the godly speak helpful words...' Proverbs 10:32 NLT

Solomon never wrote, 'The lips of the godly are glossed with sarcasm' or 'The mouths of the righteous can chew you up and spit you out.' Know why? Because 'godly' means behaving like God. It means we need to be holy and watch what we say. Do you think Jesus took Peter aside for a word in his ear: 'See that Judas bloke? I trust him about as far as I can launch him; he's sooo going to get it!'

It doesn't fit with His character, does it? Jesus was totally holy.

Perhaps if your tongue only spoke blessing you'd be nearer the holy mark too. Like, instead of using it to mouth off about next door's annoying kids, why not make friends and speak positive words into their lives? Or instead of moving those lips to moan about everything that's wrong with the world, why not do something about it? Like, speaking up about fair-trade products or persecution or human trafficking.

Yet sometimes, it's the smallest things you say that have the biggest impact. Like thanking a teacher after a good lesson or commenting on your mum's new hair-do. After all, a small compliment is far godlier than a sly dig, don't you think?



SoulFood: 1 Sam 17:4-51, Eph 6:10-18

content.title: God-gloss (2)
content.introtext:
'The lips of the godly speak helpful words...' Proverbs 10:32 NLT

'God-gloss' gives you beauty inside and out. So if you want to glow, apply godliness to your lips every day.

Firstly, there's nothing more attractive than handing out encouragement with your smile: 'Kind words bring life, but cruel words crush your spirit.' (Proverbs 15:4 GNT) Ella Wilcox once said, 'A pat on the back is only a few vertebrae removed from a kick in the pants, but miles ahead in results.' Seriously, a snide comment may get a quick cheap laugh, but a word of support can last a lifetime.

Secondly, 'healing' is such a good look to apply to your face: 'Pleasant words are a honeycomb, sweet to the soul and healing to the bones.' (Proverbs 16:24 NIV) People with loads of inner struggles can start to be healed through a card, an email or even a text from you. Proverbs 25:11 NCV tells us: 'The right word spoken at the right time is as beautiful as gold apples in a silver bowl.'

Finally, the best shine you can apply to your lips is the sparkle of salvation. The most beautiful thing in the universe is telling people about Jesus: 'The words of a good person give life, like a fountain of water...' (Proverbs 10:11 NCV) You can speak life-giving words to those who are lost, making beautiful their past, present and future.



SoulFood: Deut 32:29-34:12, Matt 14:13-21, Ps 119:17-24, Pr 17:7-10

content.title: Training
content.introtext:
'...If God is for us, who can be against us?' Romans 8:31 NKJ

You know those people who seem to have 'God's favour' stamped on their passport to life? Most of them have been to rock bottom at some point. Many of the Bible's heroes faced a lot of un-super stuff before they were raised to starry heights.

Take David, the man described as Israel's greatest ever king. Long before he was being measured up for his crown and robes, God had him endure instruction in the toughest boot camp. First he was trained in obscurity-unseen, unappreciated and unknown. The only applause David received growing up would have come from his sheep flock.

Teenage David was far from Mr Popular. He was stuck out in the hills with the world's most unglamorous job. Yet coping with being a 'nobody' qualified him to be the big 'somebody'. Secondly, he was trained in monotony. Years before fine wines and food fit for a king, he lived a simple everyday existence. Endless hours of farming come rain or shine, he could be found doing plain old, dull L.I.F.E. Being consistent in the boring stuff grounded David for all the amazing stuff later on. Not feeling much of 'the glam' lately? Good. It means you're in training.

SoulFood: Deut 14-17, Matt 13:1-9, Ps 78:32-39, Pr 16:31

content.title: The definition of love
content.introtext:
Love...keeps no record of being wronged.' 1 Corinthians 13:4-5 NLT

When it comes to 'love', different people seem to be reading from different dictionaries. To Mr Drunken, 'love' is just a word used in an attempt to take advantage of the young lady next to him whereas to Miss Gush Gush Chick, 'love' is what you fall in when you spy the latest clothes catalogue. The Bible has one or two thoughts on the 'L-word' (and get this-not one mentions puppy dogs, bling or hearts with arrows scrawled through them). So wrap your mind around this: Love-the real definition...

I may give away everything I have, and I may even give my body as an offering to be burned. But I gain nothing if I do not have love. Love is patient and kind...is not jealous, it does not brag...is not rude...not selfish...does not get upset with others...does not count up wrongs...is not happy with evil but is happy with the truth... It always trusts, always hopes, and always remains strong. Love never ends. There are gifts of prophecy, but they will be ended... There is the gift of knowledge, but it will come to an end. The reason is that our knowledge and our ability to prophesy are not perfect. But when perfection comes, the things that are not perfect will end.' (1 Corinthians 13:3-10 NCV)



SoulFood: Deut 3-4, Matt 12:1-14, Ps 46, Pr 16:20-22

content.title: Dirty window syndrome
content.introtext:
You who judge others do these very same things.' Romans 2:1 NLT

Heard the one about the woman who peered out her window every morning just to have a good gossip about the state of her neighbour's dirty washing? One morning she noticed it was sparkling clean. 'Maybe she's ditched that cheap washing powder,' she sneered. 'Or maybe I got up early and cleaned our windows,' piped up her hubby. Gotcha!

We need to be on red alert to 'dirty window syndrome'. Maybe you recognise the early symptoms in yourself: You 'tut-tut' over your mate's choice of boyfriend and in the next breath you're drooling over the school bad boy. You're quick to pull up your mate about her gossiping, but not so quick on yourself when using prayer as an excuse for tongue-twitching: 'Can we just pray for my friend, she's sleeping around...' You're shocked to hear old Scrooge never puts a penny in the collection, but you think nothing of short-changing your parents.

When Paul wrote about 'greed, hate, envy, murder, quarrelling, deception... gossip' (Romans 1:29 NLT), surely he didn't mean you, right? But he goes on to say, 'you are just as bad... you...do these very same things.' Paul knows about our 'dirty window syndrome'-judging other people's dirty laundry through our own grimy eyes.

Instead of focusing on the speck of dust in your mate's eye, learn to deal with the plank in your own. Hmm, now where have we heard that before?



SoulFood: Deut 5-7, Matt 12:15-21, Ps 78:1-8, Pr 16:23-24

content.title: Overcoming the grasshopper mentality (2)
content.introtext:
...we felt like grasshoppers next to them...' Numbers 13:33 NLT
When you come up against a giant, either your faith will cause you to soar or your fear will cause you to sink. The Israelites died about 30 km from the Promised Land, walking around the desert in circles. Why? Because they let their fear get the better of them: 'We even saw giants there... We felt like grasshoppers next to them.' If you're to see (and seize) what God has promised you, you'll have to conquer your giants. Now, you have the power to, but do you have the guts to? Joshua and Caleb looked upwards with the eyes of faith, even when everyone else started to look down and get depressed. 'The whole congregation...said..."Would to God that we had died...in the land of Egypt..."' (Exodus 16:2-3 KJV) These guys were on a serious downer! This is someone with a 'grasshopper mentality': (1) They constantly talk about life's injustices; about how they've been mistreated and misunderstood. To them Paul answers, '...endure hardship as a good soldier of Jesus Christ.' (2 Timothy 2:3 NKJ) (2) They make excuses for not conquering in life. Sometimes they even put others down because they are stepping out in faith. To them Paul writes, '...in all these things we are more than conquerors through Him who loved us.' (Romans 8:37 NIV) (3) They complain about what they don't have instead of focusing on what they do. To them Peter writes, 'His divine power has given us everything we need for life and godliness through our knowledge of Him who called us...' (2 Peter 1:3 NIV) Sound like anyone you know (including yourself)? Get to know God better. That's how to move from a grasshopper mentality to a giant-killer mentality!
SoulFood: Jer 51-52, Matt 7:1-14, Ps 137, Pr 15:15-17

content.title: Practice what you preach
content.introtext:
...add to your faith, goodness...' 2 Peter 1:5 NIV

If you think you can play fast and loose with the world's rules and expect your non-Christian mates to follow God's, you're dreamin'. Instead of preaching Jesus, live Jesus. If living Jesus means leaving that party early, set your mental alarm to leave when you should. If living Jesus means keeping quiet when everyone else is going gossip-mad, keep it zipped. And if living Jesus means spending a bit more on ethical clothing rather than penny-pinching at sweatshop city, splash the extra cash. What you say will go in one ear and out the other; what you do will be noticed. Standing out from the crowd is top of the Kingdom Job Description. People know when you're wearing 'what would Jesus do' round your wrist but 'what I want to do' round your heart. 2 Peter 1:5-7 GWT tells us what to aim for: '...make every effort to add integrity to your faith; and to integrity add knowledge; to knowledge add self-control; to self-control add endurance; to endurance add godliness; to godliness add Christian affection; and to Christian affection add love.' See, you can't tell someone you're a 'good Christian friend' and then never invite them round for tea nor can you show 'good character' by partying through every Saturday night. Your best preach will be the one you live; so live Jesus.

SoulFood: Deut 8-10, Matt 12:22-37, Ps 78:9-16, Pr 16:25

content.title: Where are you going?
content.introtext:
You have been wandering around...long enough; turn...' Deuteronomy 2:3 NLT
Choices, choices, choices-they're all around you. Whether it's options, uni, job, church mates, what to do, where to go... the list sometimes seems endless, doesn't it? Do you ever feel like you're walking round in circles with all the choices, with no idea which way to turn to make sure you end up in the right place? And you know that it matters too-some of these choices are life-changers, and you don't want to end up doing the wrong thing, or in the wrong place. You're not alone-Israel had the same problem in the Old Testament, wandering about in the desert, not knowing where to go next. God stepped in and told them what to do (read the whole story in Deuteronomy). Some of the stuff He told them to do probably seemed a bit scary or crazy to them-but what God said, happened. He'll do the same for you too, if you ask Him. The question is: will you trust Him enough to turn around and go wherever He says, making the choice He tells you, even if it seems a bit scary or not the most logical option? It's worth it if you do-because that's when you'll end up where God wants you-and when you're in the place He wants, that's when He'll use you best to do His work through you. Walk His path-it's so worth it.

SoulFood: Acts 12-13, Matt 9:14-26, Ps 123, Pr 16:1

content.title: Questioning or accepting?
content.introtext:
How are the dead raised? With what kind of body?' 1 Corinthians 15:35 NIV
There's no shortage of fascination with the afterlife, the supernatural, life beyond death. It's right there in films, in books and on TV. But how do we know what is really true? What really happens? Jesus tells us a few things about Heaven. First, it's real. Jesus said, 'There is more than enough room in My Father's home. If this were not so, would I have told you that I am going to prepare a place for you?' (John 14:2 NLT) Secondly, you're invited. Jesus said, 'When everything is ready, I will come and get you, so that you will always be with Me where I am.' (v3) And third, there's only one way to get there: Jesus said, 'I am the way, the truth, and the life. No one can come to the Father except through Me.' (v6) In Luke 23 we read how 'they nailed Him to the cross. And the criminals were also crucified-one on His right and one on His left.' (v33) One of them went to Heaven when he died, the other didn't. One choose to reject Jesus: 'One of the criminals hanging beside Him scoffed...'(v39) But the other criminal believed in Jesus, saying, 'We deserve to die for our crimes, but this man hasn't done anything wrong.' Then he said, 'Jesus, remember me when You come into Your kingdom.' Jesus said, 'I assure you, today you will be with Me in Paradise.' (vv40-43 NLT) Do you believe in Jesus or scoff at Him? Your answer will have a dramatic effect on whether you get to see Heaven or not.

SoulFood: Acts 20-21, Matt 10:21-31, Ps 14, Pr 16:6-7

content.title: Cash generator
content.introtext:
Keep your lives free from the love of money...' Hebrews 13:5 NIV

Wanna scare your careers adviser? Tell them you want to be a poet or a sleigh-rider or a Sudoku designer. Watch them flap as they say, 'Right...but what about something to fall back on?' You see, there isn't much money in poetry. Jobs in Sudoku construction are few and far between. Here's the thing though: why not follow your heart rather than the dollar?

It's true we all need money to survive but money isn't the be-all of life. Hebrews 13:5 NIV tells us to chill out on this score: 'Keep your lives free from the love of money and be content with what you have, because God has said, "Never will I leave you; never will I forsake you."'

Don't let finance dictate your future. People get all twisted up in knots, staying awake at night, stewing over money. It's as if money will solve all their problems. Cash is a mixed blessing because it gives us independence. Being self-sufficient means we no longer need God to provide, which in turn means we no longer automatically go to God for help, which in turns means we miss out on relationship with God as our provider.

Yesterday's devotional looked at you being made for a mission. That's the point: keep your focus on your mission, not your wallet. Billy Graham said, 'If a person gets his attitude toward money straight, it will help straighten out almost every other area of his life.' So: 'Keep your lives free from the love of money.'



SoulFood: Jer 14-17, Mark 16:1-20, Ps 21, Pr 14:17-20

content.title: Creative accounting
content.introtext:
Two are better than one...' Ecclesiastes 4:9 NKJ

You've probably heard the story of Moses and the Ten Commandments before, but instead of focusing on Moses, let's take a look at his brother Aaron. The brothers worked together as they campaigned for freedom for the Jews, and as they crossed the Red Sea, and as they began their journey through the desert. Then it all went pear-shaped. Moses went up a mountain to spend time with God, leaving Aaron with the rest of the Israelites. He was gone so long that the people thought he wasn't coming back. The pressure grew on Aaron to provide a God they could see. It got too much and he ended up making a golden idol for them.

When Moses came back down and saw what Aaron had done, he confronted him. But Aaron blamed everyone else: 'You know how prone these people are to evil. They said...make us gods... they gave me gold and I threw it into the fire.' (Exodus 32:22-25 NIV) But Aaron wasn't the only one to struggle during the journey. Moses found that being the sole problem-solver was more than he could handle. His father-in-law had to tell him: 'You cannot handle it alone...select capable people...that will make your load lighter...' (Exodus 18:17-24 NIV) Ever wonder why Jesus sent His disciples out in twos instead of solo? Because when we've got the right person by our side, we have support, encouragement and-protection. Protection from what? Ourselves! If we're serious about walking with Jesus, accountability is a step we must be willing to take. So, who are you accountable to?



SoulFood: Ex 20:17, Ps 10, Pr 28:16

content.title: Hide and seek
content.introtext:
...the Lord, whom you seek, will suddenly come...' Malachi 3:1 NKJ

We've all played it and maybe even still do-hide and seek! You go off to hide and then your friend tries to find you and vice-versa. Playing it with small children can be scary. They can be so good at it, you start believing they must have been abducted by aliens-it's the only explanation, surely?

Do you ever sometimes feel that God is playing hide and seek with you? One minute being a Christian feels great; you have amazing experiences of God; you feel Him with you big time, all the time; you ask questions and you get answers; He gives you visions, pictures, words of wisdom; you hear His voice and then... ... ...nothing! It's like He's hiding-you can't see Him or hear Him anywhere. And it's usually at a time when you feel like you need Him the most. You turn to Him and it feels like He's gone. You're left crying: 'Where are you, God? I need you!'

Don't rely on your feelings. God promises: 'Never will I leave you; never will I forsake you.' (Hebrews 13:5 NIV) When things get tough, God promises: 'When you pass through the waters...they will not sweep over you. When you walk through the fire, you will not be burned...' (Isaiah 43:2 NIV) If you're feeling like God has deserted you, know for sure 'the Lord, whom you seek, will suddenly come.'



SoulFood: Jer 18-21, Matt 1:1-25, Ps 59:1-8, Pr 14:21-22

content.title: W.W.J.D. (1)
content.introtext:
...we become more and more like Him.' 2 Corinthians 3:18 TLB

When we're growing up, we all have our own ideas of who we want to be, how we want to dress, what we want to do. We form our own opinions and they're the ones that matter, we want to be our own person. It's never music to our ears when we hear: 'Ooh, you look just like your mum' from Auntie Ethel, and 'Oh, you sound just like dad' from Grandad Tom. Yeah, sometimes we want to dress like our friends, follow the latest trends and copy styles-but it's our choice, right? We're still our own person!

When we read in the Bible that 'we should become more like Him'-like Jesus-it can freak us out. It's not about growing a beard, moving to Israel and wearing a long robe (makes your school uniform suddenly sound very appealing, doesn't it?) And there's no need for that panic attack thinking all Christians are supposed to become clones of one another (imagine church services where the people look like they've been photocopied over and over!)

God's talking about Character Building, not Christian Cloning, when He says, '...throw off...your former way of life, which is rotten through and through... You must display a new nature because you are a new person, created in God's likeness-righteous, holy, and true.' (Ephesians 4:22-24 NLT) Make this your No.1 priority!



SoulFood: Jer 22-24, Matt 2:1-15, Ps 59:9-17, Pr 14:23-24

content.title: W.W.J.D. (2)
content.introtext:
...we become more and more like Him.' 2 Corinthians 3:18 TLB

At the end of His life, Jesus declared His mission a success by saying: 'I have brought You glory on earth by completing the work You gave Me to do.' (John 17:4 NIV) David writes, 'Not to us, O Lord, not to us, but to Your name give glory...' (Psalm 115:1 AMP) The breath you took as you read that last sentence was given to you for one reason: that you might 'reflect the glory of the Lord...' (2 Corinthians 3:18 NIV) The way Moses led Israel changed after he prayed, '...show me Your glory.' (Exodus 33:18 NCV) We cross a line when we make such a request. When our deepest desire is not the things of God, or the favour of God, but God Himself, we cross a threshold. Less self-focus, more God-focus. Less about us; more about Him. This calls for the death of ego. It rubs us the wrong way. It's a truth we must constantly remind ourselves of: '...God made all things, and everything continues through Him and for Him. To Him be glory forever!' (Romans 11:36 NCV) And if you still haven't got the message: '...there is only one God, the Father, who created everything, and we exist for Him...' (1 Corinthians 8:6 NLT) Why does the earth spin? For Him. Why do you have talents and abilities? For Him. Whose Word matters? His. Whose will must be done? His, not ours. God's to-do list consists of one item: 'Reveal My glory.' Heaven's framed and mounted statement of purpose reads: 'Declare God's glory.' Everything and everyone exists to reveal His glory; including you! Try to remember that.



SoulFood: Jer 25-27, Matt 2:16- 3:10, Ps 64, Pr 14:25-28

content.title: W.W.J.D. (3)
content.introtext:
...we become more and more like Him.' 2 Corinthians 3:18 TLB

Eight times in the New Testament, we're told to 'make every effort' to be like Jesus. You don't just veg out on the sofa and wait for it to happen. The apostle Paul explains our three responsibilities in becoming like Christ:

(1) Changing our habits. Your character is made up of the sum of your daily habits. Listen: 'You were taught to leave your old self-to stop living the evil way you lived before. That old self becomes worse, because people are fooled by the evil things they want to do.' (Ephesians 4:22 NCV)

(2) Changing our thinking. The Greek word for 'transformed'-metamorphosis-is used today to describe the amazing change a caterpillar goes through in becoming a butterfly. It is a superb picture of what happens to us when we allow God to shape our thought life. As we spend time talking to God and reading His Word, we take on the beauty of Christ's character; we leave behind those caterpillar limitations. Paul says: '...be transformed by the renewing of your mind...' (Romans 12:2 NIV)

(3) Changing our clothes. God's Word says, 'Therefore, as God's chosen people, holy and dearly loved, clothe yourselves...' (Colossians 3:12 NIV) Most people wouldn't go to a party in a school uniform; you need to dress yourself in the right gear to make the most of the moment. So in life put on the right things: '...clothe yourselves with compassion, kindness, humility and patience.'



SoulFood: Jer 28-30, Matt 3:11- 4:11, Ps 95, Pr 14:29-33

content.title: Led by God (1)
content.introtext:
...along unfamiliar paths I will guide them...' Isaiah 42:16 NIV

Don't ask God to bless your plans, ask Him to show you His-they are already blessed. When the time is right the plan will be clear, the people in place and the resources available. Peter writes: 'His divine power has given us everything we need for life...' (2 Peter 1:3 NIV) Did you hear that? Everything! God told Abraham when to leave home (see Genesis 12:1), and Jacob when to go back home (see Genesis 31:3). He even told Elijah where to find food in the middle of a famine (see 1 Kings 17:1-5). And His promise to you is: '...along unfamiliar paths I will guide them...' The path you are on today may be unfamiliar to you but it's not to God. He has already gone ahead of you. All you need is the faith to step out and follow Him.

God never changes. If He talked to people all through the Bible He'll talk to you too. Question is: Have you learned to recognise His voice yet? Nothing should be more important to you than learning to hear from God for yourself. Other people's ideas should only confirm or clarify what He's already shown you. If you have not heard from God you will be tempted to think that human ideas are His commands-and that could hurt you. Listen: God has a personal plan and a specific destination for you. Take the time to ask Him about it. His Word says, 'He guides the humble in what is right and teaches them His way.' (Psalm 25:9 NIV)



SoulFood: Jer 31-32, Matt 4:12-25, Ps 98, Pr 14:34

content.title: Led by God (2)
content.introtext:
I will guide you along the best pathway for your life...' Psalm 32:8 NLT

Solomon says, 'Many are the plans in a man's heart, but it is the Lord's purpose that prevails.' (Proverbs 19:21 NIV) Even though your plans aren't perfect, if your heart's motive is right, God will make things work out for your good and His glory. Are you having difficulty sorting out your ideas from what He is saying? We all struggle with that, especially when the Bible doesn't give us specifics. For example, when it's time to go to uni or marry or get a job, what should you do? Listen: 'I will guide you along the best pathway for your life.' You say, 'That's nice, but I'd like a little more detail.' Ok:

(1) Ideas go away but God's direction stays. God moves at His pace and He invented you and time, so He can make it work! There is persistence in His leading. That is why time is on your side. Do not rush ahead of Him.

(2) God's direction is impossible to follow without Him. He plans it that way. Jesus said, '...without Me you can do nothing.' (John 15:5 NKJ)

(3) God's direction usually begins with discomfort. Listen: 'like an eagle that stirs up its nest...The Lord...led him...' (Deuteronomy 32:11-12 NIV) Eagles learn to fly when their mum pushes them out of the nest and over the cliff's edge. Can you imagine their thoughts? 'Mum, what are you playing at!' But it's only when the eagle is forced out of its comfort zone that it discovers it was born to fly, spreads its wings, releases its power and finds its place in the heavens. Has God been stirring up your nest? Relax! He's leading you!



SoulFood: Jer 33:1-36:26, Matt 5:1, Ps 102: 1-11, Pr 14:35-15:2

content.title: Led by God (3)
content.introtext:
...He will direct your paths.' Proverbs 3:6 NLT

Here are some examples of when hearing God about something makes all the difference. (1) Future choices. When trying to decide what's next, look carefully at your options and ask God to make the right one clear. (2) Before you make a choice based on someone else's idea. Why? Because people's ideas aren't God's commands. Don't commit yourself to stuff you can't do and end up trapped by promises you can't fulfil. Be there for people, but be led only by God's Spirit. (3) When someone's being awkward. What people say can totally effect how we think. Don't make bad decisions because your mate is being moody-that can prevent you making the right choice. (4) At a tough time. Don't change your college course just coz it's a bit tough...take a minute and ask what God wants you to do. If someone asks you to do something, think first...is this something that is going to be pleasing to God? (5) When you're tempted. Don't just cruise along with the crowd. Often saying 'no' is the right answer. Think: 'Is this in tune with God's heartbeat?' (6) When you have popularity. A compliment is always nice but don't let it navigate your decisions. Flattery just inflates the ego and can make it tough to hear God clearly. Some people will be excited by your dreams because they don't have their own...but are you ready to carry passengers? It's wise to share your heart with people you know have a good relationship with God.



SoulFood: Ps 23, Jn 10:7-18

content.title: Led by God (4)
content.introtext:
For it is God who works in you...' Philippians 2:13 NIV

You can't put your life into compartments by saying, 'In this category I'm gonna do things my way, but in that category I'm gonna be led by God.' Every step you take must be synchronised with the beat of God's heart! Nothing is more important than keeping pace with Him. Listen: '...God...works in you to will and to act according to His good purpose.' (Philippians 2:13 NIV) God works through us as we engage our minds, open our mouths, move our feet and use our hands to do what He has already put into our hearts. The moment you say 'yes' to God He gives you what you need to do what He asks. Check this: He doesn't show His will to you first, then call you next. No, He calls you, and as you move out and obey Him He shows it to you step by step, helping you as you go.

God is never content with the 'normal'! Never! Every day in different ways He will develop you into a greater God-carrier. You're not out for a stroll, you're on a mission. Again and again you will be given challenges and be put into situations that will mature you to the point where you have the same attitude, the same responses and the same desires as Jesus. When you start to understand that, walking with God will take on a whole new meaning. Realise that your walk with Him is the only walk that will ever satisfy you or fulfil your purpose for being on this planet.

content.title: Thinking about Heaven (1)
content.introtext:
We...would prefer to be...at home with the Lord.' 2 Corinthians 5:8 NIV

The sense that we will live forever-somewhere-has shaped every civilisation in history. In the pyramids of Egypt, the embalmed bodies had maps placed beside them as guides to the future world. In AD 125, a Greek named Aristides wrote, 'When a Christian passes from this world, they rejoice...and escort his body with songs of thanksgiving as if he were setting out from one place to another nearby.' In 1952 young Florence Chadwick stepped into the Pacific, just off Catalina Island, determined to swim to the mainland of California. She'd already been the first woman to swim the English Channel both ways. The weather was foggy and chilly; she could hardly see the boats accompanying her. Still, she swam for 15 hours. When she begged to be taken out of the water, her mother, who was in a boat alongside, told her she was close and that she could make it. Finally, physically and emotionally exhausted, she stopped swimming and was pulled out. It wasn't until she was on the boat that she discovered that the shore was only about a kilometre away. At a news conference the next day she said, 'All I could see was the fog...I think if I could have seen the shore I would have made it.'

Heaven is not a myth; it's a magnet that pulls us in the direction of home. A home, which Paul describes as 'better by far'. (Philippians 1:23 NIV) No matter how tough life gets, keep your eyes on the heavenly shore; draw strength each day from God, and you'll make it!



SoulFood: Jer 41-44, Matt 5:38- 6:8, Ps 102:18-28, Pr 15:4-7

content.title: Thinking about Heaven (2)
content.introtext:
Set your minds on things above, not on earthly things.' Colossians 3:2 NIV

Gary Larson captured a common misconception of Heaven in one of his Far Side cartoons. In it a man with angel wings and a halo sits on a cloud, doing nothing. A caption reads: 'Wish I'd brought a magazine.' How come we talk so little about Heaven? Why has it fallen off our radar screens? Listen: '[Satan] began to curse God, His name, the place where He lives, and all those who live in Heaven.' (Revelation 13:6 GNT) Satan bad-mouths three things:

(1) God's person

(2) God's people

(3) God's place-Heaven. After being evicted from Heaven (Isaiah 14:12-15), it must be maddening for him to know we're now entitled to the beautiful home he was kicked out of. What better way for him to attack us than to whisper lies about the place Paul tells us to set our minds on? If we believe his lie we'll set our minds on this life, not the next. And we won't be motivated to take others with us. CS Lewis writes, 'The Christians who did the most for the present world were just those who thought most of the next. The Apostles...who set on foot the conversion of the Roman Empire, the great men who built up the Middle Ages, the English Evangelicals who abolished Slave Trade, all left their mark on Earth-precisely because their minds were occupied with Heaven. It is since Christians have largely ceased to think of the other world, that they have become so ineffective in this. Aim at Heaven and you will get earth "thrown in", aim at earth and you will get neither.'



SoulFood: Jer 45-48, Matt 6:9-18, Ps 110, Pr 15:8-9

content.title: Overcoming the grasshopper mentality (1)
content.introtext:
...we felt like grasshoppers next to them...' Numbers 13:33 NLT

You'll never know what you're made of spiritually until you come against something too big to handle alone. That's when you discover what you really believe. Moses sent twelve scouts to the Promised Land. They weren't the kind with badges on their sleeves for making campfires and tying knots, but spies sent to check out Israel's new homeland. They all saw the same thing: a land rich in honey, milk-and giants! Now that was literally a big problem! Acknowledging or knowing there's a problem isn't lack of faith. And it's not a sin. Paul said, '...we wanted to come to you...but Satan stopped us.' (1 Thessalonians 2:18 NIV) He knew there was a problem! The difference between the scouts was in how they saw the problem. Ten said, 'We saw the giants...and we were in our own eyes as grasshoppers,' but two scouts called Joshua and Caleb said, '...don't be afraid of the people of the land...The Lord is with us...' (Numbers 14:9 NLT) Real faith feeds off the stuff the enemy throws at you. Like the scene with Neo from The Matrix, faith has its arm stretched and beckons with its fingers: 'Bring it on! The Lord is with me!'

The negative report of the ten spies caused three reactions in the people:

(1) Fear. Fear is irrational. It can make you forget every good thing God has promised, or done for you.

(2) Some wanted to go back to Egypt-back to how things used to be.

(3) Others wanted to settle in the wilderness. You've got to move with the cloud, otherwise today's manna is the last you'll see.

So, is the God you serve bigger than the giant you see? He says He is.



SoulFood: Jer 49-50, Matt 6:19-34, Ps 122, Pr 15:10-14

content.title: Get into good habits (1)
content.introtext:
Everyone followed their old customs...' 2 Kings 17:34 CEV

Old customs' are like habits. Things you get used to, and do without even realising it half the time. Here, the people were in bad habits-their 'customs' meant they weren't worshipping God properly, and weren't being obedient. They kept on feeding the habits every day by not changing things-and the longer you do that, the harder the habit is to break.

When a habit is really deeply rooted, it can mean you have to hit rock-bottom before you even realise it's all gone wrong. So habits are really important things to get right-and what better time to start developing good habits and getting out of bad habits than right now?

Now, by 'bad habits', I'm not talking about things like biting your fingernails or interrupting a teacher in class and, by 'good habits', I don't mean always using a tissue when you sneeze or saying 'please' and 'thank you'.

Don't get me wrong, those things all make sense-but even more important are the habits you get into when it comes to your relationship with God. It's the most important relationship of your life, so you need to get it right. Many of our habits and customs are set when we're young-so get them sorted now. How? We'll look at that tomorrow.

content.title: Get into good habits (2)
content.introtext:
Everyone followed their old customs...' 2 Kings 17:34 CEV

Have you ever noticed that you end up acting a bit like your mates when you've spent loads of time with them? Well, why not get into the habit of spending loads of time with God-every day, even-and maybe then you'll end up acting more like Him. Pretty good habit, hey?

Do you find it hard to read your Bible when all your favourite shows are on at night? Make it a habit that you don't put the TV on when you get in from school or work until you've spent at least ten minutes in your room hanging out with God. Have you got a habit of gossiping with your mates, and criticising people behind their backs? Instead, get into the habit of praying for the people you struggle with every day. (You don't have to be kneeling with your eyes closed to pray-you can do it silently in your head whenever you see them.)

Do you always press 'snooze' on your alarm on a Sunday morning, and end up missing church, thinking 'it's ok, there's youth group on Thursday'? Get in the habit now of setting your alarm earlier and getting out of bed and into church instead-where better to hear from God than in His house? When you're too old for youth group, it's better to already be in the habit of meeting up with other Christians regularly, than having to start afresh. Make your habits good ones today.

content.title: Listen to the coach!
content.introtext:
They go from strength to strength...' Psalm 84:7 NIV

Going from strength to strength.' Sounds like a pretty good plan really, doesn't it? I mean, who wants to go from weakness to weakness? No one! So, how do you actually achieve going from 'strength to strength'? Well, it's all about growing, changing and building up the right muscles.

Think about all the athletes training for the 2012 Olympics for a minute. When they're working out and training, they'll all have coaches nearby, won't they? It's the job of the coach to point out where an athlete's strengths and weaknesses are, tell them where they're going wrong, and what to change to get better. The athlete chooses whether to pay any attention to the coach or not-but chances are, if they don't, they won't become the best. The coach is an expert, and only suggests changes and training to help them get better. Yeah, it'll probably be hard work: they'll have to try new things and scrap old ways they thought were good. But if they're committed to being the best, they'll listen to the coach and they'll likely get better.

What's that got to do with you? Well, you may not be training for the Olympics, but you do have a top-class coach watching your every move, just waiting to give you advice. He wants to help you become the best by changing the way you're doing things, and go from strength to strength. Who? God the Holy Spirit. So what are you waiting for-ask Him to coach you today.



SoulFood: Acts 1:1-3:10, Matt 8:1-9, Ps 109:1-15, Pr 15:22

content.title: Leap of faith
content.introtext:
...everyone who has will be given more...' Matthew 25:29 NIV

Every accomplishment in your life starts with a decision. It's not chance or fate that determines your destiny, but your choices. Jesus told the parable of the talents: a businessman gave three employees talents to invest. The first two doubled theirs. The third one buried his. Scared of losing it, he didn't even take a tiny risk. '"You bad and lazy servant!" his master said. "You knew, did you, that I reap harvests where I did not plant, and gather crops where I did not scatter seed?"' (Matthew 25:26 GNT)

God wants us to do the best with what He gives us, and that involves us making choices, and sometimes taking what feel like massive leaps of faith: 'without faith it is impossible to please God.' (Hebrews 11:6 NIV) Have faith that God will be with you when you make those tough choices, and that He's given you the skills to do what you need to. Don't waste the talents God has given you by being too scared to use them. Jesus ended His parable saying, '...to everyone who has, more will be given... Whoever does not have, even what he has will be taken away.' (Matthew 25:29 NKJ)

Your goal should be to 'maximise the investment' on everything you do. To get more, you must use what God's already given you. When you step out in faith, God moves, and extraordinary things happen. When you limit what you will do, you limit what you can do. Just think: if you don't act now, what could you be missing out on later?

content.title: Sound familiar?
content.introtext:
It is no trouble for me to write the same things to you...' Philippians 3:1 NIV

Do you get everything right first time? Be honest, and I bet the answer is 'no', isn't it? So why do you assume that others should? The people you admire and look up to won't always get it right first (or second, or third, or fourth...) time either! Paul understood that we all make mistakes, and sometimes we need to hear things loads of times before we eventually get it-which is why he said, 'It is no trouble for me to write the same things to you again, and it is a safeguard for you.'(Philippians 3:1 NIV) He understood that you have to keep hearing and doing it in order to get it right.

So, next time you're in church or youth group, and the talk sounds familiar, or even when you're reading word4U2day and it's a favourite old theme popping up, instead of switching off and thinking, 'They're not still on about that again, are they?', why don't you listen, and ask God if there's still something you can learn from it?

If not, appreciate that there may be others who need to hear that message again. Maybe, the reason they're still 'on about it' is because God's told them too-and until you get what He's trying to tell you, they'll just keep on going!

content.title: Down but not out
content.introtext:
...we are knocked down, we get up again.' 2 Corinthians 4:9 CEV

Do you ever feel like you keep getting knocked down, and as soon as you pick yourself up and brush off the dust, you're knocked down again? It makes you feel like a failure, but get this-YOU'RE NOT!

Pretty much every time you're knocked down, if you stop and look, you'll learn something. So although it may not feel like you're getting anywhere, when you look back you'll see that with each fall, you've taken a little step further forwards. It's so easy to focus on the negatives because the devil is spending all his time trying to make you feel like rubbish, a pathetic failure. You don't want him to win, do you? No! So next time you're knocked down and feeling beaten, try saying, 'Take a hike, Satan, you're not gonna keep me down.' Keep going with a smile on your face, thinking about what you can learn from the latest fall.

Remember too, that the things you do with ease now weren't that easy to start with. An article in The Wall Street Journal said: 'You've failed many times...you may not remember. You fell the first time you tried to walk... Did you hit the ball the first time you swung the bat?... the ones who hit the most home runs, also strike out a lot.'

Getting knocked down certainly doesn't make you a failure-but getting back up again is the key to becoming a success.

content.title: You're see-through to God
content.introtext:
Nothing is hidden from the Lord, and He judges what we do.' 1 Samuel 2:3 CEV

Don't try and trick God-He can see right through you! He can look right past what you're doing to what's going on in your heart. Yeah, it's great if you're doing fab things for others, being a real 'good Samaritan'. But if you're only doing it to impress someone, then God won't think much of it.

At the end of the day, if you're not making an impact with God, what's really the point of whatever you're doing? God is the ultimate judge. He's the one who created you so He's the one whose praise you should be seeking.

Learn from Jesus' teaching at the Sermon on the Mount. 'Watch out! Don't do your good deeds publicly, to be admired by others, for you will lose the reward from your Father in Heaven.' (Matthew 6:1 NLT) It's really not worth it, is it? While you're at it, why not go one step further-and act so that you're glorifying God, not yourself? Jesus also said, '...let your good deeds shine out for all to see, so that everyone will praise your heavenly Father.' (Matthew 5:16 NLT)

Remember today's word-nothing is hidden from God, and He's the one who will ultimately judge you-so check out your heart today. Is it ready for God to look at?

content.title: Learn to love better
content.introtext:
Love is always supportive, loyal, hopeful, and trusting.' 1 Corinthians 13:7 CEV

Before you switch off, thinking, 'Mushy stuff? Er, no thanks!' just stop a second. Even if you haven't got that special someone in your life who sets your heart racing and makes you weak at the knees, you'll still have friends and family who you love. (Go on-admit it!-you do care, don't you?)

So maybe it's worth stopping for a second, and seeing what we can learn about loving better. Here are just two top tips:

(1) Don't just use your ears to listen. Listen to the things people don't say, as well as the words they do. If your mates and family feel like you're really paying attention to their lives, they'll feel more loved and valued-which has got to be a good thing, right?

(2) Believe the best (and forget the rest!) So you'll have probably seen them at their worst-but reminding them of all that isn't necessarily going to make them feel supported, is it? Instead, focus on the best, remind them of the good times, tell them they do something well.

Yes, it's still really important to let them know if they're doing something dodgy, and to correct them gently if they keep mucking up in the same way-but it's just as important to give encouragement, whether they need it or not. Who knows-you might just make their day!

content.title: Go on-give!
content.introtext:
It is more blessed to give than to receive.' Acts 20:35 NCV

Errr, what? How backwards is that? Just what is this verse going on about?!

Ok, don't panic-no one's disputing that it's great when you get an awesome present, and this verse isn't saying it's wrong to get prezzies at all. What it does teach us, though, is that it's really important to give, as well. That doesn't mean God is saying you have to save all your hard earned cents and splash the cash on a complete stranger. But maybe it's time you had a think about what you could give to bless others around you.

How about offering to babysit, doing the shopping for your gran, or helping out the younger kids at Sunday school in church? You may be thinking: 'Yeah, but why bother?' Well, the simple answer is, you should bother because God wants you to. That's all the reason you need. As a child of God (that's what you are, by the way!) you should want to please Him-and He loves it when His children give to each other.

But get this-the added bonus is that when you do give, you'll end up getting blessed too! I can't tell you how or when-that's not how it works-and that shouldn't be your reason for doing the giving (remember, God knows what you're thinking), but God loves it so much when we bless others to please Him, He blesses us too! Win-win all round. So what are you waiting for? Get giving today.

content.title: Praise (1)-Like riding a bike
content.introtext:
I will praise You more and more.' Psalm 71:14 NLT

Have you ever watched a little kid learning to ride a bike? Maybe you even remember it yourself? There are tears and tantrums as they can't balance, fall off, get grazed knees, have to have training wheels or help from dad. It looks like they'll never get the hang of it, and they want to give up so often. But dad patiently keeps encouraging them, that it'll be worth it when they can-and, like the old saying goes, once you've learnt to ride a bike, you never forget. Before they know it, the kid is sailing off on their own, having fun with friends, enjoying the freedom that comes with cycling.

Praising God can be a bit like that-daunting to start off with, coz it seems like a mammoth task. (I mean, where do you even start, right?) However once you've started, and got it, it's great, and you may not even want to stop. It's so worth it when you do start praising.

The more you praise God, the more thankful you are to Him, the more you realise just why He needs praising, so the more you want to praise Him... you get the picture! So why not make the first move today? Start praising-just think of one thing you're grateful for. Then another. Before you know it, you'll be sailing off into the distance, praising God, wondering what took you so long, and maybe even enjoying it and encouraging others to give it a go too!

content.title: Praise (2)-Through thick and thin
content.introtext:
My mouth is filled with Your praise...all day long.' Psalm 71:8 NAS

Sometimes, it's the hardest times in our lives-the times when we least feel like praising God-that we really need to make the effort to do it anyway. It may feel like everything's gone wrong, things can't get any worse, and praising God is the last thing on our minds.

But just stop and think for a minute. Is ignoring God going to help at all? Um, no. Is whinging to God going to make you feel any better? Um, not really. So-why not give it a go, praise Him, and see what happens!

Check out the story in Acts 16 of Paul and Silas when they were in prison. They'd been badly beaten, were locked up when they didn't deserve to be, and were under special guard. Things couldn't have been much worse. So what did they do? Not what you'd expect at all. They didn't grumble or moan about the injustice of it-instead, then sang praise to God. At the top of their voices!

They trusted that no matter what, God was still an awesome God, and still worthy of praise. No matter how bad their situation was, God was still in control. And when they were singing and praying God moved in an amazing way. So today, why not stop moaning and start praising-it's not always easy, but it's powerful stuff, and God's worth every bit of it.

content.title: Foot Spa
content.introtext:
No...messenger [is] greater than the one who sent him.' John 13:16 NIV

Corns and calluses, bunions and blisters, cracked heels, fungus nails and athlete's foot: feet can be disgusting! Their stinky, sweaty, smelly stench can make you throw up-have a sniff of your sneakers, if you don't believe me!

Peter knew this, which is why he said to Jesus, 'You will never ever wash my feet!' (John 13:8 NLT) Jesus washed all His disciples' feet that day and He explained why: 'Unless I wash you, you won't belong to Me... I have given you an example to follow. Do as I have done to you.'(John 13:8;15 NLT)

Now before you go running for a foot spa, Jesus wasn't saying: 'Be a chiropodist'! He was saying, 'Be humble, serve one another'. A humble individual does things without thinking, 'What's in it for me?' Being humble comes with benefits-we get:

(1) Inside info: God lets us in on stuff. Psalm 25:9 NLT says, 'He leads the humble in doing right, teaching them His way.'

(2) God's help: Life's tough and we need help. God promises to look out for the humble. Psalm 147:6 NLT says, 'The Lord supports the humble, but He brings the wicked down into the dust.'

(3) To please God: When you know God, you want to please Him and being humble is the way. The Lord says in Isaiah 66:2 CEV: 'The people I treasure most are the humble-they depend only on Me and tremble when I speak.' 'I urge you to live a life worthy of the calling you have received. Be completely humble...' (Ephesians 4:1-2 NIV)

content.title: Growing Pains
content.introtext:
After you have suffered...He will place you on a firm foundation.' 1 Peter 5:10 NLT

Lizards, snakes, and spiders have something in common. They leave their old skins behind. Snakes shed their skin by brushing against something, like a rock, creating a rip in their skin-usually by its nose and mouth. The snake then works on this rip until it can shed its skin completely. They leave a long old scaly snakeskin and slither away with brand new, bigger and better, skin.

2 Corinthians 5:17 NLT tells us: 'anyone who belongs to Christ has become a new person. The old life is gone; a new life has begun!' This is just the beginning. We need to keep on growing up in this new life Jesus has given us.

Snakes don't just shed their skin once-they do it up to six times a year because if they don't, they won't stay healthy. We are a new creation and that doesn't change but we still need regular 'Spiritual Skin-Shedding Check-ups'. Staying away from church and letting your Bible gather dust can cause spiritual malnutrition and stunt your growth: '...let God transform you...by changing the way you think...' (Romans 12:2 NLT) 'Strip off every weight that slows [you] down, especially the sin that so easily trips [you] up.' (Hebrews 12:1-2 NLT)

Things can go wrong for the snake. Their skin can become too dry to shed and bits that stay attached become diseased. Growing up isn't easy but it's worth the effort-God promises '...after you have suffered a little while, He will restore, support, and strengthen you, and He will place you on a firm foundation.' (1 Peter 5:10 NLT)

content.title: You're on a Mission!

Go! I am sending you...' Luke 10:3 NIV

A missionary in Africa was once asked if he really liked what he was doing. His answer shocked people. 'Do I like this work?' he said. 'No. My wife and I do not like dirt... We do not like crawling into vile huts through goat refuse.'

This man knew that sometimes God asks you do the very thing you don't want to-and for him and his wife, it was stepping across animal poo! He wasn't happy about it, so why did He do it? content.title: Too good to be true?
content.introtext:
He always does exactly what He says.' 2 Corinthians 1:19 TLB

The scenario: They seem too good to be true; laid-back, fantastically fit, genuinely interested in what you've got to say. After hooking up, you start to think the unthinkable-they're the 'perfect dreamboat date'. Unfortunately, they forget to mention they already are 'the perfect date'-somebody else's!

Why is it in life that anything that seems 'too-good-to-be-true' usually is? The 'perfect' couple splits up. The 'perfect' friend stabs you in the back. The 'perfect' preacher caught red-handed. It's hard when the people you love and respect let you down; it shakes your world and you're left with that nagging doubt, 'Can I trust anybody?'

Perhaps, without realising, you carry that distrust into your faith. You pay lip-service when it comes to believing God is good but deep down your heart hesitates. Best not get your hopes up in case this God stuff turns out 'too-good-to-be-true'.

People may let you down but God won't: 'He always does exactly what He says. He...fulfils all...[His] promises.' (2 Corinthians 1:19-20 TLB) Now there's a verse to hang your hat on when everything seems out of focus. When that long streak of trials and troubles seems never-ending, that verse reminds you to cling by your fingernails to the promises God has given you. Holding out during life's storms is a sure-fire way to cultivate character and fire-blast your faith. Cling to God; He's too good to not come true on His promise.

content.title: How's your prayer life?
content.introtext:
It is time to seek the Lord...' Hosea 10:12 NKJ

You can do it anywhere! In your bedroom, in the kitchen, in the garden, on holiday; by the pool, up a mountain, in church, in the shops or on the bus. You can do it with one person, a group of people or just by yourself. The important thing is that you do it! Sometimes you might not want to; you're not in the mood; you don't think you're good at it; you think you're too young or it's not really important for you to do it right now. Sometimes you want to do it but you're scared of doing it wrong, you're frightened you'll mess it up. But no reason for not doing it is going to cut it-you have to do it! It can be anywhere, but it must be somewhere! It can be anytime but it must be a set time. Without prayer, what do you have to draw on? If you're spending hours watching TV but say you've no time to pray 'it is time to seek the Lord.' If you're living comfortably with sins that once troubled you, 'it is time to seek the Lord.' Prayer-there is nothing better. If you've come this far with little prayer, inconsistent prayer, or no prayer, think how far you'll go when you begin to pray. 'It is time to seek the Lord.'

content.title: Tomorrow never comes
content.introtext:
Seventy years are given to us!... But...soon they disappear...' Psalm 90:10 NLT

Today we need to ask ourselves, 'What am I doing with my time?'

You might think it doesn't matter: 'I've got all the time in the world, I can do what I like when I like!' When we think like this, we act like this-our actions always reflect what we're thinking: 'For as he thinks in his heart, so is he.' (Proverbs 23:7 NKJ)

Thinking we have all the time in the world means we don't bother doing things now-we can just do it tomorrow! But tomorrow never comes. We waste our time; we never get as fit as we can, as healthy as we could be, we never read enough, we ignore our family and our friends. God drops to the bottom of the heap. 'What, prayer? Bible study? Church? Tomorrow, next week, once the summer is over, after Christmas... yeah, I'll do it then!'

We don't have all the time in the world. Listen: 'Seventy years are given to us! Some even live to eighty. But...soon they disappear.' So give up your 'I'll do it tomorrow' attitude, because tomorrow never comes. Start living now! Don't waste the time God has given you, don't miss out on being the best you can be: 'for we are God's masterpiece. He has created us anew in Christ Jesus, so we can do the good things He planned for us long ago.' (Ephesians 2:10 NLT)

content.title: Time it right!
content.introtext:
My entire lifetime is...but a breath.' Psalm 39:5 NLT

What difference does it make, what I do with my time?' Good question! After all it is your life, isn't it? You never asked to be born, so you can do with it what you want, right?

But what if how you lived now and what you choose to do with your time affected your future... a life beyond death? In the big scheme of things, our moment in history is summed up by the psalmist who wrote: 'My entire lifetime is...but a breath.' But God promises us many times that it is possible to live forever-there is life beyond death.

Listen: 'For the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.' (Romans 6:23 NIV) And in John 11:25-26 NLT, Jesus says, 'I am the resurrection and the life. Anyone who believes in Me will live, even after dying. Everyone who lives in Me and believes in Me will never ever die.'

But with all that he had and all that he knew even he came to the conclusion that life is 'meaningless', it has no point, no purpose-unless it's lived knowing God. Our time is wasted and gets us nowhere unless we use it chasing after God, doing God stuff.

content.title: Forecast: heavy rain
content.introtext:
...seven times he said, "Go again."' 1 Kings 18:43 NKJ

There's a strange little bit in 1 Kings 18. For over three years there has been a drought in the land. Elijah the prophet has just witnessed God embarrass the beliefs of all false-god followers at Mount Carmel. And then, after promising rain to end a record-breaking dry spell. Elijah bows before God and tells his servant to go and look for signs of heavy clouds. Trouble was, the clouds were nowhere to be found. Seven times Elijah told his servant to go back and look for signs of rain. Only on the last time did the sky show the smallest sign of a cloud. And yet a few verses later we read about a black sky, a rising wind and heavy rain.

This odd weather forecast story teaches us about the unseen nature of faith. Elijah believed for rain even though he lived in a world of catastrophic drought. Even though the sky showed no promise of rain. Even though-six times-nothing has happened. It would have been easy to match up what he's seen with what he's said and come to the conclusion that maybe he's wrong. Faith asks us to believe despite what we see. Faith asks us to persist on believing despite what results we're experiencing. Faith asks for God's reign even in what seems like a long spell of drought.

Have you got the faith to believe for revival in this country's long drought of hearing the Word of God?

content.title: Mission possible
content.introtext:
...called according to His purpose.' Romans 8:28 NKJ

As you sent Me into the world, I have sent them into the world.' (John 17:18 NIV) Know who said those words? Know who He was talking about? Yup, you guessed it: Jesus was talking you up for a serious mission.

God started a major bit of reconstruction work in the world with the mission of Jesus and now He wants you in on the job. Your mission is two-fold: to lend support to other Jesus followers and to make Jesus known to His non-followers. Here are some things to be aware of to help you:

(1) Look within you. What moves you? What are you excited about? Paul said, '...I am compelled to preach...' (1 Corinthians 9:16 NIV) Maybe the thought of opening your mouth in front of heaps of people gives you the shakes, but there'll be something that you feel compelled to do. Answer that and you have a good clue for your mission.

(2) Look behind you. What has life taught you? Your experiences could be the key to helping others. If you know what it feels like to feel alone and unwanted, part of your mission will be to get alongside others who are going through the same and show them love and acceptance.

(3) Look ahead of you. Where everybody else is blind, what do you see? Your mission is to say something with your life.

content.title: Approved by God
content.introtext:
I have called you by your name; you are Mine.' Isaiah 43:1 NKJ

Have you noticed how everyone seems to have an opinion about you? And how so many people are quick to drag you down? Sometimes it's too hard to ignore what they say and we let their words rob us of our self-worth. Our self-esteem hits rock bottom-words like, 'I don't love you anymore', 'you're stupid', 'you're useless', 'you'll never learn', 'I wish you'd never been born', 'why can't you be more like your sister?' can leave us feeling like old bubblegum that's been scraped off the bottom of a shoe.

God wants you to know how precious you are, how valuable, how important you are to Him. You matter-He loves you just as you are. Listen to some of the things God says about you and never lose sight of your true value, your true worth. No matter what opinions others may form of you, it's only God's opinion of you that really matters.

...the Lord who created you says, "Do not be afraid-I will save you. I have called you by name-you are Mine... your troubles will not overwhelm you... the hard trials that come will not hurt you. For I am the Lord your God, the holy God of Israel, who saves you... I will give up whole nations to save your life, because you are precious to Me and because I love you and give you honour. Do not be afraid-I am with you!"' (Isaiah 43:1-5 GNT)



SoulFood: 2 Kings 24-25, Mark 14:12-26, Ps 73:17-28, Pr 13:20

content.title: Testing times (1)
content.introtext:
God has come to test you...so that you will not sin.' Exodus 20:20 GNT

Tests, exams: you can love them or hate them, pass them or fail them, but you can't avoid them! Sometimes they seem pointless, other times like your whole life depends on them!

In Exodus, Moses told the people; 'God has come to test you...so that you will not sin.' God had given them rules to live by, to test they were living right. Not a list of do's and don'ts to spoil their fun, but commands for their protection and profit.

Jesus teaches us the importance of passing God's test: 'Anyone who listens to My teaching and obeys Me is wise, like a person who builds a house on solid rock. Though the rain comes...and the floodwaters rise and the winds beat against that house, it won't collapse, because it is built on rock. But anyone who hears My teaching and ignores it is foolish, like a person who builds a house on sand. When the rains and floods come and the winds beat against that house, it will fall with a mighty crash.' (Matthew 7:24-27 NLT)

It's no good stashing our Bible in the back of the cupboard or skimming over the words and getting the general gist. We need to 'eat them up', know them and act on them if we are to pass the test of life.



SoulFood: Hosea 1-5, Mark 14:27-42, Ps 139:1-6, Pr 13:21-23

content.title: Testing times (2)
content.introtext:
God has come to test you...so that you will not sin.' Exodus 20:20 GNT

Chuck Swindoll tells the story of a bird named Chippy: 'Chippy the parakeet never saw it coming. One second he was peacefully perched in his cage singing, the next he was sucked in, washed up, and blown over. His problem began when his owner decided to clean his cage with a vacuum. She stuck the nozzle in to suck up the seeds and feathers at the bottom of the cage. Then the phone rang. Instinctively she turned to pick it up. She'd barely said 'hello' when-sswwwwPPPPP! Chippy got sucked in! She gasped, let the phone drop, and snapped off the hoover. With her heart in her mouth, she unzipped the bag. There was Chippy-alive, but stunned-covered with heavy black dust. She grabbed him and rushed to the bathtub, turned on the tap full blast and held Chippy under a torrent of ice-cold water, power-washing him clean. Then she did what any compassionate pet owner would do: she snatched up the hairdryer and blasted the wet, shivering little bird with hot air.'

Swindoll ends his story with these words: 'Chippy doesn't sing much any more.' In an instant, that parakeet's life went from Chirpy Chatty Chippy to Cheerless Choking Chippy. Life may throw you some tough tests, leaving you feeling like Chippy: vacuumed up, ice-blasted and blown to bits! But God doesn't want you to let them steal your song! '...the Spirit also comes to help us...' (Romans 8:26 GNT)



SoulFood: Hosea 6-10, Mark 14:43-52, Ps 139:7-12, Pr 13:24

content.title: Testing times (3)
content.introtext:
God has come to test you...so that you will not sin.' Exodus 20:20 GNT

A little boy was playing in his sandbox. Sitting in the middle, surrounded by his toys, he began to dig when he came across a huge rock. He dug around it but the rock was too big and his hands too little to lift it. So he pushed the rock with his feet to the side, but he couldn't roll it up over the little edge to get it out of his sandbox. The little boy grunted, struggled, pushed and shoved-but his only reward was to have the rock roll right back, smashing his chubby fingers. Finally, he burst into tears of frustration.

All the while the boy's dad was watching. The moment the tears started, a large shadow fell across the sandbox. It was his dad. Gently but firmly he said, 'Son, why didn't you use all the strength that you had available?' Defeated, the boy sobbed back, 'But daddy I did! I used all the strength I had!' 'No, son,' corrected the father kindly. 'You didn't use all the strength you had. You didn't ask me.' The father then reached down, picked up the rock and removed it from the sandbox.

Sometimes things happen that appear too difficult, but God doesn't expect us to handle things by ourselves, He's always there to help. Psalm 46:1 NIV says, 'God is our refuge and our strength, an ever-present help in trouble.' With God we can get through anything, so don't sit and struggle on your own-ask for His help.



SoulFood: Ex 20:16, Deut 19:15-20, Rev 21:8

content.title: Just do it
content.introtext:
Be strong in the faith, just as you were taught, and always be thankful.' Colossians 2:7 NCV

Once upon a time we all learnt to tie our shoelaces, perhaps with a little rhyme to help us along. But there definitely came a time when we no longer needed to ask 'how?' We just knew, so we stopped asking and just got on with it! We learn new things all the time, and when we've got it sussed we stop asking and just do it.

Being a Christian is about having a relationship with Jesus, getting to know God. What He likes, what He hates (yes, there really are things God hates-check out Proverbs 6). We learn what life's about, where we fit in, the things Christians should and shouldn't do. But there comes a time when we know it. We don't have to ask, 'What's that about?' because we just know. God expects us to just get on with it: 'Be strong in the faith, just as you were taught, and always be thankful.' (Colossians 2:7 NCV)

Don't wait around until you know everything about the Christian faith before you live it. That's never going to happen. Simply learn some, then do it. No more sitting around or hiding away.



SoulFood: Hosea 11-14, Mark 14:53-65, Ps 139:13-24, Pr 13:25
