During the first test, the 'fear test' Gideon lost 22,000 men, leaving only 10,000. Next was the 'water test' to 'Separate those who lap the water with their tongues like a dog from those who kneel down to drink' (v5). Only 300 soldiers passed the test! We learn two lessons from this story: 1) you need to be able to see your enemy approaching. Those who got down to drink like dogs, sacrificed their vision to satisfy their immediate need 2) when God reduces your support, it's in order to give you a miraculous victory. So when the people around you can't pass God's 'water test,' let them go and trust God. He has something better in mind.

content.title: Giving up 'centre stage'
content.introtext:
Let each of you look out...for the interests of others.

Philippians 2:4 NKJV
You see one of your mates and shout, 'How's it going?' Thinking you're actually interested, they come over to tell you something cool that happened to them yesterday. But you're not really interested are you so you jump in as fast as you can saying, 'Think that's cool? Let me tell you about...' You're off and running, making every effort to outdo them and prove that your life is way more interesting that theirs! Meanwhile, your mate's wishing they'd just kept walking when they first saw you. They'd hoped to hear something like, 'That's awesome, tell me more.' Instead they just get an earful of your ego. The Bible says, 'Let each of you look out not only for his own interests, but also for the interests of others.' In other words, give up 'centre stage.' That's easier said than done when we tend to only be bothered with one person - me! Whatever happened to 'Rejoice with those who rejoice...' (Romans 12:15 NIV)? Those simple words remind us that life is not supposed to be a competition - it's supposed to be a celebration! So next time you feel the urge to interrupt, practice saying, 'Enough about me. How are things with you?' Then listen! Listen with your ears, your eyes, your mind and your spirit. Try to understand the feelings coming through. Then you can 'Rejoice with those who rejoice; mourn with those who mourn..' (Romans 12:15 NIV)

content.title: Will you be one of them?
content.introtext:
If My people who are called by My name...

2 Chronicles 7:14 NKJV
This time last year nobody was thinking about saving money; it was 'business as usual', spend, spend, spend. Wow, haven't times change? Skyrocketing fuel prices have forced people to park their petrol-guzzlers and take the bus. Other people were talking about 'climbing the property ladder'; now they're struggling to pay their mortgage. Flash floods seem to strike whenever they please. It feels like our security blanket has been ripped away and our comfort zone shaken to its core. But there is an ancient Word for these crazy days; it's an old message for a new generation. 'If My people who are called by My name will humble themselves, and pray and seek My face, and turn from their wicked ways, then I will hear from heaven, and will forgive their sin and heal their land' (2 Chronicles 7:14). Have you heard those words before? Can you sense God speaking from eternity? Those words are a reminder that every action brings a reaction. If we spend money we haven't got, if we treat the planet like it's disposable, trouble will definitely come our way. Listen, we need to turn things around and someone needs to set an example. Even within a pampered church that majors on 'what God will do for you, and how to get Him to do it', God has people willing to be humble and get praying. The question is, will you be one of them?

content.title: Nothing is more important than love
content.introtext:
...live a life of love...

Ephesians 5:2 NIV
The great Scottish writer Thomas Carlyle married his secretary, Jane Welsh. She kept working for him but when she got ill, Carlyle, who was devoted to his work, didn't really notice. But she had cancer and was eventually confined to bed. Although Carlyle loved her, he found that he didn't have much time to give attention to give to her. Then she died. After the funeral Carlyle found Jane's diary and began to read it. On one page she'd written a single line: 'Yesterday he spent an hour with me and it was like heaven: I love him so much.' A reality he'd somehow been too blind to see now revealed itself with crushing clarity. He'd been too busy to notice how much he meant to Jane. He thought of all the times he'd been preoccupied with his work and failed to notice her. He hadn't seen her suffering. He hadn't seen her love. Turning the page, he read words he'd never forget: 'I've listened all day to hear his steps in the hall, but now it's late, he won't come today.' Thomas was devastated. Later, friends found him at the side of her grave, covered with mud. His eyes were red from weeping, 'If only I'd known, if only I'd known,' he cried. After Jane's death, Carlyle made little attempt to write again. Nothing is more important than love. Is there anyone you need to spend time with today?

content.title: Passion plus...
content.introtext:
Love the Lord your God with all your heart...

Deuteronomy 6:5 NIV
There's an interesting sequence of events leading up to Peter's denial of Christ. First, Jesus warned Simon Peter that he was a target: '"...Satan has asked to sift you as wheat. But I have prayed for you, Simon, that your faith may not fail..."' (Luke 22:31-32 NIV). Next we read that when the guards had arrested Jesus, Peter '...followed at a distance' (Luke 22:54 NIV). Later that same night Peter, the man who swore he'd die for Jesus, denied knowing Him. Then the cockerel crowed, Peter realised what he'd done, and he '...went outside and wept bitterly' (Luke 22:55-62 NIV). Can you see the three steps? 1) you don't pay attention to the warnings about the enemy's attack b) you allow situations to get between you and Jesus; you start to follow 'at a distance' 3) you end up denying Jesus by your words or actions. It's a classic process that happens to lots of people, so don't say, 'That will never happen to me.' That's what Peter said! Instead make sure you stay on your guard, and stay passionate. That red-hot fire inside you to make Jesus known is like your fuel for the race. Lewis Hamilton wouldn't win many Grand Prix races without fuel, but he also has to stay focused too, as every lap contains new dangers. So there's the Word 4u 2day, keep your passion alive and stay focused, then you'll withstand any attacks.

content.title: God will provide!
content.introtext:
'...do not worry...'

Matthew 6:31 NIV
King David writes, 'I was young and now I am old, yet I have never seen the righteous forsaken or their children begging bread' (Psalm 37:25 NIV). Nobody can say that King David lived a 'sheltered life'! He lived on the front line, and so when as an old man he shares his reflections about the way the world works we need to pay attention. His advice to the next generation is to learn how to lean on God: 'Trust in the LORD and do good; dwell in the land and enjoy safe pasture. Delight yourself in the LORD and he will give you the desires of your heart. Commit your way to the LORD; trust in him and he will do this;' (Psalm 37:3-5 NLT). The sad thing is, even though David, Israel's greatest King, took the time to write down this advice, and even though it was taught year in year out in the schools and the synagogues of the land, the people just didn't follow it. When Jesus began to minister He had to deal with the same issue saying: 'Do not worry, saying, "What shall we eat?" or "What shall we drink?" or "What shall we wear?"...your heavenly Father knows that you need them. But seek first his kingdom and his righteousness, and all these things will be given to you as well' (Matthew 6:31-33 NIV). So today, relax, no really, chill, trust, God will provide!

content.title: 'Freeze!'
content.introtext:
...take captive every thought...

2 Corinthians 10:5 NIV
Nineteen-year-old Liu Shih-Kun was an amazing pianist in China until the 1966 Cultural Revolution banned all things of Western influence. Refusing to renounce his beloved music, Liu was branded an enemy of the state and thrown into a tiny jail cell with no friends, no books, and even worse; no piano. Six years later, for political reasons, he was asked to play in Beijing with the Philadelphia Orchestra. After years without an instrument to practice on, he performed brilliantly. Eighteen months later when he was finally released, he again played flawlessly. His secret? Stripped of everything musical, for seven and a half years Liu disciplined himself to shut out negative thoughts and practice hour after hour on an imaginary piano. What if you were in that position; all alone, the things you love taken away, would you find a positive focus or would you freak out and think of the worst thing that could happen? Police shout 'Freeze!' when they want to stop a suspect and protect themselves. And you can freeze out harmful thinking by capturing every thought and making it 'obedient to Christ.' Paul says: 'For our struggle is not against flesh and blood, but against... the spiritual forces' (Ephesians 6:12 NIV). Your thoughts have power. To win over them, you must totally surrender to Jesus and control what you allow your mind to dwell on.

content.title: Back at square one
content.introtext:
..."Throw your net on the right side....."

John 21:6 NIV
Have you ever had an amazing day, a day when everything went right, when you were totally in the zone, a day you hoped would never end? And then you woke up the next morning and everything was plain and ordinary and boring again. Why is life like that? The four gospels all give us a different angle on the life of Jesus and, especially when it comes to the events after His resurrection, they all pick out different details we have to stitch together. We know this: Jesus rose from the dead, met Mary Magdalene first and later that day appeared to the 11 disciples. But then, maybe a week or so after that, they went back to what they were doing before they met Him: fishing. After something massive has happened we can crave the simplicity and security of what we know, we end up like the disciples: back at square one. But there's good news: If God called you, you're still called. Jesus shouts to the guys from the shore giving them identical instructions to the very first day He met them (Luke 5). Once again an ordinary day is touched with the extraordinary as Jesus steps into the scene. That morning Jesus ate breakfast with them, chatted with them, encouraged them and reminded them that they should always be ready to be interrupted by a visit from the Master.

content.title: Up and Down the Mountain (2)
content.introtext:
...if you have faith...

Matthew 17:20 NIV
When the disciples came down from the Mountain they encountered an epileptic boy who kept having fits. His dad was totally desperate. What happened next was a valuable lesson for them, and for us... 4) Do what you've always done, get what you've always got. It takes more than personality and religious catch-phrases to set people free from illness; and this was a biggie! Sadly the disciples were powerless because they were prayerless. Jesus said: '...this kind does not go out except by prayer and fasting' (Matthew 17:21 NAS). Persistent prayer is the price we pay for walking in power. 5) Rise above the attitudes you see around you. Jesus confronted the core problem: '..."O faithless...generation"' (Matthew 17:17 NKJV). Now before you say 'That's a bit heavy JC!' just think, why should we act all wishy-washy in the face of a faithless generation moulded by godless media. If we let it, it will pull us down and wear us out. So we need to get tough. That day Jesus said, '"If you have faith as small as a mustard seed, you can say to this mountain, 'Move'"...and it will move"' (Matthew 17:20-21 NIV). Here's two final thoughts: a) 'If you have faith.' Everybody around you doesn't have to have faith in order for you to see miracles b) you don't have to be a spiritual giant; just use your ickle mustard-seed faith and God will move stuff for you.

content.title: Up and Down the Mountain (1)
content.introtext:
...Jesus took...Peter, James and John...up a high mountain...

Matthew 17:1 NIV
There's five things to look at in this story - we'll look at three today and two tomorrow: 1) Not everybody gets to go up the mountain. Jesus didn't take everybody and He didn't explain or apologise to those disciples who stayed behind. He loves us all equally but He doesn't give us all the same experiences with Him. He knows what He's doing, so trust Him. 2) Those who go up the mountain aren't more spiritual. After seeing Jesus glowing with God's glory, Peter blurted out, 'Let's build three tents and stay here.' Peter was keen, but a bit daft too. Learn from his mistake and shut up so you can listen what God has to say, then take steps to make sure you build your life on His Word. 3) God's plan is to make Jesus famous, not you. 'While he was still speaking, a bright cloud enveloped them, and a voice from the cloud said, "This is my Son, whom I love; with him I am well pleased. Listen to him"...When they looked up, they saw no one except Jesus' (Matthew 17: 5-8 NIV). The number one challenge in your life is getting to the place where you focus on 'no one except Jesus.' The most important relationship you have is with Him and the only plan that will work out right is the one He gives you.

content.title: No Pain No Gain
content.introtext:
...those who were scattered went everywhere preaching the word.

Acts 8:4 NKJV
As we read through the New Testament we see the young church exploding with growth. They were obviously doing something right. Did they have great worship leaders that played guitars? Did they have nice buildings with comfy seats? Did they podcast their sermons around the world on iTunes? Actually, no to all those. The crazy thing is that the Bible shows us how it was in times of persecution (agro, intimidation, prejudice and violence) that the church grew most quickly. It's a powerful reminder that the bad times, not just the good ones, cause us to grow. Even though they don't know it some of the people who give you a hard time for being a Christian can help you out without even it. As you stand your ground your faith-muscle gets stronger. Like Joseph, you can look back years later and say, '...you meant evil against me; but God meant it for good...' (Genesis 50:20 NKJV). If God lets you to go through a tough time then it must be for your good or for the good of others through your example. Understanding this takes you deeper in your walk with God. So, whether the battle is over your family, your education, your health, or your friendships, expect three things: 1) the closer you get to victory the more intense the battle; 2) what matters isn't your comfort but your calling; 3) God is totally on your side, so keep fighting!

content.title: Save yourself the embarrassment!
content.introtext:
...you will forget the shame of your youth...

Isaiah 54:4 NKJV
Parents have 1001 ways of embarrassing their teenagers. It just comes naturally to them! The worst of them all is reserved for that special occasion when you bring your boyfriend or girlfriend round for the first time. It's all going really nicely and then it happens: 'Ooh, I bet you'd like to see some old pictures of...' ...and you can insert your name at the end of that sentence. The family photo album comes out and you wish the ground would swallow you up. The scary thing is, you've now entered a stage of life when for lots and lots of people, really big mistakes are made, really bad choices leading to all sorts of mess. Are you going to be a casualty or will you get through to adulthood with mind, body and spirit in good shape? Imagine 10 years from now looking back at a video of your teenage years - will it be embarrassing or will you be happy to let it be seen? Is today's Bible verse going to be something you need to reach for in the future or will you make sure that it doesn't apply to you? One thing's for sure, if you commit each day to God then the chances of you stuffing up are seriously reduced. So what are you waiting for; ask Him to show you which direction to go in today.

content.title: Seventy-seven times!
content.introtext:
..."How many times shall I forgive?...

Matthew 18:21 NIV
In the book of Genesis Cain kills his brother Abel, but bizarrely God's judgment is to put a mark on him, saying that if anyone killed Cain they'd pay for it seven times over. Cain had a great-great grandson, called Lamech. One day somebody hurt Lamech, who then killed the guy, saying, 'I have killed a man for wounding me...If Cain is avenged seven times, then Lamech seventy-seven times' (Genesis 4:23-24 NIV). In his mind he was absolutely justified. The guy who did him wrong, had it coming. The spirit of revenge is never satisfied. Simply stated: It doesn't work! Fast forward to the New Testament, Peter had been hurt by someone close to him, and it happened more than once. So he went to Jesus and asked, 'How many times do I have to forgive? Seven times?' Peter thought he was being dead generous and expected Jesus to pat him on the back but Jesus deflated his ego by saying he must forgive the offender, 'not seven times, but seventy-seven times.' Where did Jesus get that number? From the Old Testament. Jesus knew the Scriptures well, so He chose it deliberately. He was tearing up the story of Lamech once and for all! So what about you; you can follow in the footsteps of Lamech and retaliate, or you can follow Jesus and keep extending forgiveness; but you can't do both!

content.title: Look in the rear-view mirror
content.introtext:
...After the fire came a gentle whisper

1 Kings 19:12 NIV
A respected author writes: 'I was driving a safe distance behind the car in front when the driver slammed on his brakes. I stopped short, but the car behind was too close and rammed into my Jeep. There was no real damage, but as I drove off something about the incident nagged at me. Weeks later I was on a fast-moving motorway. Behind me was a huge truck loaded with cars...in front were several cars...and up ahead, a school bus. Suddenly I noticed the brake lights from the cars ahead. The bus had stopped to let a child off. I pulled to a stop behind the car in front; then I remembered the lesson from the accident earlier. Sometimes I can stop safely, but the driver behind me can't. When I looked in my rear-view mirror the truck loaded with cars was frantically trying to stop. I pulled over, giving him an extra car length, and he screeched to a stop, right behind the car ahead of me. If I hadn't listened we'd all have piled up.' There are often times when God gives us gentle checks, a little reminder or nudge that we should or shouldn't do something. Paying attention to these often tiny, split second decisions can end up changing the course of your life forever. So when you feel a tiny nudge, don't ignore it!

content.title: Are you approachable? (2)
content.introtext:
But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, self-control

Galatians 5:22-23 NAS
Approachable people are like this: 1) Personal warmth; they actually like people. Ok, so some people are a nightmare, but the truth is that people suss out whether you like them or not. And if you're going to be approachable you need to learn to love people! 2) Their moods are consistent. How frustrating are moody people? You never know how they'll be. If you're moody, people will be scared to talk to you. 3) Sensitivity to people's feelings. Although approachable people are emotionally stable, they don't expect everyone to be that way. They recognise that good people have bad days; and act sensitively to that. 4) They understand human weakness, including their own. Don't be down on yourself, but be honest about your own weaknesses. When you're not trying to show people how fantastic you are and admit your struggles other people will be honest too. An old proverb says: 'Blessed are they who can laugh at themselves, for they shall never cease to be amused.' And because they can admit their own faults, they don't have a problem allowing other people to have faults as well. 5) The ability to forgive, and ask for forgiveness. Sometimes you screw up. Fact. We all do. So why do we often find it so hard to admit that? When you've messed up, say sorry. Get over yourself and ask for forgiveness. When you can do this other people will do it too.

content.title: Are you approachable? (1)
content.introtext:
But the fruit of the Spirit is... kindness, goodness... gentleness,

Galatians 5:22-23 NKJV
Before we look at whether or not we're approachable, we've got to ask 'do we care?' After all, some of us quite like the idea that people are scared of us, or that we're 'well 'ard'. People like this don't tend to be very approachable, because you never know what response you're going to get! But is this really how you want people to see you? You might feel good thinking people are scared of you, but it's hard to make good friends. Let's take Jesus as an example. He was the ultimate hardman, and talk about scary; He was the Son of God AND could do pretty much anything He liked! Yet people flocked to Him in their thousands, His disciples never left his side. And why? It was because Jesus showed all the fruits of the Spirit. He was no walk over, yet He had so much compassion for people. When people were trying to kill Him, He fought back with love. He was kind, He loved kids, He was gentle and humble but at the same time He knew He was the Son of God. He knew He had the strength of Father God to draw on when He felt weak. Let's think about how we can model ourselves on Jesus today. We've the same Father God watching our back so drop the well 'ard act and do it, Jesus style!

content.title: Living with a thankful heart!
content.introtext:
I will bless the Lord at all times...

Psalm 34:1 NKJV
David said, 'I will bless the Lord at all times: his praise shall continually be in my mouth.' A thankful heart isn't always easy to have but it's defo better than being bitter and miserable, in fact it can save your life! When Jonah disobeyed God and ended up inside the whale, he told God, '...I will sacrifice to You with...thanksgiving...' (Jonah 2:9 NKJV). When he did, God made the fish spit him up on dry land. When you're down in the dumps and life's feeling rubbish, that's when you need to open your trap and praise God. Nothing shows trust like thanking God when life's smacking you round the head. This does two things: 1) It builds your faith. David said, '...magnify the Lord with me...' (Psalms 34:3). Picture a giant magnifying glass pointed at God. When you remember just how big God is, the problem becomes so tiny it's ridiculous! Plus, '...faith comes by hearing...the word of God' (Romans 10:17 NKJV). Hearing God's promises coming from your own lips, causes faith to rise in your heart. So start talking! 2) It restores life. Before raising Lazarus from the dead, Jesus looked up to heaven and said, '"Father...thank You that You have heard Me. And I know that You always hear Me..."' (John 11:41-42 NKJV). As soon as you thank God for stuff you're faith levels rocket, then the grey can turn to colour.

content.title: Always Available
content.introtext:
God is our refuge and strength...

Psalm 46:1 NIV
Yesterday we began to think a bit about the troubled world we live in. Terrorism, wars, hurricanes, tsunamis, crime, disease. Every night the media invades our homes bringing all this stuff to us in glorious Technicolor. The result is that our emotions can take a bit of a battering. Instead of having a true grasp of reality our minds start producing all sorts of worries about the future - what if we're next? In response to that the Bible says three things: 1) 'God is our refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble.' When you're in a tight spot, God is totally available to help you. Read the whole Psalm - there's no catch, it doesn't say that God will help you occasionally or reluctantly. No, He's there for you, always. What more do you need? 2) 'Therefore we will not fear' (v. 2 NIV). Don't panic, talk defeat, or give in to despair. A songwriter said, 'He's as close as the mention of his name.' Just breathe His name in prayer, and He'll be there for you. 3) 'Before the rush and roar of oceans, the tremors that shift mountains' (v. 3 TM). When everything you once thought to be solid and dependable, is shaken to the core you'll be where you've always been; in the strong and loving arms of God; the One who's always available to help.

content.title: Facing the elements
content.introtext:
In every thing give thanks...

1 Thessalonians 5:18 NKJV
This time of year can be a real drag, can't it. You get up and leave the house in the morning... it's dark. You pack up to go home again later on in the afternoon... it's dark. And it's cold. Yep, this is the time of year when your mood can hit rock bottom and before you know it every other word off your lips is some kind of moan, groan or complaint. Well just be careful, if you let a bit of mouldy weather get you down what will you do when real hardship comes along? Joseph was people-trafficked by his own shady brothers! He couldn't possibly have known that God would turn their actions inside out and establish him as Prime Minister. Joe just had to take each day as it came 'making the most of every opportunity...' (Ephesians 5:16 NIV). And Joseph's not the only one, the Bible tells story after story where difficulty actually makes people stronger. Listen, there's a plan unfolding in your life, and it isn't affected by rain or snow or sleet or hail! Around this world there are some places that don't have a lot of God's kingdom happening, war zones, places of poverty, disaster sites. God loves the people in those places as much as he loves you and he needs people prepared to face the environments, that He might be glorified. So see this winter as a practice run!

content.title: You must understand the reason
content.introtext:
...let grain from the bundles fall purposely for her...

Ruth 2:16 NKJV
OK, last day on Ruth. Let's keep going where we left off yesterday. Ruth, right in the middle of feeling loss, feeling hungry, feeling homesick, suddenly gets more than she ever needed dropped right into her lap. She didn't deserve it, didn't earn it, and couldn't even understand it. It's called grace; it's how God works! But here's the health warning: If you're not used to being blessed it might not take long before it starts going to your head! That's why the Bible says: 'Remember that God, your God, gave you the strength to produce all this wealth' (Deuteronomy 8:18 TM). And here's the small print (you should always read the small print!) God doesn't bless you so you can sit back and count your wads, or so you can strut around posing in all your bling. God's gifts are just tools to help you do His will. That's all that matters. At the end of the day what good is that stuff, if it takes you miles away from God? When God gives you something, He wants you to use it to make Him famous. So, when God gives you His blessings, be sure to read the instructions that go with them; only then will you find true fulfilment! So have you got it? God is the source of everything you have; and ever will have!

content.title: 'Finding yourself'
content.introtext:
...she found herself working in a field belonging to Boaz...

Ruth 2:3 NIV
Ruth had made a brave decision to travel with her mother-in-law to a place she didn't know. But now life was spiralling downward. Her husband was gone. Home was a long way away; there was no money in the bank. She was in survival mode which meant hanging around the fields picking up off-cuts from the harvest. Not a good look, ladies. Then God started turning things around. The guys cutting the harvest started dropping handfuls of barley in her path; undeserved blessings. Why? Because the boss (Boaz) saw Ruth hanging around and told his workers, 'leave them for her to pick up' (Ruth 2:16 NIV). Ruth had no idea that word had been spoken, she just started getting blessed! And you don't know what God will speak over your life. Suddenly everything can change! Doors can be opened, mountains can be moved. What's happening? Your steps are being ordered by the Lord (Psalm 37:23). And you don't even have to worry about somebody else getting what's yours, because nobody can pick it up except you; the boss says so! The minute the boss started showing favour to her, Ruth's downward spiral was over. She came from the fringes to the foreground. Instead of only looking forward to off-cuts she got the cream of the crop. When God speaks, that can happen very quickly. So be ready!

content.title: Who belongs in your life?
content.introtext:
"...Where you go I will go..."

Ruth 1:16 NIV
Ruth told Naomi, 'Where you go I will go.' Relationships are weird. Suddenly you can meet someone and 'tzzzzt' - there's an electric connection between you. It's what made Elisha quit farming and follow Elijah, a prophet with self-esteem issues; it's why Timothy hung out with Paul, an old man with a habit of getting into fights. You know instantly, 'I won't reach my destiny without you in my life.' Looking back you realise if you hadn't met that certain person, you wouldn't be where you are today. On the other hand, 'Orpah kissed her mother-in-law goodbye' (Ruth 1:14 NIV). Now Orpah's leaving didn't make her a bad person; it just meant her part in the story was over. Listen, you need to learn to recognise when somebody's part in your story is over, otherwise you'll just drive each other nuts. Yep, it can be hard to admit something is over, especially a relationship. Look, if God wants that for you He'll make it work. But if it blatantly ain't working then accept His will in the matter. Get up, go outside, put one foot in front of the other and start living again! Never beg anyone to stay with you against their will. Their leaving is no accident; it just means God has something better in store for you (and possibly them too), so trust Him and move on!

content.title: You gain through your pain
content.introtext:
...Naomi was left without her two sons and her husband.

Ruth 1:5 NIV
When hers sons died, Naomi experienced a unique bonding process with her daughters-in-law, Ruth and Orpah, who (obviously) had lost their husbands. Unless you've been through something like it, it's hard to understand that kind of bond. Tragedy can bring together the oddest people. When you're hurting, don't look for support from people based on what they look like or where they live. All you want is someone who's been there themselves, someone who really knows what you're going through. People can't give you what they don't have. The old preacher Charles Spurgeon gets at this issue using the image of soldiers returning from battle, 'Just as old soldiers compare stories and scars, when we arrive at our heavenly home we'll tell of the faithfulness of God Who brought us through. I wouldn't like to be pointed out as the only one who never experienced sorrow, or feel like a stranger in the midst of that sacred fellowship. Therefore be content to share in the battle, for soon we will wear the crown.' So if you're fighting just to get through another day, remind yourself that you aren't the first and you won't be the last to do so. Like Naomi, God sees what you're going through and has plans for your life yet to be revealed. Be encouraged. You will gain through your pain. Hold on to His hand; He'll bring you through this!

content.title: Be grateful for your blessings
content.introtext:
I went away full, but the Lord has brought me back empty...

Ruth 1:21 NIV
When it comes to valuable life-lessons, the book of Ruth is right up there. For the next few days we're gonna dig into it... When famine came to Bethlehem, Naomi, her husband and two sons moved to Moab where the economy was thriving. What they hoped would be a short stay turned into ten years. The lads married two local girls, Ruth and Orpah. Then the unthinkable happened; Naomi's husband and both sons died! As you might expect she was absolutely gutted. She heard that things were back on the up in Bethlehem so she decided to go home. After arriving back safely she said, 'I went out full, and the Lord has brought me home again empty' (NKJV). She was choking on the irony that she'd left a land of nothing for a land of plenty and come back with even less than she set out with. The truth is, you can be blessed and not know it. You never miss the water till the tap runs dry! Only as you look back do you realise that what you have is much more important than the things you don't have. Have you been saying, 'I'll be happy when...'? Forget it, happiness doesn't come from getting what you want, it comes from appreciating what God's given you. So take a few minutes today to put down that wish list and just say some simple thank yous.

content.title: Inside Outside
content.introtext:
I came so they can have real and eternal life, more and better life than they ever dreamed of.

John 10:10 TM
Living your fullest life needs help from two places: the inside and the outside. 1) The Inside: You need to be able to dig deep and to how to go the extra mile. Yep, that means extra effort and extra time. Mega business dude Andrew Carnegie had this sussed and was fond of saying, 'There's no use in trying to help people who won't help themselves. You cannot push anyone up a ladder unless he or she is first willing to climb it.' The apostle Paul puts it like this: 'each one should carry his own load' (Galatians 6:5). 2) The Outside: You need to be teachable, open to other people whom God brings along to input into your development. This isn't just a good idea, it's a God idea; called discipleship, or basically, mentoring. Good mentors lead by example; they know that to have influence they first need your respect. They treat you as an individual understanding your strengths and weaknesses. They notice whether you're right-brained (creative) or left-brained (methodical). They find out whether you learn visually or verbally. They know when you need a pat on the back or a kick in the butt! They're someone who, like the apostle Paul, can say 'Follow my example, as I follow the example of Christ.' (1 Corinthians 11:1 NIV) If you can get a mentor you'll be well blessed. So don't hang about, ask God to bring you one!

content.title: The J word
content.introtext:
...I coveted them and took them...

Joshua 7:21 NIV
Christmas was three weeks ago now and all of a sudden those trainers you thought were the bomb as you tucked into your turkey feel pretty sad compared to the new style that's just been released. Or what about that new mobile you mithered for months about? Yeah, you were well happy with it until first day back when you found out she had one too! If that sounds a bit like you then you need to pay attention today because it sounds like 'stuff' has got a hold of you. There's a story from the book of Joshua about the time when things started going wrong for Israel; they started losing battles. Joshua asked God why and God said it was because there was sin in the camp. When Joshua started doing a bit of detective work one of his soldiers, confessed, 'While we were in Jericho, I saw a beautiful Babylonian robe... and a gold bar... I wanted them for myself, so I took them.' At the end of the story it cost the guy his life and the lives of his family. When you get jealous about stuff you're basically putting something else in the place of God. If you think you really do need (not just want) something, pray about it and trust God to give it to you! In the meantime be grateful for what He's already given you.

content.title: Control your anger (2)
content.introtext:
Refrain from anger and turn from wrath

Psalm 37:8 NIV
A bad temper is not something to be proud of, but prayed over. When you blow your top, you just reveal your contents. And which of us hasn't done that, and regretted it? Here's three ways to get your lid firmly back on! 1) Less is more: By cramming too much stuff into too little time, you wind yourself up! Like violin strings that are pulled too tight, you end up snapping, then feeling guilty because you're not 'spiritual' enough. 'Do not think of yourself more highly than you ought, but rather think of yourself with sober judgment, in accordance with the measure of faith God has given you.' (Romans 12:3-4 NIV). 2) Don't be a hammer: If you want to get on in life you'll need to tackle different problems in different ways. People whose only tool is a hammer have got no choice but to treat every problem like a nail. Before long they've got holes all over the house, so put the hammer (anger) down! You know, the bible describes 9 different fruit of the spirit but not one of them is anger (see Galatians 5:22) 3) What's the point: Sometimes 'enough is enough' and you need to speak up. When Jesus got angry in the temple he had a point because poor people were being ripped off and he was drawing attention to it. In this case, '...if you know the right thing to do and don't do it, that, for you, is evil' (James 4:17 TM).

content.title: Control your anger (1)
content.introtext:
In your anger do not sin.

Ephesians 4:26 NIV
Everyone, except the emotionally disturbed, likes to think of themselves as deep-down basically an OK person. And most people are, until they get angry. You see, anger dissolves personality. Anger is that it brews and festers invisibly waiting for its moment and then - KABOOM! The nicest, sweetest people can explode in a ball of rage. It ain't pretty! So what if that's you? Or maybe you've not exploded yet but you can feel your fuse burning shorter and shorter. Listen to what Paul says: 'In your anger do not sin.' (NIV). Does that mean it's always bad to get mad? No, Paul is making the point that we can't help things happening that stir us to feeling angry, but we have a choice not to let that anger lead to sin. You can scream something really hurtful and nasty at your sister / brother / mum / dad (or whoever) or you can let off steam in your bedroom by screaming into your pillow! One of those things is OK by God and the other isn't! Sometimes we're angry because we think people don't appreciate us, or take advantage of us. Again Paul writes: 'Get rid of all...anger...forgiving each other...as...God forgave you' (Ephesians 4:31-32 NIV). So, if you're inclined to be hot-tempered, ask God now to remind you of all the times He's forgiven you. It's a great way to cool off ;-) [KMP1]

content.title: I just want to know
content.introtext:
...to depart and be with Christ...is far better.

Philippians 1:23 NKJV
A kid wrote a letter to God, addressed it to heaven and posted it. Letters like that usually end up in the bin in the corner of the Post Office, but somehow this one was opened. It read, 'Dear God, what's it like to die? I don't want to do it, I just want to know. Your friend, Michael.' It's a big question that lots of Christians have spent a very long time thinking about. Harold Sala sees it like this: 'When I'm going to a part of the world I've never been to, I read and investigate to find out what it's like. I browse travel books, go on the Internet, talk with someone who can tell me what it's like from personal experience. No other book in the world can tell me what the Bible tells me about heaven. The only person who has been there and can tell me what it's like, is Jesus.' At the end of the final Narnia book The Last Battle, the characters die in a train accident and CS Lewis wraps up the story like this: 'The things that [happened] after that were so beautiful I cannot write them. For us this is the end of all the stories, but for them it was only the beginning of the real story.' But we'll leave the last word to the Apostle Paul: '...we know that if the earthly tent we live in is destroyed, we have a building from God, an eternal house in heaven...' (2 Corinthians 5:1).

content.title: Resolving conflict, God's way!
content.introtext:
...speaking the truth in love, we will...grow up...

Ephesians 4:15 NIV
There are two ways to tell the truth. The 'give them a piece of your mind' style, which only makes things worse, or God's way: 'Speaking the truth in love.' Suppose a couple always argue because he's always late. How can she get her message heard by 'speaking the truth in love'? Here's a five possible ways: She could say to him: 1) 'I feel frustrated.' No blame, no attack; just an honest expression of her own emotion 2) 'When you are late.' No judging or name-calling, just a description of reality 3) 'It seems to say to me that my time is not really important to you.' Sharing how it looks from her point of view 4) 'Please try to be on time, or call and let me know when you'll be here.' Instead of focusing on the past (which nobody can change), she's telling him what she'd like him to do differently next time 5) 'Would you like me to do that to you?' This final option is drawing him out of his own little world and into hers. At the end of the day, there's always a whole load of ways to say what needs to be said and maturity is being aware of the options and choosing the right one at the right time. Question is, are you gonna try it? Who's your guinea pig going to be?

content.title: Battling selfishness
content.introtext:
Nobody should seek his own good, but the good of others.

1 Corinthians 10:24 NIV
Let's be honest, selfishness is a battle we fight daily. But it's a battle we've got to keep fighting. Left to get out of control selfishness will gradually dissolve your personality from the inside out. Thankfully the Bible is full of amazing examples to keep us focused: Paul and Silas were beat up and thrown in the cells but they still found the strength to minister to their jailer (Acts 16:32). When young Stephen was being stoned to death, he prayed for those who were killing him, 'do not hold this sin against them' (Acts 7:59-60). And of course the ultimate example, when Jesus was hanging on the cross in intense pain, He took time for a condemned criminal hanging next to Him (Luke 23:39-43). How tempting it must have been for all these heroes to just think about themselves; they had every excuse, but their acts of love brought the fragrance of heaven down to earth. When we begin to win the war against selfishness and walk in love, people will take notice; it's totally opposite to the way of the world. And let's remember, we'll never win the world by being like the world! So here's the question you need to answer: How many people might come to know Jesus if you could get your eyes off yourself and start paying attention to what they're going through? It's time to find out!

content.title: The secret - revealed
content.introtext:
Put yourself aside, and help others get ahead.

Philippians 2:4 TM
Do you want to know what God's plan for your life is, in one sentence? OK, here it is: God wants to make you a channel through which His blessings flow to others. That's it. Finito. What more do you need to know? Well, most people aren't satisfied with just knowing that. We're curious; we want to ask more questions, the most obvious one being: 'How?' God's cool with us asking those sort of questions because questioning is a great way to get to know Him better. King David asked those kinds of questions a lot, 'Show me your ways, O Lord...' (Psalm 24:4). When we ask God questions, He is less concerned with the question and more concerned with the attitude with which we ask it. When we read about the life of Jesus in the books of Matthew, Mark, Luke and John we see that He was always being asked questions, some easy, some hard. The way He responded very often depended on what was in the heart of the one doing the asking. Were they after a Word to help them get ahead or were they wanting to learn about how to truly live for God? So what's in your heart today? Are you ready for God to show you His ways; that always lead to others being blessed, or are you secretly hoping that you'll be able to keep the blessing for yourself?

content.title: Dragon's Den
content.introtext:
...each according to his ability.

Matthew 25:15 NIV
One of the stories Jesus tells is a bit like the TV programme Dragon's Den; it's all about investing in people who've got ideas about how to turn a little into a lot. In Jesus' story though there's only one dragon who decides to invest money in three different people. They weren't all given the same amount, they were given, 'each according to his ability.' As the story unfolds we are impacted by a scary truth: God only gives what you have the ability to handle. Why is that scary? Because it means if you don't make the most of what God gives you it's not like you can go back to Him making excuses like, 'Well, I got the jitters so I decided to do nothing.' That won't wash. It's tough but it is the truth at the heart of this story. The first guy doubled his. The second did the same. They both got big fat promotions as a reward. But the third caved in to fear and buried his cash in a hole. What did he get in return for that? He got his butt kicked that's what. Message? When you fail to use what God gives you, He's not impressed and you lose the rewards you would have enjoyed. Listen, fear of failure is not of God. That's why you need to ask Him for the gift of faith; today and every day.

content.title: Touching the power
content.introtext:
I want to know Christ...

Philippians 3:10 NIV
What's the most impressively powerful thing on the planet? A rocket blasting off into space? A nuclear reactor exploding atoms deep underground? Paul writes: 'I want to know Christ and the power of His resurrection, and the fellowship of His sufferings.' Resurrection Power. The power that raised Jesus from the dead. That's truly impressive. Who else can do that! Think: what problem or need do you face that resurrection power can't handle? What's dead in your life that needs to be raised? So how can you touch this power without just melting or exploding in the process? The answer is right there, 'That I may know Him.' When you make intimacy with Jesus your top priority, you tap into His power. But a lot of us would like to put a full stop after the words, 'The power of His resurrection.' If we do we're stuffed. If we're going to know Jesus intimately we must also know Him in 'the fellowship of His sufferings.' Depressed yet? Yep, 'sufferings' means more than just putting up with bad hay fever or having to share your room with your little sister. For Paul it meant being beaten to a pulp and locked in jail! But it all created a special kind of friendship with Jesus that's impossible any other way. Think about it, what kind of friend say, 'I only want to share the good times with you, keep your suffering to yourself.' Getting the idea?

content.title: God's got too much invested in you
content.introtext:
...we were...chosen...

Ephesians 1:11 NIV
One of the impossible mysteries of God is how He can know all about our life and how it will unfold even though He has blessed us with free will to make whatever choices we want. It's mind boggling! The Message version of the Bible puts it this way: 'He had his eye on us, had designs on us for glorious living, part of the overall purpose he is working out in everything and everyone.' Within that purpose God knows the things (and people!) you'll be attracted to and also the things (and people again!) that you'll want to run from! When Jonah tried to run from God and go to Tarshish, God loved him too much to let him escape his destiny so He sent a storm to wreck the boat and get Jonah back on track. Jonah was squeezed into a desperate place of prayer and then God answered him, by sending him off to his original destination. And God loves you too; much too much to let you escape His plans for you. God has too much invested in you to let you get away. If you have to leave behind a relationship, or an addiction, or a selfish dream, you'll come. Why? Because the echo of God's voice deep in your heart will never go silent. So, for your own good, make up your mind to follow Him today.

content.title: In the waiting room
content.introtext:
...look not only to your own interests, but also to the interests of others

Philippians 2:3-4 NIV
People will often say that relationships are more important to them than anything else, but their actions don't show it. How about you? Relationships are living things and like any living thing if you don't feed and protect them, they will die. While things are going well we can take the people close to us for granted, then a crisis comes along to remind us how valuable the people in our lives are. One author writes: 'The Intensive Care waiting room is different from any other place in the world. And the people who wait are different. They can't do enough for each other. No one is rude. The distinctions of race and class melt away. The garbage man loves his wife as much as the university professor loves his, and everyone understands this. Each person pulls for everyone else. In the Intensive Care waiting room the world changes. Vanity and pretence vanish. The universe is focused on the doctor's next report. If only it will show improvement. Everyone knows that loving someone else is what life is all about. Could we learn to love like that, if we realised that every day of life, is like a day in the Intensive Care waiting room?' The apostle Paul says, '...if I have a faith that can move mountains, but have not love, I am nothing' (1 Corinthians 13:2 NIV). He's absolutely right isn't he?!

content.title: Shiny Green Triangles
content.introtext:
All Scripture is... profitable...

2 Timothy 3:16 NKJV
It's the 7th of January. By now, all that's left of that massive tin of Quality Streets your Gran brought round for Christmas are about a dozen of those Toffee Pennies; the round ones in the gold wrappers. Who put them in there? They don't even have chocolate on! We all have our favourites; the shiny green triangles, the strawberry creams, those crunchy ones in the blue wrapper. But be careful; don't go treating the Bible like a tin of Quality Street. You can't just pick the bits you like and leave out all the rest. To grow in your faith you need to take in all the different tastes of God's Word because 'all Scripture is... profitable...' (2 Timothy 3:16 NKJV). To make a profit in business you have to know your business inside out, otherwise you'll soon be out of business. To get on in your Christian life, make it your business to know your Bible. There's nothing like just setting aside half an hour to get into your Bible. Without it you won't be able to hear what God is saying to you. You'll always have to depend on somebody else. Imagine dealing with your mates on that basis, never bothering to listen to a word they say? How long do you think your friendships would last? The same is true with God, so put down your W4U2D and open your Bible... now.

content.title: One Word
content.introtext:
Lord, if it's you...tell me...

Matthew 14:28 NIV
One of the most famous Jesus-stories is the one when He walked on the water to His disciples in the boat. Gobby Peter shouted out, 'Lord, if it's you...tell me...' (Matthew 14:28 NIV). Jesus gave him one word, 'Come,' and with that Peter hopped over the side of the boat and started walking! Was he scared? Wouldn't you be? Ice skating is hard enough but how the heck do you stand up when the water's still wet and wobbly! But Peter's desire was greater than his fear. And that's all you need to get started, a desire for God that's bigger than your doubts. There's another detail in this story we should note: The disciples didn't exactly back Peter up in his surfing-without-a-surfboard experiment! So bear in mind that when God gives you a Word and you step out in response to it, not everybody will cheer and shout out encouragements. It's normal for you to want people to see what you see and believe what you believe. But if you're not careful, people's opinions will short-circuit your faith and make you doubt what God has said. God says: 'I'm not going to confirm what I've told you through them. In fact, I don't even need them to agree with what I've spoken concerning you.' Relax. You may want your mates to back you up, but the truth is, Jesus is all you need!

content.title: Are you a 'grafter' (1)
content.introtext:
...receive...the engrafted word...

James 1:21 KJV
Have you ever turned on the telly and caught a few minutes of any of those gardening programmes? Yes, it is a bit baffling how people can get so excited about borders and rockeries. But if you're going to understand some of the things in the Bible you'll need to know a bit about gardening; Eden, home of the first people is a pretty big clue that God is into gardens. Today's verse is a gardening image. In some translations of the Bible the word 'planted' is used but the original word is actually 'grafted' or 'engrafted' which is when a gardener carefully slices a branch off one tree and then transplants it into a hole he's made in a branch of another tree. From then on the branch that's been relocated starts receiving all its water and life from the new tree. Now let's get creative, picture yourself reading your Bible, and as you do, those words from God are becoming attached to you, they start growing in you and producing fruit in your life. That's how God's Word works, and that's why you need to read it every day. As God's Word actually becomes part of who you are, you will find that it frees you from fear, lifts you when you're low, directs you the way to go, and gives you the strength to fight and win. So, how do you feel about gardening now?

content.title: When Jesus comes!
content.introtext:
During the fourth watch of the night Jesus went out to them.

Matthew 14:25 NIV
Night time is when God does some of His best work! It's mentioned in loads of Bible stories, like when the Israelites faced the Red Sea, '...all that night the LORD drove the sea back' (Exodus 14:21 NIV), also, during 'the middle watch' of the night, Gideon defeated the Midianites (Judges 7:19-24), and let's not forget, Jesus rose from the dead before 'daybreak' (Matthew 28:1). Matthew says: '...in the fourth watch of the night He came to them, walking on the sea. When the disciples saw Him ...they were terrified...immediately Jesus spoke..."Take courage, it is I; do not be afraid"' (Matthew 14:25-27 NAS). The 'fourth watch' mentioned here is from 3:00 a.m. 'til 6:00 a.m. Check these two things out: 1) Jesus waited until the storm was so bad that the disciples had lost all hope. That's because God decides the timetable for our rescue, and He's never late 2) the disciples didn't recognise Jesus until He shouted to them. Often the answer you need is right beside you, but you can't hear it because of all the other chaos you're paying attention to. So now we know this what should we do with it? The answer is simply this: to know that in life there are dark times, guaranteed, but that doesn't matter one bit to God, '...to you; the night will shine like the day...' (Psalm 139:12 NIV). He's always ready and able to save.

content.title: Rules or relationship?
content.introtext:
...I will put my laws in their hearts...

Hebrews 10:16 NIV
Take a survey in the street and you will not find anyone who likes being called a dog. Yes, you might find plenty of pooch lovers but they won't appreciate you saying they might be a bit canine themselves! One of the amazing things about dogs is that they can understand human language; but only in a very limited way: Sit! Fetch! Heel! So if we're so much smarter than Rover and Fido why do so many of us have that sort of Christian life? Following Jesus gets reduced to: 'Stop that; come back here; don't do that,' and don't forget the classics: 'Read your Bible; pray; go to church; pay your tithes; witness.' Now, this is all stuff we should be doing, but God never meant us to do them at the end of a lead! Let's listen to what the Bible says on the matter: 'But now, by dying to what once bound us, we have been released from the law so that we serve in the new way of the Spirit, and not in the old way of the written code. (Rom 7:6 NIV) and repeats this again elsewhere saying: '...I will put my laws in their hearts...' (Heb 10:16 NIV). The point is quite clear: living life as a Christian is about changing first on the inside, the heart, so that works its way outside in your behaviour. Trying to keep to an external system of rules is a dog's life!

content.title: The joy of giving
content.introtext:
Each of you must bring a gift in proportion to the way the LORD your God has blessed you.

Deuteronomy 16:17 (NIV)
The award-winning film Schindler's List, is the story of one man's efforts to bring hope in a desperate situation. As the boss of a factory in Germany, Oskar Schindler decides to use his position to save lives. By employing Jews from the concentration camp in his factory, Oskar rescues them from the gas chambers. But it's expensive, so he starts selling his personal possessions in order to keep the business afloat. At the end of the story the Nazis are defeated and the full impact of Oskar's effort is revealed as the dead are counted and the living stagger back to freedom. But kneeling by the railway tracks that carried thousands of Jews to their death, Oskar realises he could have saved more. Overwhelmed with regret, he thinks of the few goods still remaining in his possession; what else could he have sold to save a life? But it was too late. Yes, Schindler was a hero. But interestingly, all he could think about was what he didn't do. He wished he had done more. We learn a powerful lesson about giving from this man; if even generous givers look back on their lives and wish they'd done more what about those who never gave at all, or gave less than they could, what will say when they stand before God? OK, Christmas is over, but that doesn't mean the giving stops.

content.title: Peace
content.introtext:
When you enter a house, first say, "Peace to this house."

Luke 10:5 NIV
New Year's Eve has the reputation of being the maddest night of the year. Up and down the country and around the world, on New Years Eve people are going nuts; and often sadly ending up in a right state in the process. But have you ever been out and about on the morning of New Year's Day? (If you're reading this and it's still before 10 o'clock you might want to try it) It is deathly quiet. There's hardly anyone around. It's probably the most peaceful morning of the whole year. When Jesus sent out 72 of His followers to go and take the good news of salvation to the towns of Galilee He told them to find a 'person of peace' and stay at their house, saying 'Peace to this house'. But what did He mean? Did He just want the disciples to have a nice, quiet place to stay? Well, to understand what He meant we need a deeper understanding of the word 'peace'. In Hebrew it is 'shalom' which is a deep emotional word meaning 'Nothing missing, nothing broken'. It is about wholeness, completeness, wellbeing. That's what Jesus was all about; bringing God's shalom to a broken and hurting world. And just like He sent out the 72, He wants to send you too. Will you be one of His shalom-bringers this year?

content.title: New Year, New you!
content.introtext:
...I no longer live but Christ lives in me...

Galatians 2:20 NIV
It's your last chance to think up some New Year's resolutions! Have you ever wondered why we do that? Is it to impress friends? To try and be a better, nicer person? Because you think people expect you to? And do you ever actually manage to keep them all?!? How long do you think it'll be before you break any in 2009? Hebrews 12 urges us to keep striving, while Romans 3:23 reminds us that we're all going to slip up; so why bother?! Which one do we pay attention to? Our word for today, Galatians 2:20, goes on to say that God loves you and gave Himself for you. Think about that for a minute - it's a pretty huge thing! Verse 21 says that we can never get to a point of supreme goodness by effort. So that means no matter how many resolutions we keep, we'll never reach perfection. But that is why Jesus died for you - so that unreachable goal is brought right to us. So although resolutions aren't the be-all and end-all at New Year, if you remember how amazing it is that God gave Himself for us, and that we have Christ in us to help us, you might find it easier to do the right thing, for the right reasons, whatever your resolutions. And when you find it hard going, you know on whom you can call for help! [KMP1]Disappointed smilly!

content.title: In the fire
content.introtext:
Then the king promoted Shadrach, Meshach and Abednego...

Daniel 3:30 NIV
We can learn a few things from those guys in the fiery furnace: 1) Obeying God doesn't mean you'll never have trouble. Don't expect the world to always get you - sometimes, it'll be hard work for you 2) You're not alone, God is with you in your trouble. If you've ever seen the Veggietales 'Rack, Shack and Benny', you'll remember that when King Neb threw them in the fire, suddenly there were 'four men, and one was reeeaaal shiny!' (check out the whole story in Daniel 3:19 - 27). The fire didn't kill them, 'cos Jesus was there too. So be encouraged. It may feel like you're stuck in the flames, but God is with you - He'll bring you out of this victorious. 3) Your trouble will become your testimony. Your mates are watching. When what they're trusting in doesn't work, they'll look to see if what you're trusting in does. Your faithfulness to God and His to you, will challenge them in ways nothing else can. Everybody in Babylon knew what Rack, Shack and Benny believed, but they wanted to know if it worked when the heat was on (literally!). It did, and lives changed! 4) On the other side of your trouble, there's great blessing. Our word for today is a Scriptural principle: when you're faithful in a tough place, God can trust you in a high place.

content.title: No shortcuts - you've got to work for it!
content.introtext:
Lazy hands make a man poor, but diligent hands bring wealth.

Proverbs 10:4 NIV
Bill Gates, founder of Microsoft (and the world's richest man), was asked about his success, and offered some insights to anyone starting out. He makes a lot of sense! 1) Life isn't fair - get used to it 2) The world doesn't care about your self-esteem; it expects you to accomplish first, feel good second 3) You won't make £30K a year right out of school, or be a Company Director. You have to earn it 4) Do you think your teacher is tough? Wait till you have a boss - he's worse! 5) Flipping burgers isn't beneath you; it's opportunity 6) Some schools may have abolished winners and losers, but life hasn't. They may have eradicated 'failing grades' and given you as long as you want to get the right answer. This bears no resemblance to reality 7) Life isn't divided into terms. You don't get summers off. Employers aren't interested in helping you 'find yourself;' you do that on your own time 8) Be nice to nerds; chances are, you'll end up working for one someday! OK - it's not gospel but it's useful advice ;-) The writer of Proverbs sussed this a long time before Bill Gates did: 'Lazy people want much but get little, but those who work hard will prosper' (Proverbs 13:4 NIV). So don't try and take shortcuts in life - you've got to work for it!

content.title: Performing the impossible
content.introtext:
...that in the coming ages he might show...his grace, expressed...to us...

Ephesians 2:7 NIV
Whatever you're going through right now is important. God wants to use it to help shape your future. God doesn't measure us in terms of what we're doing now, or how we feel. No, He's got a much greater plan in mind. Read Romans 8:29. Thousands of years ago, God knew you; and one day, your character will be just like Jesus'. Doesn't that blow your mind? God is going to put us on display and say, 'Look at My workmanship. Can you believe that I made these awesome creatures from clay? When I first scooped them off the ground they wouldn't hold water. But I worked with them, moulded them and raised them up until they held relationships and jobs. What you heard about them was true. They were a disgrace and a disaster, but My grace was sufficient. Now they will sit with Me, ruling and reigning for ever!' People think that Houdini and David Blaine performed the impossible; but when it comes to that, they were amateurs. Could they have split an ocean down the middle, caused an eclipse for 24 hours, turned water into wine, resurrected the dead, and done it all with such style? Well, guess what? That same God is at work in your life, and He plans to show you off some day. Incredible as it may sound, when God gets through with you, you'll be 'something else.'

content.title: Fight Right
content.introtext:
If you bite and ravage each other, watch out-in no time at all you will be annihilating each other..

GALATIANS 5:15 NIV
You know what it's like; your 'so called friend' says something or does something, so 'bang out of order' that in an instant, you decide they are no longer your friend. Or your boyfriend/ girlfriend goes from being your soul mate to a 'so over mate' when they do or say something that makes you wonder what you ever saw in them in the first place! Aaggh! Well that's the way it's got to be right? You can't just let them humiliate you like that, you can't let them walk over you, you've got to stick up for yourself, and you don't care anyway, there's plenty more friends you can make, there's plenty other hunks / babes you can date...Right? Or is it? God knows how people let us down and hurt us, which makes us, want to lash out. But God says 'whoa hang on a minute! You keep lashing out at each other like that and it won't help you, it will destroy you!' We need to learn to fight right! Fight to make your relationships work - not end! Fight to do things God's way not your way! Jesus said, '"...I have come that they may have life, and have it to the full."' (John 10:10). So if you want to live your life to the Max, want to get the very best out of life, then fight right!

content.title: Happy Boxing Day!
content.introtext:
He will reply, "I tell you the truth, whatever you did not do for one of the least of these; you did not do for me.

Matthew 25: 45 NIV
No, it's not a day to celebrate the talents of Amir Khan or other incredible sportsman in the world of boxing! No it's not an excuse for you to belt your brother to bits or punch your sister's lights out! At one time, Boxing Day was a day to open 'Christmas boxes' and share the contents with the poor. These boxes were wooden or clay containers where people placed gifts throughout the year; you'd see them on ships, in churches or in factories. What's happened? What do we do today? - Hit the shops to find the latest bargains! Go watch the football! Overeat AGAIN in front of the TV! It's not about helping those in need. It's about getting what we want; take take, take, me, me, me! This isn't Jesus; idea of Boxing Day! In today's reading Jesus tells a story that lets us know that He wants us to help people; anyone and everyone who needs it! Life's not about 'What can I get for me?' but 'How can I help?' Listen '..."Lord, when did we see you hungry or thirsty or a stranger or needing clothes or sick or in prison, and did not help you?" He will reply, "I tell you the truth, whatever you did not do for one of the least of these, you did not do for me."' Ouch! Jesus says that not helping others means we do not love Him.

content.title: Christmas Day
content.introtext:
Today in the town of David a Saviour has been born to you; he is Christ the Lord.

Luke 2:11 NIV
Imagine today is your birthday, a very special significant birthday, like your 18th, and you wake up SO excited! You've been waiting for this day for what seems like forever and now at last it's here. You can hardly believe it! You have a smile on your face that stretches as wide as is possible. Today just feels like the best day ever and you can't wait to get up and celebrate. You have big plans, big hopes for this day. You race down stairs to receive great cards and presents from your family, before going out to receive even more from your friends. You're even looking forward to terrible renditions of Happy Birthday! But instead, the smile on your face begins to fade, as all your hopes for the day start to disappear. You see no-one is interested in you today, there's no cards, presents, singing; not even a text message...it's as if you don't exist! You want to scream at the top of your voice 'Hey it's me, it's my birthday, this day is special, celebrate with me!' But you know there's no point. No-one cares, no-one's listening, they're all doing their own thing! What a nightmare that would be! Today is a special day! It's the day set aside to remember that Jesus was born. He is your Saviour ...don't treat Him today like He doesn't exist.

content.title: W8
content.introtext:
Be still before the LORD and wait patiently for him

Psalm 37:7 ESV
Waiting! Not many of us enjoy waiting do we? Waiting for the bus to come, school to finish, or even for the microwave to warm up our leftover pizza. We don't want to wait do we? It's hard. When we want something we want it NOW!!!. 'Hurry up!' we shout at our friend who's late or the shop assistant who's serving. Just hurry up!! It's Christmas Eve and everyone's waiting for Christmas Day. Are you one of those people who can't wait to see their presents so has already found them and even opened a few? It can be hard to wait. But the Bible tells us to 'Be still before the LORD and wait patiently for Him'. Waiting for God patiently, not screaming at Him to hurry up but patiently waiting, being still; listening for God, not rushing ahead of Him. It can be hard to wait! When we want something to happen and nothing is changing, it can be so tempting for us to try and make that change ourselves. Recently a little girl died, because a cyclist couldn't wait for her to move out his way, he ploughed into her, knocking her to the floor, unconscious. Days later she was dead. It's important to wait. Sometimes it's a matter of life and death. Ask God, today, to give you the patience to wait when you need to. To do things in His time not yours.

content.title: What are you talking about? (2)
content.introtext:
He who guards his lips guards his life...

Proverbs 13:3 NIV
Paul Galvin's business had gone bust. He went to the auction of his own company, and with his last $750 he bought back the department which later became Motorola! He was 'down' but definitely not 'out!' 'When times are good, be happy; but when times are bad, consider: God has made the one as well as the other. Therefore, a man cannot discover anything about his future.' (Ecclesiastes 7:14 NIV) 'Good times' can be less helpful than 'tough times'; and the 'hard times' can be better for you than the 'easy times'. Whatever changes and challenges come your way; whether planned or unexpected, whether you feel like your going forward or sliding backwards - God is waiting for you to turn to him and know him. 'If any of you lacks wisdom, he should ask God, who gives generously...' (James 1:5 NIV) 'Ask and it will be given to you...' (Matthew 7:7 NIV). And there's more; God can make you a new creation (2 Corinthians 5:17), give you strength (Isaiah 40:31), guide and comfort you (Psalm 23). 'You will have to live with the consequences of everything you say'. Proverbs 18:20 reminds us that, for better or for worse, repeated actions create behaviours, behaviours create character and character creates a destiny. So make sure you are careful, with an attitude like the Israelites of Deuteronomy 11:18, and protect your life!

content.title: What are you talking about? (1)
content.introtext:
...he who invokes a blessing on himself...shall do so by saying, May the God of truth...bless me...

Isaiah 65:16 AMP
Words are powerful things. From 'God said' in creation, to God's Word being a sword in Ephesians 6:17. Words can change things big time. When Christiano Ronaldo was being pushed off the ball as a five year old, or when Leona Lewis was queuing up with thousands of hopefuls on X-Factor and told she'd have no chance, did they give up? No! Read Isaiah 65:15, and you'll see that: a) you must rise above what others might say to you (in words or actions) b) there is power in what you say to yourself. In a way, rising above what others say is the easier of those two points. Follow Ronaldo and Leona's example, and filter those put downs from others. And then get tough on what about what you're saying to yourself; don't ever run yourself down. Instead read the Bible out loud to yourself and pray God's promises into your life. Go on; start now! The more time you spend hanging out with God and reading His love-letter to you, the more it'll change how you see the people and situations around you, and even how you view yourself. Your mouth, your body and your brain are precious to God - so take care of them (check out 1 Corinthian 3:16 and Ephesians 4:29) and let God use them to take care of you.

content.title: Love yourself
content.introtext:
Love others as well as you love yourself.

Matthew 22:39 TM
Do you ever look around at everyone, and think they're so much better than you? Your mates have the looks of the cast of High School Musical, the charisma of Ant and Dec and the wit of Peter Kaye; whereas you feel like you have the looks of Shrek and the personality of a broom handle? Don't be so down on yourself! Not only are you being unfair to yourself, but with an attitude like that, you can't love others as God wants you to. You're the one person you can never get away from, so unless you learn to love and accept yourself, you'll probably end up miserable; which no-one wants. The devil loves any opportunities to 'prowl[] around...looking for someone to devour' (1 Peter 5:8 NIV), so don't give him that pleasure by sitting around moping. Stamp on his head and tell him to get lost, and start to think positively about yourself! Read about what God has to say about you (Isaiah 43:4 is a good place to start). When you can see good stuff in you, that's evidence that God is at work in you. Yes, the Bible cautions us about having an over inflated opinion of ourselves - but don't go to the other extreme! Check out 2 Corinthians 4:7. Recognise God's treasure in you, and the potential you have, and run with it. Go on; love yourself!

content.title: Get changed!
content.introtext:
...you have taken off your old self...and have put on the new self...

Colossians 3:9-10 NIV
Have you ever spent ages getting ready in the morning; slapping on that makeup, or spiking up your hair? Making sure you look the best you can, so you can impress that guy or girl that you fancy? I bet you wouldn't dream of letting them see you not looking your best; so why should it be any different with God? Don't settle for letting Him see you looking second best. Look in the mirror at the reflection of your heart and your mind and see what God sees. Ask yourself, are your attitudes and behaviours what you want God to be seeing? If not, then you need to think about changing them. How? By taking off the old, chucking it away, and putting on the new. Your focus each day must be to 'Clothe yourselves with the Lord Jesus Christ, and do not think about how to gratify the desires of the sinful nature' (Romans 13:14 NIV). It's your choice, and only you can make that change. He's not going to force you to. The devil aint gonna like you making that change, and he's gonna do what he can to stop you; so expect it to be tough, but stick with it. That's why you need to get on your knees and ask God to help you keep off those old 'clothes', and stick with the new.

content.title: Get into good habits
content.introtext:
Bring...(the whole tenth of your income)...

Malachi 3:10 AMP
Before you skip today's reading thinking it's not for you, just stop and think. Do you get pocket money or an allowance, ever get paid to babysit your little sister, do odd jobs around the house, or have a Saturday job? Yes? Then this IS for you. No? Read it anyway, 'cos one day soon it will be! 'Tithing' means giving God back some of your money. How's that fair, 'cos it's your money isn't it? Well, no, not really! Everything we have is ours thanks to God. He gives us everything we need. The Bible says we should give back at least 10%; which may seem a lot, but just remember, it was His to start with! We're also told to give the first 10%; that means before anything else, not after you've got that new top or DVD you've been wanting for ages! Giving God the first tenth of whatever 'income' you have shows Him that He's first in your life. God promises two things to those who tithe: His blessing and His protection. By tithing, you're partnering with God. He'll bless you back more than you could ever bless Him, and He'll protect you when the devil tries to attack you financially. So get into good habits now; it'll make it much easier to stick to in the future.

content.title: Life isn't a stage show
content.introtext:
Love the Lord your God with all your heart...

Deuteronomy 6:5 NIV
Sometimes it may seem that life is just one big stage show. You may act like one person at home, another at school and yet another at church, and you choose which personality and character traits you want people to see. Your life is like a chest of drawers, and each drawer has a costume and mask in that you put on for different occasions. You could rival Alistair McGowan, you have that many different personas! You probably do it without even thinking. But just stop and think now; which mask do you put on when you're with God? Because whatever it is, it's pretty pointless. God doesn't see us as a chest of drawers or a collection of separate performances, He sees us as a whole person. When no one is looking, He sees; when you're at school, He sees; when you're in church, He sees. God made us with one will, one mind, one heart, and one spirit. It's the devil's lie that we can 'have it both ways,' being who we want, when we want; but that just leaves us mentally and emotionally frazzled, and worse; distant from God! God wants us to be the same all the time; no masks, no costumes. How can we do that? By living with integrity, and striving to 'Love the Lord your God with all your heart and all your soul and all your strength'.

content.title: That's grace!
content.introtext:
...grace was given me...

Ephesians 3:8 NIV
If you were asked to describe yourself in two words, what would you choose? I'm guessing you probably wouldn't get what God would say about you; He says 'pure joy'. Maybe not the first two words that spring to mind! But that is what grace is all about. It means 'pure joy' - although you don't deserve it, God considers it a pure joy to save you. What do you make of that?!? This 'grace' stuff can be a bit hard to get your head around. In John 8, a woman is caught committing adultery. The law makes no bones about her punishment; the Pharisees are eager to stone her. Jesus, being righteous, surely must agree? Without a lawyer to defend her, or even a character witness, things aren't looking good. But suddenly Jesus starts to write in the sand. We're not told what, but some have suggested maybe a list of their sins, complete with times and places. Ouch! When He's done, her accusers are gone.
