With goodness and mercy embroidered on the heels of your K-Swiss, where can you go that you should be worried about? 2) Give credit due and you're excused from A-Level theology. The Apostle Paul is generally acknowledged as a qualified smarty pants, and even he says, 'How unsearchable are His judgments and His ways past finding out' (Romans 11:33 NKJV). Paul knew that God is Chief, some things are not worth stressing our brains over, we'll never work out why God says yes to some prayers and no to others, but we can trust He knows what He's doing. 3) Give credit due, it's all about Him, not you! Paul writes, 'From him and through him and to him are all things.' What a fancy way of saying: God is Chief! It's tempting to want to play god yourself, we all think we have our own lives sussed. We all get a bit stroppy with The Almighty from time to time, because he's not doing things our way. However, God sees the bigger picture through eternity's goggles, He's a bit more clued up than us, don't you think? Give credit due: God's chief.

content.title: Meet the man
content.introtext:
COME, SEE A MAN

JOHN 4:29 NIV
For some people, past experiences leave them terrified of getting emotionally close to people; hopping in and out of relationships and one night stands gives them a feeling of control where they might otherwise feel powerless. Jesus met a woman at a well with her own relationship issues; five husbands down and counting, a past full of hurts, and a history of regrets, and still no clearer about herself. Unlike all the other men she'd met, Jesus addressed her real need; 'Come...meet a man who told me everything!' (TLB). Her answer wasn't another man; she'd already tried that! Her answer was meeting the man, and asking Him to fill the void in her life. If you've got trust issues, it may take a lot of guts to put your trust in this man Jesus. But look at the story again, unlike all the other men this woman had met before, Jesus doesn't want or ask anything dodgy of her. He's not out to use, harm or manipulate her. If He was, with all the woman's background, she'd would've spotted it a mile off. Instead she recognises the Messiah. Come meet a man who is safe to get close to; come meet the Messiah.

content.title: Rock the boat
content.introtext:
THEIR NETS BEGAN TO BREAK

LUKE 5:6 NIV
You know when your mum just can't see it? In your head you're going to be the next Leona Lewis, and your Mum gives you that 'you've got to be joking' look, saying something like, 'that's nice dear, but what about something to fall back on, have you considered shelf-stacking?' She doesn't realise she's in the presence of a future megastar, does she? Well, it was definitely that way with Peter in Luke 5. Peter gave Jesus the 'You've got to be joking' glance, after fishing all night without so much as a minnow. See, Jesus had told Peter, 'Launch out into the deep, and let down your nets' (Luke 5:4). Peter, after explaining he'd have more luck in the Manchester Ship Canal (okay, maybe they weren't his exact words!), went along with it. Right up until this point Peter had no way of knowing if Jesus was just the latest wannabee prophet dude trying to sound important or if He was the real deal. He just hadn't cottoned on that he was in the presence of the real Living God. Then it happened; the biggest catch of his life and he knew! Life would never be the same again. Have you realised yet? 24/7 you're in the presence of the Living God. Or are you waiting for something to happen? If so, what's Jesus asking you to do? What will your response be?

content.title: Lessons from lepers
content.introtext:
YOUR FAITH HAS MADE YOU WELL.

LUKE 17:19 NIV
Crack your Bible open, today we're looking at lessons from lepers from Luke 17:12-19. Found it...? Read it...? Right then, did you notice these three things? 1) They kept their distance. 2000 years ago, everyone stayed well clear of lepers, so when God in flesh approaches, these poor outcasts keep their distance. Ring any bells with us? When people make us feel like outcasts, we might think God would reject us as well. NO SIR! The Bible says, 'When you draw close to God He will draw close to you' (James 4:8). Get in with the best, get in with God. 2) They went on their way. We read, 'As they went, they were cleansed.' Sometimes change is speedy, but mostly it's slow. Step-by-step, the lepers walked, step by step the lepers changed. If you've been praying for a change in yourself, don't beat yourself up just because you're not where you'd like to be yet, keep on with it, you're changing step by step. 3) They were mostly brats! Ten miracles, one set of thanks. Spoilt brat alert! This story reminds us how quickly we forget God's goodness. When God gives you your heart's desire, remember your thanks. One leper did and he became whole. Let your praise and thanks form a great big heavenly kiss on your creator; He SOOOOO deserves it!

content.title: Abba arms
content.introtext:
UNDERNEATH ARE THE EVERLASTING ARMS.

DEUTERONOMY 33:27 NIV
Some people wonder why God would be described as 'Father' at all. In a messed up world of absent fathers and crummy dad role models, surely it's a bad marketing mistake. Surely the last thing God would want to be compared to is a 'Father'. Jesus didn't just call God, 'Father'; he went a step further, describing Him as 'Abba'. No, he wasn't comparing God to a dodgy Swedish Eurovision pop combo; He was tuned into his Dad. The Aramaic word, 'abba', is a bit like when a toddler says, 'Daddy' or 'Dada' today. So, why was a grown man like Jesus baby-babbling to God? Well, perhaps if your take on dads is not a good one, maybe, the best way of looking at it is to think what would the best dad in the world be like? He'd love you no matter what, he'd want to bear-hug you tight, he'd have nothing but the best for you, he'd feel your hurt more than you feel it, he'd provide and protect you, he'd wipe away your tears, he'd get the family pics out showing everyone how proud he is of you, he'd pull out all the stops to make sure you know he loves you. God's all that and more. That's why Jesus called him, 'abba' or 'dada'. That's why you're safe in your dada's everlasting arms.

content.title: Breaking the rules
content.introtext:
STREAMS OF LIVING WATER WILL FLOW FROM WITHIN

JOHN 7:38
A little boy asked his mum if he could sleep over at his friend's house. 'Why?' she asked. 'Just for fun,' he replied. 'But you slept over there last night,' she said. He thought for a minute then asked, 'Who says you can't have fun two nights in a row?' He's got a good point hasn't he! As your life progresses you might find yourself starting to question some of the boundaries that have been created around you. The challenge is going to be working out which of the rules you are expected to follow really are for your ultimate benefit and which are just temporary guidelines that can be removed as you get more mature - a bit like stabilisers on a bike! The problem is, you won't always be in the best position to tell the difference. That's why it's great to be a follower of Jesus. You don't have to read many pages of the gospels (Matthew, Mark, Luke and John) to see that Jesus really didn't like rules very much. He lived in a world where people were weighed down and boxed in by all kinds of stupid laws. But Jesus didn't teach anyone to just stuff the rules and do whatever they wanted; He taught about living life by higher laws. Religious rules pressurise from the outside-in; His spirit-rhythms flow from the inside-out. Make sure you're in the flow today!

content.title: The scariest word
content.introtext:
GOD WILL...TREAT YOU EXACTLY AS YOU TREAT THEM.

MATTHEW 7:1 CEV
If you had to make a list of the scariest words in the world what would be on it? Chances are this word would be pretty high on the list; Rejection. That's something about being human that means we have a deep need to be accepted and appreciated. There are two ways to deal with this scary word. The first way is to change for the worse and start doing all sorts of things that you don't really feel comfortable doing just coz you think that's the way you've got to be to 'fit in' and not get the cold shoulder. The second way is to change for the better and start looking for ways that you can let other people, people who maybe spend most of their time feeling like outsiders, know that they actually are amazing creations who God has a plan and purpose for. Solomon said, 'It's wonderful to say the right thing at the right time' (Proverbs 15:23 NLT). Have you any idea how many of the people you know never hear a word of appreciation? People aren't mind-readers; when you see something good in someone, tell them. Don't wait for a sign from Heaven first! Think about practical ways you can help people feel accepted and appreciated. Paul said, 'Whenever we have the opportunity we should do good to all' (Galatians 6:10 NLT). God's blessed you to be a blessing, so don't hold back today.

content.title: Stop flamin' blamin'
content.introtext:
CHOOSE FOR YOURSELVES

JOSHUA 24:15 NIV
Our lives are like icebergs. Only 15% is visible; that's your rep'. The rest, your character, is hidden deep below the waterline. Character means acting the same, no matter who's watching. It's how we react to everyday agro and hassle. It's how we handle failure and success. It's making the right choices, in the small things and the big things. Israel's famous leader Joshua challenged them: 'Choose for yourselves this day whom you will serve...But as for me and my household, we will serve the Lord.' So today, the choice is yours! Ever notice that some people always blame other people, or their circumstances when something goes wrong? That's a sure sign that they've got a lot of learning to do in the character department. And what do you do if that's you - if 'blame' is your middle name?! Well for a start, stop flamin' blamin'! You can no more blame your lack of character on your circumstances than you can blame the mirror for your lack of good looks! Choose to change. Every time you make a good decision you take another step forward. Take a minute now and jot down the times when you've faced a temptation recently. Next to each, note your choice. What problem areas do you see? Write down what choice you will make next time and pray that God will help you see it through.

content.title: Healing for wounded relationships (5)
content.introtext:
HE HAS SENT ME TO BIND UP THE BROKENHEARTED.

ISAIAH 61:1 NAS
Right, we're going to spend one more day on relationships. Have you ever thought that your relationships are a bit like having a bank account? Bank accounts are great, as long as you've got money in the account! When you overspend your account goes into 'overdraft'; not good news. Before you know it nasty letters are coming through the letterbox telling you that unless you put things right they will charge you more and more. Oh, and they usually let you know that they will charge you 25 quid just for sending you the letter. Cheek! When you abuse someone's trust, you send your 'relationship account' into overdraft! There are only two things you can do: 1) Stop making withdrawals! Don't go expecting loads of favours like you normally do. This is time to practice the Jesus way, aka denying yourself (see Mark 8:34) For now, lean on God and start re-learning how to live life without that individual constantly being there to meet your needs. 2) Start making deposits! Make them small and often. Your gift will return to you...pressed down, shaken together...running over' (Luke 6:38 TLB). Quietly find ways to make life easier for the person you've hurt: use kind words and thoughtful actions. These are the things that help defrost the atmosphere and make it possible to start getting along again.

content.title: Healing for wounded relationships (4)
content.introtext:
I THANK MY GOD EVERY TIME I REMEMBER YOU

PHILIPPIANS 1:3 NIV
Every minute of every day, somewhere in the world someone is taking their car to the mechanic. A lot of the time, what happens when the mechanic looks at the problem is that a whole bunch of other problems get spotted too! In the same way, a relationship breakdown can bring into focus all sorts of personal issues too, like how well we do or don't communicate, or how we cope or don't with intimacy issues. If you want a healthy relationships then sooner or later you'll have to allow God to get His hands on areas of your own life that aren't the way He designed them to be. If you try to keep on driving your life forward without ever spending time being tweaked and tuned by the Holy Spirit don't be surprised when you break down. While we're on this sort of holy 'Top Gear' theme think about this too: every car needs oil to keep its engine running smoothly. So what's the 'oil' of relationships? Appreciation. Saying thanks, and meaning it. Do the people close to you know that you're thankful for the things they do for you? If you haven't shown your appreciation recently then it won't be long before that relationship starts overheating! Paul told his friends 'I thank my God every time I remember you', why not do the same today?

content.title: Healing for wounded relationships (3)
content.introtext:
WHEN I SEE HIM, PERHAPS HE WILL ACCEPT ME...

GENESIS 32:20 NLT
Life doesn't come with a lifetime pain-free guarantee; and when pain comes, especially relational pain, getting life back on track involves a degree of effort and risk. If I care about you, but do something that hurts you, then I have to hope that ultimately you'll forgive me and put it behind you. To make this possible you'd have to believe that I'm truly sorry and won't do it again. This explains why healing a wounded relationship is a two-person job. Your job is to work at trusting me again and my job is to prove that I'm trustworthy. When we start rebuilding that broken bridge of trust we shorten the distance that separates us until we can be re-united. A classic example of this is found in the story of the brothers Jacob and Esau, in Genesis 32. Jacob had ripped off his brother, then run away. Years passed until eventually Jacob knew he had to put things right. It's fair to say that Jacob was bricking it, not knowing whether his brother would hug him or hang him! Before he actually meets his brother face to face he sends him all sorts of gifts as a way of saying sorry, to make a good impression and to show he's changed. To Jacob's relief his brother isn't bitter about the past; he's dealt with it in his heart. Should you do some bridge-building today?

content.title: Healing for wounded relationships (2)
content.introtext:
I HAVE HEARD YOUR PRAYER AND SEEN YOUR TEARS; I WILL HEAL YOU.

2 KINGS 20:5 NIV
Lots of animals when they're hurt and bleeding will lick their wounds. In a funny kind of way we can do the same. We get all introverted and focus over and over again one the pain we feel. Well it might work for dogs and cats but not for you and me! Healing involves three things that you can't do on your own: 1) Talking. Find a trustworthy person and get the pain out in words. It will help you get over the anger and the blame and the confusion 2) Sharing. A problem shared is a problem halved, right? When nobody knows how you feel the hurt is made worse by loneliness and isolation. Don't let that happen 3) Acceptance. If the person who hurt you apologises and asks for forgiveness don't reject it - accept it! Yes, maybe you do want them to feel as bad as you do but that just brings twice as much hurt into a world that's got too much already. Many years ago a broken King cried out to God from the bottom of his heart. God replied graciously saying, 'I have heard your prayers and seen your tears; I will heal you,' That's a word for you too today, if you dare to believe that the God who healed back then is still in the healing business today. Do you?

content.title: Healing for wounded relationships (1)
content.introtext:
HE HEALS THE BROKENHEARTED AND BINDS UP THEIR WOUNDS.

PSALM 147:3 NIV
It happens to people every day. Maybe it's happening to you right now? Not much hurts like broken promises and shattered trust. But you know, God is the Healer and that extends to relationships. Here's three things about how that healing works: 1) Healing of the heart is a process, not an event. Give it time. All the apologies in the world (and apologies are good; when they're for real) can't heal anyone overnight. Nobody can set up a schedule for emotional healing; 'OK, by next Thursday at 2 o'clock everything will be sorted.' Nope. In fact trying to rush it will only make it worse. 2) Not normal is normal, for now! Ever notice how if part of your body is bruised or sore you automatically protect it from more knocks and bumps? Right. It's the same when you're bruised deep inside. Oh yeah, the one who caused the pain may be doing business as usual but for the wounded, life feels way too vulnerable right now. A hurting person needs handling with extra care - like they have a label on saying 'FRAGILE - Handle With Care'. 3) Remember, healing will come, in time. God said, 'There is a time to cry and a time to laugh. There is a time to be sad and a time to dance. (Ecclesiastes 3:4 NCV). So if it's you that's hurting, or someone you love, trust that God is the Healer.

content.title: Cheerful giving or fearful giving?
content.introtext:
GOD LOVES A CHEERFUL GIVER.

2 CORINTHIANS 9:7 NIV
OK, let's start with a chunky chunk of Bible today: 'The person who plants a little will have a small harvest, but the person who plants a lot will have a big harvest. Each of you should give as you have decided in your heart to give. You should not be sad when you give, and you should not give because you feel forced to give. God loves the person who gives happily... God can give you more blessings than you need. Then you will always have plenty of everything - enough to give to every good work' (2 Corinthians 9:6-8 NCV). Are you a cheerful giver or a fearful giver? You're probably not a greedy person. You might really want to help God's work. But do you usually look after yourself first? Why not? Most people do! Well imagine a farmer, who, for fear of getting hungry, eats his seed for breakfast and leaves nothing to plant in his fields. It's daft, right?! So don't scoff the seed that God wants to be sown for your future harvest. When you make giving your first priority, you don't have to fear. Jesus said, 'Put God's work first and do what he wants. Then the other things will be yours as well' (Matthew 6:33 CEV). When you get a God's-eye view on your cash the thing to fear isn't giving away too much, it's planting too little!

content.title: Billy
content.introtext:
GOD CHOSE THINGS THE WORLD CONSIDERS FOOLISH.

1 CORINTHIANS 1:27 NLT
Remembering his time working at a summer camp, Tony Campolo says, 'Teenage boys have a tendency to pick on some unfortunate kid. That summer it was 13-year-old Billy, a kid who couldn't walk or talk right. When the kids from his cabin were assigned to lead devotions, they voted Billy in as the speaker. It didn't seem to bother him. He dragged himself up to the pulpit amid sneers and snickers and it took him a long time to stammer, "Je-sus loves...me... and...I...love Je-sus." There was stunned silence, and when I looked around there were boys with tears streaming down their cheeks. We'd done many things to try to reach these boys but nothing had worked. It wasn't until a special needs kid declared his love for Christ that everything changed. I travel a lot and it's surprising how often I meet people who say, "You probably don't remember me. I became a Christian at a camp where you worked and do you know what the turning point was for me?" I never have to ask. I always know I'm going to hear, "Billy!"' The Bible says, 'God chose things the world considers foolish in order to shame those who think they are wise.' So when you find yourself focusing on what you can't do, remember that, do what you can and let God do the rest!

content.title: Smells and shadows
content.introtext:
IN THE SHADOW OF HIS HAND HE HID ME.

ISAIAH 49:2 NIV
After visiting the Balkan region of South-eastern Europe, reporter James Creelman wrote, 'I learned that the world's supply of rose oil comes from the Balkan Mountains. The thing that interested me was that the roses had to be gathered during the darkest hours. Initially this seemed to be a relic of superstition. But as I investigated I learned that 40% of the fragrance disappears in the light of day.' Do you want to make a difference in the world? Well, God wants your life to be really smelly (check out 2 Corinthians 2:14-16) and you'll need to let God work with you in the shadows before you come into the spotlight. Before the prophet Elijah called down fire from heaven in front of the evil pagan priests on Mount Carmel, God told him to go and hide himself at a brook known as Cherith (1 Kings 17). The country was in a mess and people were dying but Elijah needed to sit tight in this craggy Nowhereville until God said the time was right for him to go and confront the King. Stories like this make us think differently about being in the shadow, don't they? Like Elijah you need to learn to embrace the shadows, enjoy the sidelines, to discover God and grow in them, then stride out confidently with something to say that's worth listening to!

content.title: The Voice
content.introtext:
GOD WILL COMMAND HIS ANGELS TO PROTECT YOU WHEREVER YOU GO

PSALM 91:11 CEV
When Steve Anderson's mother-in-law developed cancer, his wife flew out to see her. Steve really wanted to go too, but they couldn't afford two tickets. Steve prayed and amazingly a local businessman called Joe offered him a seat in a two-seater airplane. On the journey they encountered thick fog and needed to get in contact with the air-traffic controller who recommended they turn back. But fuel was low, so Steve prayed again. A voice came back through the radio, 'Come in on emergency landing.' Then as they descended the radio voiced screamed, 'Pull it up! Pull it up!"' Through a break in the fog they saw that instead of approaching the airport they were over a busy highway and had narrowly missed an overpass! The voice continued, 'Listen to me and I'll get you down,' and calmly issued instructions until they landed. Safely on the ground Joe picked up the radio and told the tower, 'We'd never have made it without you. Thanks, you saved our lives.' The controller replied, 'What're you talking about? We lost contact with you right after we told you to turn back!' So, if the controller didn't guide them in, who did? The Psalmist wrote, 'God will command his angels to protect you wherever you go' (Psalm 91:11 CEV). Steve Anderson says, 'I believe God sent an angel to bring us in safely.' And He'll do the same for you!

content.title: Another chance
content.introtext:
WHERE CAN I RUN FROM YOU.

PSALM 139:5 NCV
A story is told of a London bus driver was had to drive people to the massive mission events at Wembley Stadium where evangelist Billy Graham would be preaching. When one of them invited him in to listen he said 'No thanks'. The following year he moved to New York and guess what, Billy was preaching at Madison Square Garden this time and the bus driver was once again doing the shuttle run. As he helped people off the bus, a lady asked if he'd like to join them. Once more he politely declined. Later, the bus driver married an Australian lady and eventually ended up working in Sydney where, once again he was assigned to drive people to a stadium where Billy was preaching. This time when he was invited he figured there was no escape, so he gave in. Looking back he says, 'No matter where I went I was confronted with Billy Graham, so I went to hear him and committed my life to Christ. It was the best decision I ever made.' David's great Psalm says, 'Where can I go to get away from your Spirit? Where can I run from you?' (Psalm 139:7 NCV). Isn't God amazing? He'll follow you round the world to give you another chance to find your life in Him. How many chances has He already given you? Say yes to him today.

content.title: Bulldogs and poodles
content.introtext:
DRAW NEAR TO GOD AND HE WILL DRAW NEAR TO YOU.

JAMES 4:8 NKJV
A bulldog and a poodle were arguing one day. The bulldog was making fun of the poodle, calling her a weak little runt who couldn't do anything. The bulldog said, 'I challenge you to a contest. Let's see who can open the back door of their house the fastest and get inside.' The bulldog was thinking he would turn the door handle with his powerful jaws, while the poodle was too small to even reach the handle of his back door. To the bulldog's surprise the poodle said, 'OK, I accept the challenge.' 1,2,3... GO! The bulldog ran to the back door of his house and jumped up to the handle. He got his teeth and paws around it and tried to turn it but he couldn't get enough grip. Finally he quit in frustration. Meanwhile the poodle had just been watching. Then she did what she'd been doing every day of her life. She went up to the door and scratched on it a couple of times, then waited. Within a few seconds her master opened the door and picked her up in his arms, cuddled her and carried her inside. The difference was in the relationship. Some of us are bulldog Christians. It's all grunting, growling and trying to be the first. Give it up! All God asks us to do is, 'Draw near to Me and I will draw near to you.'

content.title: Showing love
content.introtext:
SHE HAS SHOWN ME MUCH LOVE.

LUKE 7:47 NLT
Jesus was never shocked. In fact, people found Him shocking; even scandalous. Luke writes, 'One of the Pharisees asked Jesus to have dinner with him, so Jesus went to his home...a certain immoral woman...heard he was...there [and]...brought a beautiful alabaster jar filled with expensive perfume. Then she knelt...at his feet, weeping... kissing his feet and putting perfume on them' (Luke 7:36-38 NLT). Some people, who have been hurt by religion can't stand being in the same room as religious people. Some people are so religious they don't know how to relate to people still lost in their sins. Jesus was neither. He accepted the invitation to eat with the religious guy, the Pharisee. At the same time though He gave grace to the sinner. Can you do the same? Jesus said, 'Her sins; and they are many; have been forgiven, so she has shown me much love. But a person who is forgiven little shows only little love.' Clock these 3 points: 1) Keeping in mind what Jesus saved you from will keep you passionate in your love and your giving 2) Other people may know what you've done but Jesus knows what you can become 3) Don't be afraid of showing your emotions. That's not just a personality thing, we all know some people are more emotional than others. No, this is about not letting anything stop you showing Jesus know how much you love Him. Show Him today.

content.title: Flying in formation!
content.introtext:
LET US NOT GIVE UP MEETING TOGETHER.

HEBREWS 10:25 NIV
Geese. They flap around with their long bandy necks, honking (ie making a loud noise; not a smell!) What could we ever learn from a goose? Well chew on this: Every autumn geese fly south to where the climate is warmer. But they don't just set off in a random flappage of feathers, they fly together in a 'V' formation. Geese know that to complete the long trip, they have to fly united. Air waves created each time a bird flaps its wings provide uplift for the one behind, conserving its energy and enabling it to double its flying range. A goose flying solo could never complete the trip but in formation the youngest, the oldest and even the weakest get there. In other words, they do as a team what they could never do alone. When the Bible says, 'Let us not give up meeting together... but let us encourage one another,' it's saying, 'Stay in formation! Enjoy the uplift!' Christians aren't meant to fly solo, whatever their calling, gifting or maturity. We're all part of Team Jesus, created to fly as a unit with other believers. Sometimes a goose will go off alone and find itself adrift. Before long though its wings become heavy from exhaustion and it loses altitude. There's only one thing it can do; get back with the group. How about you? Are you flying in formation today?

content.title: Keep practicing (2)
content.introtext:
In a race all the runners run, but only one gets the prize ...Run...as to get the prize

1 Corinthians 9:24 NIV
Every single footballer, athlete, basketball player and swimmer has to warm up to get started!! It's a natural thing. Your muscles, blood and heart need a gentle push to get em' going. A bit like life hey? You can warm up daily by practising what's important to you. It's during these warm ups that you prepare to face life's challenges. If you commit yaself to practice you will find that: 1) Life can always be improved: A famous write once said: 'understand that almost anything that has been done in a particular way for a given amount if time, can be done better.' Every single performance can be improved!! 2) Getting better at what you do is risky: Even getting out of bed has some sort of risk attached...so find a safe place to grow and test what is right and wrong for you!! 3) Start with the small things: When you 1st start to improve you'll get better slowly but you will get better. Remember the difference between a Gold 100m winner and a silver is hundredths of a second but there is still room to get better...slowly!! 4) There's a price to pay to reach the next level: You heard the saying "practice makes perfect"...well its true!! The more you practise, rehearse and go over and over til its right, the better you will be. So keep practising!!

content.title: Keep practicing (1)
content.introtext:
Be diligent in these matters; give yourself wholly to them.

1 Timothy 4:15 NIV
Have you got any amazing tracks on you mp3 player? Do you listen to them and think 'oh my days that band is amazing'! Well they probably didn't start out that way. In the bible it says that when David played his harp for his King Saul that, "relief would come to Saul" It hints at 2 things - the power of praise and the power of practice. David didn't suddenly wake up one morning and realise 'Oh my gosh, I am great on the Harp!' He had to practice when he was chiilin' on the hills with the sheep. When it comes to practice there are 2 tough things we face. 1). Having the desire to do it! 2) Having the desire to stick at it! Paul tells Timothy "...don't be diverted, just keep at it"... (1 Timothy 4:15 The Message) There's no way to get better at anything without being disciplined and sticking with it. It's more than talent, it's choice! And once the choice is it becomes a habit. Then two things will become obvious: 1) There'll be a clear difference between the one who practices and the one who slacks off. 2) You'll form a winning spirit. The harder the work gets, the less you'll want to give in. Lance Armstrong won the Tour de France 7 times and said "success comes from training harder and digging deeper than others".

content.title: Great expectations
content.introtext:
This day the Lord will hand you over to me, and I'll strike you down.

1 Samuel 17:46 NIV
"Its not the size of the Dog in the fight, it's the size of the fight in the Dog". When David knocked out Goliath he didn't have a special laser gun, but he had the winners attitude! It says in the bible he "ran quickly toward the battle line to meet Goliath" (1 Samuel 17:48 NIV). King Saul was hiding but David was having none of it and ran to meet the challenge! David had amazing faith, not in himself but in "him who is able to do immeasurably more than all we ask, dream or imagine, according to his power that is at work in us" (Ephesians 3:20 NIV). A boffin called Martin Seligman, a professor, did some research on a sales company and found that staff with a positive sales attitude sold twice as much as those who didn't... they're running to meet the challenge!! Boffins have also found that if you're self confident then you'll generally achieve more stuff than if you're intelligent. You see the only thing that stops us achieving great stuff is our lack of believing in ourselves!! The more we believe in ourselves the more we get done. If you keep believing you may even end up doing what you first thought was impossible!! "With God all things are possible" (Matthew 19:26) Remember, great results start with great expectations!!

content.title: Do you want to change?
content.introtext:
Let God transform you.

Romans 12:2 GNT
Change only happens when you: 1) Decide to change! A newspaper asked people to answer the question: 'What's wrong with the world' and someone wrote back "I am"!! Good answer! It's true. If God kicked every person in the butt who was responsible for messing up the world nobody would be able to sit down for a week!! 2) Change the way you think! The Bible says "let God transform you into a new person by changing the way you think" (Romans 12:2 NLT) The way you think affects the way you feel and the way you feel affects the way you act. When you're thinking God thoughts you'll act the way he wants you to. Here's a tip - get into the bible...that's the best way to change your thinking! 3) Take a small step everyday! We think change is gonna happen overnight... it won't! It happens slowly. For change to work start with small things but do them everyday. And don't get discouraged when you mess up. We all stumble about like Bambi when we're trying to change. Read this, "there has never been a doubt in my mind that God who started this great work in you (change) would keep at it and bring to a flourishing (fancy word) finish on the very day Jesus appears" (Philippians 1:6 The Message). And don't forget, God is there to help you.

content.title: Equipping people to serve
content.introtext:
He...gave gifts...to equip God's people...and build up...the church.

Ephesians 4:8-12 NLT
Different people have different gifts or talents, your gift or talent will be totally different from your mates. You gifts and talents are given to you ultimately to serve God with. In Ephesians 4 (The Message) it talks about different gifts by saying..."he handed out gifts from above and below, filled heaven with his gifts, filled earth with his gifts. He handed out gifts of an apostle, prophet, evangelist and pastor-teacher to train Christians in skilled servant work...till we are moving rhythmically and easily with each other". So all of us have a unique set of talents to help us all get along. What we have to figure out is...what's my gift? Until that question is answered you can feel a bit out of place, a bit like a striker playing in defence. You can get by - but never be truly excellent. Some people are called to be leaders....that may be you? If it is then you're gifted in helping people succeed. Why do people need to be helped like this? So they can serve God better. Why is serving God so important? To help the church be stronger to impact the world more positively. That's why it's so important to get what your gift is. You'll enjoy your life so much more once you figure out "What's my gift"? Make sure you pray about it today.

content.title: Great relationships
content.introtext:
Friends come and friends go but a true friend sticks by you like family,

Proverbs 18:24
You've heard the saying "you know who you mates are" It's used when a friendship is being tested right! Having a good mate in you life is a bit like riding a bus... you have to move over and let them sit with you for the journey, including all the baggage that comes with them. When you let them do that you're saying "you matter to me". The 2 things we look for in mates are 1) they won't bail out when the going gets tough. 2) whatever stupid stuff you do won't change them being mates and standing by you. Solomon was an important dude in the Bible and he wrote "friends come and friends go but a true friend sticks by you like family" Having one quality mate is better than having loads of not so good mates! Don't be too quick to write someone off coz they made a mistake or messed up with you. If your bike had a flat you wouldn't dump it just for that would you? Nah, you'd fix it. In a similar way, work on fixing your friendships. Yeah they're gonna be up and down but your quality mates can be relied on in the tough times, when you need a lift or feeling down they are there to pick you up. Life ain't built on what you get, its built on friendships, so keep working at yours today.

content.title: Growing in grace (2)
content.introtext:
Let us not judge.

Romans 14:13 NKJV
A word that never fits very well with grace is control. People that control are often caught in being too religious and are not very up on the grace thang coz they think they know it all!! Ring any bells with you? How much happier would you be if you didn't try to control stuff, people, situations and all that? A guy called Dennis Leonard wrote 'Give your loved ones the dignity of making their own mistakes and learning from them. If you're always getting into someone else's business, you're not only going to burn out, you're hindering God from working in their lives...They belong to Him not you!' In the Bible there were proper arguments about what you could and couldn't eat and Paul had loads to say about it, "Those who feel free to eat anything must not look down on those who don't. And those who don't eat certain foods must not condemn those who do, for God has accepted them. (Rom 14: 3 NLT). You may not feel its right to do something but you can't push what you feel on other people, just coz you feel that way! Is what you want to say gonna be helpful or just get their back up? The bible says "let's agree to use all our energy in getting along with each other. Help others with encouraging words' (Rom 14:19 TM) That's top advice...try it out!

content.title: Growing in grace (1)
content.introtext:
We do not...compare ourselves.

2 Corinthians 10:12 NIV
It is so easy to compare ourselves to our mates and people around us. If someone has the latest games console, the freshest kicks, a new ride and the best threads we compare ourselves against them don't we? Life becomes all about "how do we match up" or even "how much better or more stuff have we got than them". The Bible says that we shouldn't compare ourselves, each of us is a total individual, a one off. Comparing only leads us to compete and criticise and "want what they've got". It shows that a person is insecure and that there's not much grace about. Grace allows you to let people be themselves without comparing. The Apostle Paul says "who are we to judge". He learnt that judging is God's job to do - not ours! A famous writer called Gladys Hunt wrote: 'Acceptance means you're valuable just as you are...You aren't forced into someone else's idea...You can talk about how you feel...and why...and someone really cares...you can try out ideas without being shot down... You feel safe. No one will judge you ...even though they don't agree with you. It doesn't mean you'll never be corrected...it simply means it's safe to be you.' Grace is all over it what she wrote!! Wouldn't you love to be like that? You will be if you make a choice to grow in grace!!

content.title: Walking by faith
content.introtext:
We walk by faith, not by sight.

2 Corinthians 5:7
3 dudes in the Bible were thrown into a fire for not worshipping who they were told to... A bit harsh! Shadrach, Meshach and Abednego were literally dumped from the frying pan into the fire...did they have a hope? They did with God coz God is 'the MAN' when it comes to the impossible! Just think how impressive God is... look at the stars... the creation that has gone into that blows your mind! God saved the three young dudes from the flames coz they believed and had faith in God. Even the King himself admitted 'Blessed be...God... who...delivered His servants who...trust in Him...there is no other god who is able to deliver in this way' (Daniel 3:28 - 29). In the Bible God says "stick all your worries on me, coz I care for you"...everything we go through, God is there. Praying about your situation will change it if you have the faith to believe that God is interested and he will answer. When you look back you will see that you couldn't have come up with a better answer anyway. So try it today, take an Indiana Jones style 'step of faith'. Do you remember that scene in the film? What happened? The path suddenly appeared beneath him. So will you step out today and "walk by faith, not by sight"? Make a decision now that you'll go for it.

content.title: Are you searching for contentment?
content.introtext:
My people have...forsaken...the...living water, and...dug ...broken cisterns.

Jeremiah 2:13 NIV
It's easy to feel good about life when it's all going to plan... but we all know that don't always happen, right? The Bible talks about "being happy at anytime in everything'...coz basically if you wait about for your life to happen the way you want it to, you will be hangin' about for ages! A clever geezer once said: "don't mess up what you have by wanting what you don't have". So remember these 3 things: 1). Enjoy what God's already given you...try not to be greedy...be satisfied where you're at...its good to have goals and dreams but learn to enjoy the journey on the way to those dreams!! 2). Don't be scared!! Fear wants you to run from something that's not actually chasing you...being scared can steal your peace...will have you thinking "what if" and will stop you trusting in God...Psalm 56:4 says "in God I trust, I will not be scared"....when you really get that in your heart you can fully chill with God. 3) Don't look in the wrong places!! That verse at the top is basically saying that God's people were seriously on the wrong track...going the wrong way...relying on the wrong things...if we rely on ourselves we are doing just the same as them and will end up on the wrong track. Let's take up a dare today and rely on Jesus!!

content.title: Getting personal
content.introtext:
But grow in the grace and knowledge of our Lord.

2 Peter 3:18 NIV
Dale Evans was married to a famous Hollywood film star. She was a great lady who loved Jesus with all her heart. Here's one of her prayers: 'Lord, you know that I'm growing older. Keep me from the fatal habit of thinking I must say something on every subject and on every occasion. Deliver me from the need to try and straighten out everybody's affairs. Keep my mind free from endless details; give me wings to get to the point. I ask for grace to listen to the tales of others' pains; but seal my lips when it comes to my own aches and pains. I ask not for improved memory, but for a growing humility, especially when my memory seems to clash with the memory of others. Teach me that occasionally I may be mistaken. Keep me reasonably sweet. I don't necessarily want to be a saint; some of them are so hard to live with. Make me thoughtful but not moody, helpful but not bossy. Give me, I pray, the ability to see blessings in unexpected trials and goodness in less-than-perfect people. And give me the grace to tell them so, in Christ's name, amen.' It's obvious that Dale's relationship with Jesus was really personal and really honest. How about you? Are your prayers just phrases you've picked up from here and there or are they from the bottom of your heart?

content.title: Mastering yourself
content.introtext:
Everything is permissible for me - but

1 Corinthians 6:12 NIV
Let your body know who's in charge. Try saying 'NO' to yourself everyday. If you do, you'll be able to do it when it matters. Paul writes, 'I am allowed to do all things, but not all things are good for me to do. I am allowed to do all things, but I will not let anything make me its slave.' Paul measures what he does by these words. Is it good for me? Could it control me? Do you tell yourself, 'I need to change, but I'll do it tomorrow'! You can eat chocolate cake every night at bedtime if you want but it's not good for you, especially if you want to look buff! You can do whatever you want with your time, spend your dosh how you want, but don't start complaining when you're left with nothing. You can fill your head with all kinds of rubbish but remember that filling your head the rubbish will mash up your head in no time leaving you with no respect for yourself or anyone else. If you want to stop your bad habits and start some good ones, the only person who can do that is, YOU. Who you are is made up of what you choose everyday. Day by day, what you think, what you choose and what you do, is who you become.

content.title: The power of passion (4)
content.introtext:
His word is in my heart like a fire.

Jeremiah 20:9 NIV
If you've ever built a fire you'll know it eventually goes out if you don't keep topping it up. There are two kinds of peeps you will meet in life: The fire-fuellers and the fire-quenchers.The fire-fuellers help you and push you to be better. The fire-quenchers will try stopping you and holding you back. How can you tell the difference? People who quench your fire usually say things like: 'you can't do that... we tried before but it didn't work... don't try change things when there's no need... you don't have the talent', and stuff like that. If you've heard this before from other people around you, pray for them, love them, but don't let them affect you. These people always see what's wrong rather than what's right. They stop you from trying to be the best by putting out your fire. Sometimes they do this on purpose and other times they don't know that they're doing it. Spend more time with fire-fuellers because they don't look at you and see you the way you are, but see what you can be. They want you to burn hotter and brighter! There's about 200 million Christians in the Chinese church today. One of the guys who helped fuel the fire was a dude called Hudson Taylor. He said, 'The sun has never risen in China in 40 years, without me on my knees in prayer.' That's passion!

content.title: The power of passion (3)
content.introtext:
I must be about my Father's business.

Luke 2:49
Look at the life of Jesus. When he was 12 He told His folks, 'I had to be in my Father's house.' Later he told His disciples, 'We must do the work of the one who sent me here' (John 9:4). Jesus knew what He was sent here to do and He didn't let anything or anybody get in his way!!! When you plan your life around your God-given talent maybe you'll get laughed at by people but they don't know who you really are and what's burning inside you!!! Ask yourself, 'Would I rather live with the pain of taking a chance, or the pain of wishing I'd done something but now it's too late?' Hmmmmmm...?' Leader dude, Dr John Maxwell describes a decision to change that he made, 'I noticed that my talents would be used better if my passion was the same as my plans. I was wasting time doing things I didn't really want to do and doing things I didn't really have the talent to do. It changed my life! My problems and all the stuff that was in my way didn't just go away though, but it gave me the courage to face them with greater energy and excitement.' If your plans are not side by side with your passion, you best start planning around your passions - make some changes today!

content.title: The power of passion (2)
content.introtext:
Fan into flame the gift of God, which is in you.

2 Timothy 1:6 NIV
There are 2 kinds of life you need to avoid: 1) Life with a low flame - Don't become like Eddie who's Nana liked opera. On Eddie's eighth birthday she took him to the Opera which was sung in German. The very next day he wrote a note to his Nana: 'Dear Nana, thank you for the birthday present. It's what I always wanted, but not very much. Love from Eddie.' You have to admire the honesty! There's an old saying: 'Find something you love doing so much that you would do it for nothing and when you learn to do it really well, people will actually like pay you to do it. 2) Life with no flame - Some people say they've had enough. The truth is that most of them never had the right kinda energy in the first place. Author dude Norman Cousins said, 'Death isn't the greatest loss in life. The greatest loss is what dies inside us while we're still alive.' So if you're not careful you could end up like the dude whose grave stone said, 'Died at 30, Buried at 60.' Don't let that happen to you. When you find your God-given talent, you find your passion. Will you have to keep finding the energy? Yes you will, quite often! But it will rev you up and carry you to where you want to be.

content.title: The power of passion (1)
content.introtext:
[My] life is worth nothing unless I use it for doing the work assigned me.

Acts 20:24 TLB
Passion, isn't just the dodgy stuff people get carried away with in steamy moments of lurrrve! Actually, no, passion is something we can all do with a bit of. Passion energises you! Passion brings results. Passion keeps you from quitting. Passion is infectious. Without passion, Alex Ferguson would have drawn his pension long before Cristiano Ronaldo was a twinkling in his Mum's eye. Without passion Winston Churchill would have bottled it long before D-Day. Without passion we lose our way, and end up dawdling through life aimlessly. So what are you passionate about? Do you hate it when somebody gets bullied? Maybe God is giving you a passion for justice. Do you love to get things done to the best of your ability? Maybe God is giving you passion for making lasting changes? Do you have a passion for pop star Rhianna? Maybe God is telling you to go take a cold shower! You see, the thing is we need to channel our passions into the right things. It's so easy to use our passions for ourselves, but is that what God would want? The early disciples could've used their new found celebrity to queue hop at The Ivy, or to bag themselves a place on 'I'm an apostle get me out of here!!', but instead they knew the best place for their passion was making JC known. What about you? Where's your passion at?

content.title: Mind games
content.introtext:
Pulling down...strong holds; Casting down imaginations... bringing into captivity every thought.

2 Corinthians 10:4-5
Paul writes: 'Pulling down...strong holds; Casting down imaginations... bringing into captivity every thought to the obedience of Christ.' It all sounds a bit A-level theology, but all he's saying, is 'get a grip'. Pulling down strongholds means getting a grip on the junk in your life before it gets a grip on you. Do you need to sort some attitudes out? Do it, take control before its taken control of you. Casting down imaginations means don't let your mind run away with itself, making up a load of tosh about God not caring and all that, of course He cares, get back to the truth of it, stop believing your own fiction. Bringing into captivity every thought means get a fishing line on those wild leaping thoughts that do you no good. If your thoughts say 'I'm useless', kick them into touch with God's word, He says 'You're precious'. The mind is a tricky old thing, you'd think it was on our side, but if we don't take control of it, it can work against you, making up lies. Here's the good news, it's your mind, you tell it what to think about and what not. You wouldn't let your own foot kick you in your own groin, so don't let your mind kick itself in the head. So there you are, now you understand A-level theology, smarty pants.

content.title: Practice makes perfect
content.introtext:
Teach...your children and...their children after them.

Deuteronomy 4:9 NIV
It might scare the nappy off you now to think about having a kid, but one day you might find yourself having your very own sproglet The thing about kids is that they copy everything you do, its how they learn. Try this on for size, imagine having somebody following you around everywhere you go, copying every single thing you do. How embarrasing could it be! You're sat at dear old Auntie Ethel's for a nice slice of Kipling, when your little mini-me lets out a string of verbal abuse. Well you can't blame him, he's only repeating what he's heard you say with your mates. Or imagine, being with your best friend, and mini-me tells them what you really think of them, well he's only copying what you've said when you've stuck the knife in behind their back. Every parent knows that if you want your little one to have good manners, you have to model good manners to them. If you want your bundle of joy to being a kind person, you have to show them how to be kind. Could there be a bit of wisdom in there for us too? If we want to be better people, we need to copy our heavenly parent. If we want to be more like Jesus, we need to find out what sets his heart ticking, and start practising a bit of the same.

content.title: Do the right thing
content.introtext:
He guides me along right paths.

Psalm 23:3 NLT
Do the right thing. It's not easy, but do the right thing. Downloading that new album illegally, that's the easy thing, but it aint the right thing. Copying your mate's homework on the bus, that's the easy thing, but it aint the right thing. If you're asking whether something is a safe thing to do? Or whether it's the popular thing to do, perhaps you should be rephrasing it into, 'Is it the RIGHT thing to do?'. But how can you tell if it's right when everybody else seems to be doing it. 1) Pray about it. If you aint got peace about something, that might be a good indicator to think again. 2) Check the word. A good Youth Bible should point you in the right direction over all life's important stuff 3) Get good advice. Don't just talk to someone who doesn't know right from wrong, ask a sound, wise Christian about it, perhaps they might have struggled with the same thing at some point. The choices you make shape how you'll live your life. Saying you're a Christian and living like a caveman don't match up, its like saying you're a car just because you sleep in a garage! If you want to walk with The Lord, you've got to let him guide you, that might sometimes mean making the unpopular choice in life, hey! Its not always easy doing the right thing.

content.title: Sack it!
content.introtext:
The best...I can do is escape to Philistine country.

1 Samuel 27:1 TM
The 'sack it' mentality is something to watch out for. You know what I mean, Church seems boring, all your other mates are out drinking and sleeping around, your heart thinks, 'sack it' before you know it your brain's pickled with half a vat of bad cider. Or, its just you and the whole world wide web alone in a room, you tell yourself, 'sack it - what harm can it do?', so you click on that site you know you shouldn't. Or even, that moment you know you should walk away from an argument, but the red mist descends, the knuckles harden, every muscle screams, 'sack it', and you just let rip. David had his 'sack it' moments. On the run from Saul in 1 Samuel 27, he tells himself sooner or later he's dead meat, 'The best...I can do is escape to Philistine country.' For anyone who doesn't know, Philistine country was David's old battleground, and the last place he should be heading. As soon as we say, 'sack it', we head for the last place we should be going. It's destination trouble all the way. And for a while it feels good. Beware of anything that gives you an instant fix, junk food, drugs, sin, they all fill a hole temporarily, but in the long run they'll mess you up. So best sack off the 'sack it' mentality.

content.title: Win Win situation
content.introtext:
For to me to live is Christ, and to die is gain.

Philippians 1:21
Sometimes, we're a burger short of a happy meal. In our own heads we think that by being famous all our problems in life would disappear. We think that by winning the Lotto we will have happiness on our plates forever. We think that by being The Godfather people will have heaps of respect for us. Listen up, how many famous people screw their lives up for the sake of their face in the papers? How many lives does being a millionaire buy you? How much respect do you get when you're six feet under because you've took a bullet for the sake of being number one? That's not living, it's faking. Paul sussed onto a win win situation. If he was living for Christ, he'd win, because Christ is all there is worth living for. If he died, he'd win, because he'd gain more of Christ, he'd get the full fill of Him in Heaven. That kind of thinking shifts things into perspective. When you're not honing in on the fortune or fame, but instead got all your braincells pulsing on the saviour, you've found the secret to satisfaction. What can scare you once you've realised that by living you're with Jesus, and by dying you're with Jesus. Now isn't that just like all your numbers have come up at once, or in other words, 'For me, to live is Christ. And to die is gain'.

content.title: Who are you? (2)
content.introtext:
God...shaped each person in turn.

Psalm 33:13-15 TM
Paul has it sorted when he says, 'Each one of you is a separate and necessary part' (1 Corinthians 12:27 TLB). He knows that being different isn't a bad thing. If the church was full of carbon copies of each other, how boring would that be?! Everyone likes a good centre forward, but if a team was full of Wayne Rooneys it'd maybe score some amazing goals up front but it'd let plenty in at the back too. Its the same in Church, some of us will like to be up at the front, some of us might like to do things quietly in the background, well that's fine as well. The Bible says, 'God shaped each person in turn,' which means you've got your bit to play. A bus is good for carrying lots of people at the same time but you wouldn't expect it to win formula one. Likewise, a McLaren F1 is good for winning races, but it couldn't take you and you're whole school to Blackpool for the day. Know what you're designed for, and the rest will follow. The Word says, 'Be content with who you are' (1 Peter 5:6 TM). Stop trying to be an F1 if you're naturally a bus. There's no geek or glam with God - it's all about giving yourself permission to be the person God made you to be!

content.title: Who are you? (1)
content.introtext:
He fashions...hearts individually.

Psalm 33:15 NKJV
Ever wish you were better at footie? Ever wished you were more confident? Better at drawing or handy with a computer? Well don't be too hard on yourself, maybe you're just not created to be that type of person. Maybe, there's some special assignment in life that only you can do. Maybe, the world won't be the same unless you get a particular job done. You see, God 'personally formed and made' you (Isaiah 43:7 TM). You're the only 'you' He created, so if you fail to be who you are His kingdom won't benefit from your unique contribution. The question is: Who are you? Before you answer it, ask yourself this: 'What am I good at?' Are there certain jobs that come easily to you and you wonder why others can't do them? If so, that says something about your particular strengths and your God-given assignment in life. God said of Bezalel the builder, 'I have filled him with... wisdom...He is a master craftsman, expert in working with gold, silver, and bronze. He is skilled in engraving...mounting gemstones...carving wood' (Exodus 31:3-5 NLT). Bez might have had two left feet at footy, but he had a grip on what he was good at. Once you've got a grip on what you can do and what you can't, go for it! 'Fix your eyes on what lies before you...Don't get sidetracked' (Proverbs 4:25-27 NLT).

content.title: Learn to live
content.introtext:
Watch how I do it...learn to live.

Matthew 11:29-30 TM
You can study until your brain's turned blue, you can work a 48 hour day, you can even try to put the world to rights in your own dinner hour, but if you're not spending time with God, what's it all about? What's it all for? It's good to try your best, but if you're overly focused on winning, you're going to end up fried like bacon. Surely, there's more to life than just results, Jesus said, 'Are you tired? Worn out?...Come to me...recover your life. I'll show you how...work with me - watch how I do it...learn to live freely and lightly.' Sounds good, doesn't it but it calls for detoxing your thinking and reprogramming it. If your head's frazzled, ask yourself "What are my priorities here?" What's the point of elbowing your way to the top, if its at the expense of your mates, time, church and family? Remember, you're a human being not human doing. Sometimes you just need to be, rather than do. If you're just trying to impress with success, you're missing the whole point. Life is so much more than gaining and getting. Jesus could have rubbed people's noses in it, how so much better he was at miracles and stories than everybody else. But he wasn't interested in fame, he was too into what mattered to fall for that nonsense. Sometimes we need to relearn how to really live.

content.title: Hearts and thieves
content.introtext:
If the master of the house had known what hour the thief would come, he would have watched.

Matthew 24:43 NKJV
We don't want our stuff nicked, so we double lock our houses, we insure our phones, we hold onto our purses for dear life - but what about our hearts, don't we need to guard them as well? Three things to look out for: 1) Careful when you're cream-crackered. Esau wasn't with it, in fact he was so knackered his marbles had left him, all for the sake of a bit of supper. He made a very stupid decision that haunted him for a long time. Read it in Genesis 25:19-34 and don't say things you don't mean just because you've got a rumbling tum and you're in a bit of a mood. 2) Careful you don't get carried away. King Herod was a bit of a loose cannon. Seduced by a dancing girl, he shot his mouth off saying, 'Whatever you ask me, I will give you' (Mark 6:23 NKJV). She asked for the head of John the Baptist. A moment of excitement cost him dearly. Beware of moments of pleasure that will cost you everything. 3) Careful of lack of courage. Peter messed up big time, when he lost his bottle. He swore blind he'd never even met his best mate: Jesus. A weak moment can make you say things you don't mean. Esau being cream-crackered, Herod being a loose cannon, Peter being a coward. If only they'd double locked their hearts at the right moment.

content.title: Treading and trusting
content.introtext:
Every place that the sole of your foot shall tread upon, that have I given unto you.

Joshua 1:3
If The Bible bangs on about anything, its pretty much that God never lets us down when we need him. That doesn't mean he expects us to be divas doing nothing for ourselves. Quite the opposite, He wants us to pull our weight, step by step, walking by faith. It can take a lot of bottle at times, to keep on trudging and keep on trusting, especially when we just don't get where God's at with things. Job wasn't getting where God was at until 41 chapters into his own book. He'd been through the grind major style. Bankrupt, bereaved, and battered, Job treads through his darkest days believing, 'When I'm tired, I shall come forth as gold' (Job 23:10). Meaning that he was hanging onto his faith until it shined like top bling. Notice: a) it takes fire to produce gold. b) only the refiner knows the degree of heat and amount of time required c) to rush the process is to produce something of lesser value. Yes Job had his darker moments, when he questioned God's fairness, or even doubted if there was a God or anything out there, but if we're to take anything out of this poor man's mess, its that even in the worst of life, its worth trusting and trudging until the end. Job did, and his life was put back together through faith.

content.title: God goggles (2)
content.introtext:
We...are being transformed into his likeness.

2 Corinthians 3:18 NIV
Anyone who's ever thrown a sicky from school (tut tut) is bound to have seen the daytime TV classic, 'Cash in the Attic'. It's a show all about the junk people have gathering dust in the attic, that to the untrained eye looks like rubbish. Except experts give it a dust down to reveal priceless bits of treasure. Well God has more than a trained eye for hidden treasures. God's got a special heart for picking up the type of people who, seen through the world's eyes, seem as useless old junk. He just loves to dust down and polish up people so that their true worth can shine. Whenever somebody disses you, whenever you get that nagging voice in your head saying you'll never mount to much, whenever the world seems to have overlooked you, don't fret, because it's God's opinion that counts. Isaiah tells us that God sees us as '...precious and honoured in my sight'. Imagine that on your CV - the Lord God almighty, creator of everything says you are precious to Him. What more credentials for the job do you need? Maybe, it's about time you started to live it. Sadly, if you view yourself negatively, chances are people will talk down to you. But if you view yourself as God sees you, people will see somebody 'being transformed into his likeness'

content.title: God goggles (1)
content.introtext:
We were like grasshoppers in our own sight.

Numbers 13:33 NKJV
We all do it, from time to time - look in the mirror and see a useless lump of lard as our reflection. The trick is to see ourselves through God's eyes. Numbers tells the tale of Moses sending 12 spies to check out the Promised Land, 10 came back saying, 'We saw...giants...and we were like grasshoppers in our own sight.' Even though earlier in the story God had showed them just how much He was behind them the spies still fell for that age old trick of seeing themselves as useless compared to everybody else. It's a shame when we forget that God is right behind us just because we're intimidated by someone or something. Maybe we know it as head knowledge, maybe we repeat it to ourselves parrot fashion, but we're never going to get the full impact in our lives, unless we get completely on board with how much God is for us. Jesus died for you!! That's right, for you!! Would God really have allowed His precious Son to die on the cross unless he thought you were more than worth it? God's so proud of you, He's like a doting parent who loves nothing better than to tell the world how fantastic He thinks you are! You're so not a grasshopper in His sight, so neither should you be in your own sight.

content.title: Peace in purpose
content.introtext:
You will keep in perfect peace him whose mind is steadfast.

Isaiah 26:3 NIV
ipods are great. You can bang nails into walls with them. You can use them as a float down the swimming baths. You can even wipe your bum with them. Well you could do all that, but you'd be a bit of a looney tune if you did, because that's not their purpose. Their purpose is to play your favourite tracks. Its the same with our lives, we can end up banging our heads against brick walls, or literally throw them down the toilet when we're not tuned into their real purpose. Isaiah knew what that felt like, 'I have laboured to no purpose; I have spent my strength in vain and for nothing' (Isaiah 49:4 NIV). In fact, so did Job, 'I give up; I am tired of living. Leave me alone. My life makes no sense' (Job 7:16 GNT). Without purpose we make choices on how we feel at the time rather than our commitment to our goal. Stressed and depressed is how we might feel when purpose goes awol. Peace of heart and mind is on the menu when we're on track with our God-given call. Give your life a going over, what things might be good to drop, what things might be good to focus on? Just because you look busy doesn't mean you've got it all sussed, in fact, when you've got purpose you might be less busy - and less stressed!

content.title: Chill out
content.introtext:
Get some rest.

Mark 6:31 NIV
Sometimes the biggest head-pecker isn't our Mum, Dad or teacher - it's ourselves! You beat yourself up because you're not this or you're not that, you didn't do this, you didn't do that. Guilt shouts you down, failure laughs in your face, and all you can do is nominate yourself for 'loser of the year'. Once you're at that stage, best pack your suitcase and send your brain for a well needed vacation. We all need a rest from time to time. Yeah, but isn't chilling out just being lazy? Of course not, even Jesus knew there was a time for chilling. Check out Mark 6:30-32: 'The apostles gathered around Jesus and reported to him all they had done...Then, because so many people were coming and going that they did not even have a chance to eat, he said to them, "Come with me by yourselves to a quiet place and get some rest." So they went away by themselves in a boat to a solitary place' (Mark 6:30-32 NIV). Jesus understood that if you don't take a break, you'll break! So: a) make most of your time, get things done, but make sure you plan in decent chill out b) Go easy on yourself if you've not lived up to your own hyper-perfect standards c) Stop comparing yourself to swot of the year, you've got your own goals d) Chill, baby, chill!

content.title: Growing pains
content.introtext:
Practice these things. Devote your life to them.

1 Timothy 4:15 GWT
Why does change take so long? Well, first off because, we are slow learners. If it feels like you will just never ever understand what the heck Mr. Pythagoras has got to do with triangles, how much more will it take to change those nasty habits that stop you from growing. Don't panic though, The Bible is peppered with stories of God waiting patiently for people to change. For seconds, we've got to put our heads in reverse. The Good Book calls this, 'Taking off the old self, and putting on the new self' (Ephesians 4:22-23 NIV). We're all good at ditching our old threads once they look minging, well lets get good at ditching our minging attitudes and put on something with that fresh out of the box smell, like love, instead. Third reason change comes slow is pain. Remember how growing pains can ache good and proper - its the same with change - 9 times out of ten, there's no gain without pain. Hard truth is it'll more than likely be the tough times that ship-shape you into someone better. Finally, practice makes perfect. You don't instantly run a four minute mile without years of practice - just like, you don't instantly become Christ-like without years of practicing his wise words. That's why Paul tells it like it is, 'practice these things. Devote your life to them.'

content.title: Seeing beyond our differences
content.introtext:
So in Christ we who are many form one body, and each member belongs to all the others.

Romans 12 v 5 NIV
In life, and particularly in churches we can all have different opinions. Whole denominations are founded upon small differences in how they read the Bible; things that at the end of the day make no difference to whether you love God or whether you're spending eternity with Him! Using these differences to divide believers and split churches is one of satan's most powerful weapons. When a church is at war with itself, how easy is it for him to run riot outside the church? Churches have split opinions who can do what, how to worship, what we should be focussed on and even over the use of a hat in a Sunday meeting! How crazy is it that there are Christians who have fallen out over a hat? Evangelist Reinhart Bonke said that he was once criticised for having a woman preach the gospel at one of his African rallies. His response was that if he was drowning he would not care if he was rescued by a man or a woman. The truth is we don't live in a clear cut world and we can all interpret the Bible slightly differently. But if we agree on the important stuff then isn't it time to put aside petty differences and concentrate on what we have in common? Think and pray today what you can do to bring more unity in your community.

content.title: When you're on overload (3)
content.introtext:
Don't get worked up.

Matthew 6:34 TM
Everything that can go wrong has! The computer has crashed and your assignment is due in the morning, your boyfriend has dumped you and your friends are acting downright weird, church is doing your head in, and your dog has been sick in your shoes. Remember: 1) God's still looking out for you. When things look bad, remind yourself that God is bigger than your problem: 'Don't get worked up about what may or may not happen tomorrow. God will help you deal with whatever hard things come up when the time comes.' 2) Don't think about quitting! Every time you reach the breaking point it's a test. We have choices to make, do we quit and continually be blown around by the wind or stick with it and see it through. Paul was flogged, thrown in jail, shipwrecked and run out of town, but he refused to give in and in the end he was able to say, 'I have fought the good fight...finished the race, and... remained faithful' (2 Timothy 4:7 NLT). 3) Your breaking point can be the start of a breakthrough. Ever heard the expression 'hitting the wall'? Runners use it when they're exhausted and feel like giving up. But athletes know if they push through the pain they'll get the 'second wind' that'll carry them over the finish line. So keep going; by God's grace you'll make it!

content.title: When you're on overload (2)
content.introtext:
I'm awake all night.

Psalm 77:4 TM
You can't escape stress, but you can learn to cope with it by taking control of your life in small but important ways. Here are two: 1) think about someone other than yourself. David was so frazzled that he was awake all night. Ever been there? That's when you need to 'Let...praises shape your worries into prayers, letting God know your concerns. Before you know it, a sense of God's wholeness, everything coming together for good, will come and settle you down' (Philippians 4:6 TM). Elijah was depressed and suicidal when God showed him how to help himself. How? By leaving the cave he was hiding in, and going out and ministering to others. When we start supporting other people it puts our lives into perspective. Do you need help? Reach out to others. It's in 'connecting' that we are made whole! 2) don't get bitter. When you're trying your absolute best and still rubbish things happen, it's easy to feel hard done by. As Christians we can forget that life isn't supposed to be smooth and easy, but God provides the support and love we need through the tough bits. Bitter people are sad people. When you're bitter it destroys relationships and cuts you off from God's presence. The answer is learning to 'thank God no matter what happens. This is the way God wants you...to live' (1 Thessalonians 5:18 TM).

content.title: When you're on overload (1)
content.introtext:
When I was...beside myself, you calmed me down.

Psalm 94:19 TM
Before a violin can produce music, stress must be put on the strings but pull them too tightly and they'll snap. The same is true of you. Enough stress gets the juices flowing and helps you do what needs to be done, but beyond that you snap. Young people are faced with various types of pressure - family, expectations, exams, health, peer pressure, coursework. Before you start struggling, do two things: 1) ask for help: During Hurricane Katrina eight dolphins were swept out of their aquarium into the sea, but because they stuck together they were rescued. If one had tried to go it alone he'd have died. When you're alone too much you lose perspective. If the enemy can get you alone, he can influence you. God designed His family to stay connected or as Paul says, 'So that all the members care for each other' (1 Corinthians 12:25 NLT). 2) get real with God: When you're stressed (and sometimes you don't realise you are until this happens) the build up of negative emotions come out through an explosion at the wrong people. This stress needs unloading on God! Look at the Psalms. It's no co-incidence that loads of them start with crying out to God then finish rejoicing because all the stress has been released! God loves when we cry out to him, so get venting!

content.title: Wilderness attitudes!
content.introtext:
We who...believed are able to enter...God's rest.

Hebrews 4:3 NCV
After spending months wandering round the wilderness, the Israelites developed a blame-culture. They blamed their enemies, they blamed Moses, they blamed each other, they even blamed God! As a result of their blaming and complaining they got fully stuck in the wilderness. Blaming other people is a huge issue problem today. Nothing is our fault! It's always the government, teachers, family, friends, police, council or whoever's fault. Never us! We start feeling sorry for ourselves and from there it spirals into a full-blown pity-party where the world is against us and life is Oh-so terrible. The truth is, ninety-nine percent of the time the solution begins with a change of attitude in you! Sometimes things happen and we need to learn from them. Sometimes God lets things happen to teach us. So we can blame others, feel sorry for ourselves and be utterly miserable or we can take responsibility, understand that things don't always work the way we think they should and understand that people aren't perfect. Do you know one of those people who are miserable and think the world is against them and no one cares? The truth is those people are really hard to care for because they're so self-pitying! People will be far more concerned for you when you're positive and trying to make the best of things. So start taking responsibility!

content.title: Responding like Jesus!
content.introtext:
Pray for those who persecute you.

Matthew 5:44 NIV
A soldier made it his goal to end each day with a Bible reading and prayer. As the others gathered in the barracks and went to bed, he'd kneel by his bunk. Some of them saw this and started dissing him. Then one night, he got on his knees like normal, and a heavy boot flew across the room and hit him in the face. The others mocked him, trying to pick a fight but the soldier never said a word. Next morning when the boot-thrower woke up he couldn't believe what he saw. There at the foot of his bed were his boots, polished and returned. Imagine shining the boots that kick you! That takes some guts and what Jesus calls grace! Some of the guys in the barracks were 'leaders', they love to mock and hate anyone that's different. Others were 'followers'; they weren't necessarily bad, just weak and afraid to be different. Why did Jesus pray from the cross, 'Father, forgive them for they know not what they do'? Jesus understood that when people have been raised a certain way, they have problems and issues, and they need God too. He saw it as an opportunity to put God on display. Being this kind of person takes far more than going to church on a Sunday. It needs us to be Christ-like, example-setting, love-displaying people that make others sit up and take notice. Your 'rights', your pride and your wounded ego are not the issue; the One you represent is!

content.title: The overcoming spirit!
content.introtext:
Their weakness was turned to strength.

Hebrews 11:34 NLT
In nature, almost all animals have some form of weakness. Whether that is their size, shape, eyesight, teeth, diet or a whole load of other possibilities, there's always something that can be taken advantage of by a rival or a predator. However, as we can see from watching an animal documentary for more than five seconds, animals have an incredible way of turning these weaknesses into strengths. Being a small, slow animal may seem rubbish but you can fit into holes your predators can't. We all have weaknesses; some more than others.
