But as your strengths are God-given, is it not possible that some of your weaknesses may be too? You may be a stubborn so 'n' so but your stubbornness might just be the thing that enables you to kick that habit once and for all. You may have some physical problem that stops you getting out much, but maybe developing and using your mind is how you're going to impact the world. You may get easily bored and frustrated but maybe this could be used as motivation to make things better and get things changed, rather than stirring up negativity? Make a list today of your strengths and weaknesses. Go through this list and ask God, how can I use all these things for you?

content.title: Be patient, it'll happen in God's time!
content.introtext:
Rest in the Lord, and wait patiently for him.

Psalm 37:7
The old saying, 'You can't always have what you want,' isn't necessarily true. When you 'Delight yourself in the Lord...he will give you the desires of your heart' (Psalm 37:4 NIV). 'Excellent' you're thinking, 'so when's my Nintendo Wii arriving?' Bad news... that's not what it means! You see, receiving the 'desires of our heart' isn't a reward for being good; it's much deeper than that. The verse actually has a secret double meaning! You see when we 'delight ourselves in the Lord' (hang out with Him, love Him, serve Him and generally realise what an awesome God He is), then a weird thing happens; His desires become our desires! Suddenly we want our friends to know Him the way we do. We want to see the local 'emo' kids learn what life's about and be happy. We want to see the poor made rich, the sick made healthy, the downright miserable people living life to the max. Suddenly He has literally given us our desires, and when what we want is also what He wants, of course we're going to receive them! Clever double meaning, eh! One of the frustrating things about this verse is that there's no time limit. We don't know when we will see them. Sometimes we just need to be faithful and trust that we will get those desires in the right time; His time. So be patient!

content.title: Forgiveness (3)
content.introtext:
[I]...could never have made it apart from...mercy.

1 Timothy 1:15-17 TM
Often one of the hardest things about forgiveness is forgiving yourself. You can feel especially bad if you've done something that you criticised someone else for in the past! For example, it's easy to judge other people's relationships; 'they shouldn't be doing those things; oooo they should have more self control!'. But when suddenly you find yourself in a relationship, you may understand how easily you can make those mistakes yourself and your left feeling bad about what you've done AND the way you criticised others. It's easy to feel like the things you've done are to big for God to forgive, or even that you simply don't deserve forgiveness! This is particularly true when you know you didn't just make a mistake but made a calculated decision where you deliberately did something wrong, knowing you could ask forgiveness later. Remember what Paul said: 'Jesus...came...to save sinners. I'm proof; Public Sinner Number One ...someone who could never have made it apart from sheer mercy...evidence of his endless patience.' Before his conversion Paul persecuted the church, killing and torturing believers. It's how he made his living! Whatever you've done, it surely can't compare with that? If he could learn to forgive himself, you can too! In fact if you don't forgive yourself that's a bit of a proud attitude. You're not so special that you're the only one God can't forgive!

content.title: Forgiveness (2)
content.introtext:
People insulted Christ, but...He let God...take care of him.

1 Peter 2:23 NCV
A little boy who'd been rude to his Mum started sneaking off upstairs. 'Where you going, young man?' she asked. 'To my room to talk to God,' he replied. 'Isn't there something you want to tell me first?' she said. 'Nope,' he said, 'You'll just get mad. God will forgive me and forget about it.' Sometimes we upset someone and it's much easier to say sorry to God than to them, but actually we need to apologise to both. It's often much harder to admit we did wrong to another person than to God who knows it all anyway! Other times we can think we've forgiven someone but it's really obvious we've actually not. Some good clues are: getting angry when you think about them or whatever happened, ignoring or not wanting to see them, constantly reminding them of what happened, replaying the incident or conversations you'd like to have in your head. The Bible says that God won't share His right to settle old scores. He said, 'Vengeance is mine; I will repay' (Romans 12:19). If someone has wronged you it's up to God to deal with them, it's not your fight. When 'People insulted Christ...he did not insult them in return...He let God...who judges rightly, take care of him.' What's important is what happens in you, not to you. So forgive, forget, and move on!

content.title: Forgiveness (1)
content.introtext:
Forgive - only then will your heavenly Father...wipe your slate clean.

Mark 11:25 TM
How heavy is a glass of water? That depends on how far you have to carry it! A minute is no problem and after an hour your arm might ache. But after 24 hours you'll probably be in bad shape! The glass weighs exactly the same the whole time, but the longer you carry it the heavier it feels. It's the same with a grudge; it can get so heavy it stops you from living. People will hurt you; that's the reality of living anywhere except a desert island with a population of just you. Sometimes the hurt caused is cruel and intentional, but most of the time the person has no idea they even upset you. Does that mean you should go around pretending nothing's wrong? No, the first step is to be honest about how you feel, and when the hurt is deep this can be really hard! That's when you need to pray, 'Lord, change my heart and heal me.' Jesus said, 'Pray for those who mistreat you' (Luke 6:28 NIV). When you do that an amazing thing happens; you start seeing them through God's eyes instead of your raw emotions. Jesus said, 'If you have anything against someone, forgive - only then will your heavenly Father...wipe your slate clean.' When you don't forgive, God can't forgive you!

content.title: Ivan's standard
content.introtext:
Then you will understand what is right and just and fair.

Proverbs 2:9 NIV
It's really hard to keep working hard at school or college, day after day when you've exams and starting work can seem so far away! It's when you're bored, in your worst lessons, learning about things you don't care about that you get a really good chance to develop your character. In those times you can mess about, write notes, cause trouble or work hard anyway! There's a prize-winner Russian novel called 'One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich'. The hero of the story is a prisoner in a Siberian labour camp. He's forced to build a wall in freezing cold weather. As it gets darker and colder the foreman gives the order to hurry the job by throwing leftover mortar over the wall. But Ivan was determined to finish the job right. Eight years in a prison camp couldn't change his nature. Ivan was one of those people who wouldn't let anything go to waste without good reason. Eventually the foreman shouted at him and left him to it. Even in the dark, with the temperature at minus 20C, Ivan kept working. Only when he was sure that the wall was totally straight and even did he stop working. So, measured by Ivan's standard, what's your attitude to your work? Are you a fair-weather worker or will you keep going even when it gets tough?

content.title: Overcoming your pride
content.introtext:
Do not be wise in your own eyes.

Proverbs 3:7 NIV
To overcome your pride you must: 1) recognise your pride. Benjamin Franklin observed, 'Not one of our natural passions is harder to subdue than pride. Even if I could conceive that I had completely overcome it, I should probably be proud of my humility.' It is a funny thing that as soon as we realise we're humble and not proud that we're proud again! Pride is something that can stop us, especially when we're young, from doing some amazing thing. We're so scared of looking stupid! 2) be thankful. Paul writes, 'No matter what happens, always be thankful' (1 Thessalonians 5:18 TLB). Oprah Winfrey suggests, 'Keep a gratitude journal. Every night list five things that happened this day that you are grateful for. It will change your life. If you concentrate on what you don't have, you'll never have enough. If you focus on what you have, you will always see that the universe is abundant and you'll have more.' Selfish people never think they get as much as they deserve. If you're always thinking of things to be thankful for, that kind of pride will go! 3) learn to laugh at yourself. The Chinese proverb says, 'Blessed are they that laugh at themselves for they shall never cease to be entertained.' Proud people don't find it easy to laugh at themselves. So today have a little chuckle at your own expense!

content.title: There's hope for you
content.introtext:
I have...plans to give you the future you hope for.

Jeremiah 29:11 TM
Most young people don't have much clue about God's plans for their lives. You may have crazy dreams, secret passions, special skills, a very specific ambition but chances are you've not much idea where you'll be this time next week let alone in ten years time! Wherever you're at, it's 100% certain that God has a plan for your life. You're here for a reason, something designed just for you. So how do you find this special destiny? Just start where you are right now. When God puts your life on track, He starts by giving you hopes and dreams. Maybe you're wondering, 'Am I ever going to get to where I'm supposed to be?' If that's how you feel today, read these words from God to a group who'd spent their last 70 years in slavery after screwing up big time: 'I know what I'm doing. I have it all planned out; plans to take care of you, not abandon you, plans to give you the future you hope for. When you call on me, when you come and pray to me, I'll listen. When you come looking for me, you'll find me. Yes, when you get serious about finding me and want it more than anything else, I'll make sure you won't be disappointed...I'll turn things around for you' (Jeremiah 29:11-14 TM). Those words from God's mouth are for you too!

content.title: Learning to hear God's voice
content.introtext:
His sheep follow him because they know his voice.

John 10:4 NIV
One evening two old friends got together. One told the other that he could hear 18 different kinds of crickets (grasshoppers) in his garden. The other was amazed; he'd lived around there for years and never even heard one! The difference was, this friend was a professor of the study of insects who'd learned to tell the difference between 200 different cricket calls with his natural ears. How mad is that! Looking back, the first friend wrote, 'I suddenly understood that a person must want to hear, and learn to hear, and there were many sounds I was not hearing.' It's not enough just to want to hear God's voice, we need to learn what it sounds like in all its amazing variety. God speaks in loads of ways and one of those is through people. The problem is, when you only hear from God through someone else it's easy to ignore or doubt what you've heard. But when you know God is speaking right to you personally, you can't just ignore it. Jesus said, 'His sheep follow him because they know his voice' (John 10:3-4 NIV). Even the most useless of Bible characters did great things because they clearly knew God's voice when he spoke. Nothing in your life is more important than learning to know God's voice when He speaks to you!

content.title: Stay focused (5)
content.introtext:
That special gift...you were given...keep that dusted off and in use.

1 Timothy 4:14 TM
When you go to a job interview one question that often gets asked is: 'what are your strengths and your weaknesses?' Sometimes it's easier to come up with our weaknesses and these are often what we think we should focus on if we want to become better people. Paul told Timothy to focus on his strengths. 'That special gift...you were given...keep that dusted off and in use.' Focused people don't hide their weaknesses or excuse them; but instead they focus on their strengths. Tony Campolo says, 'What you commit yourself to, will change what you are and make you into a completely different person. The future conditions you, not the past. What you commit yourself to become, determines what you are; more than anything that ever happened to you yesterday. Therefore, I ask you, "What are your commitments? Where are you going? What are you going to be? Show me somebody who hasn't decided, and I'll show you somebody who has no identity, no personality, no direction."' Focusing on weaknesses instead of strengths is like having a handful of coins, a few made of gold, the rest of tarnished copper, and setting aside the gold coins to spend your time shining the copper ones in hopes of making them more valuable. No matter how long you spend, they'll never be worth what the gold ones are. So, stay focused on your God-given strengths!

content.title: Stay focused (4)
content.introtext:
Forgetting the past.

Philippians 3:13 NLT
1) Focused people don't live in the past. Sometimes we can focus on the wrong thing: the hairs growing out of your dad's nose, the legs of that boy or girl you fancy and what has happened in our past. We all have mess in our past; some of it we caused with bad decisions and actions, some of it is the hurt that others cause us. Although we need to learn from the past we mustn't let it hold us back. Earlier in the month we talked about how runners 'fix their eyes on the finishing line'. They can't afford to look behind; many races have been lost that way! Don't focus on the past, focus on the new start and future that God gives you each day. 2) Focused people don't think about the difficulties, but the rewards. If you dwell on the difficulties too long you'll start to develop self-pity instead of self-discipline. By focusing on results you'll stay encouraged. Make Christ your example. 'He was willing to die a shameful death on the cross because of the joy he knew would be his afterwards' (Hebrews 12:2 TLB). 3) Focused people choose their friends carefully. Some people know the person you are focused on becoming and they help you, encourage you, even tell you when you get off track. It's simple: hang out with these guys!

content.title: Stay focused (3)
content.introtext:
Acknowledge him, and he will make your paths straight.

Proverbs 3:6 NIV
When it comes to staying focused, keep in mind: 1) focused people always look for a better way. Don't just settle for what you already know. An American family who moved into a new neighbourhood had a late start one morning. As a result their six year old missed her school bus. Though it would make him late for work her dad agreed to take her to school if she gave him directions. After 20 minutes of going in circles they finally arrived at the school, which turned out to be only a few blocks away from where they lived. Steaming, her dad asked why she drove him all over the place when the school was so close to home. 'We went the way the school bus does,' she said, 'that's the only way I know.' God wants us to learn new things 2) focused people concentrate a little harder and a little longer. A famous baseball player said, 'What separates a superstar from the average ballplayer is that he concentrates just a little bit longer.' Focused thinking is the ability to remove distractions and mental clutter so that you can concentrate with clarity 3) focused people make commitments, not excuses. That's why praying and getting direction from God is so important. When you know it's from God you can commit. "In all your ways acknowledge him, and he will make your paths straight"

content.title: Stay focused (2)
content.introtext:
Do not swerve to the right or the left.

Proverbs 4:27 NIV
Focus does three things for you: 1) Focus keeps you on target. Ever found yourself pulled in a dozen different directions, spending loads of our time and energy on things you don't really care about (not including the washing up)? One author put it like this: 'Ours is a world where people don't know what they want, and are willing to go through hell to get it.' The Bible says: 'Let your eyes look straight ahead...Do not swerve to the right or the left' (Proverbs 4:25-27 NIV). 2) Focus increases your energy. Attempting everything, like attempting nothing, will suck the life out of you. Focus gives you energy. Admiral Richard Byrd, the Polar explorer, said, 'Few men come anywhere near exhausting the resources dwelling within them. There are deep wells of strength that are never used.' You have what it takes to go much further and faster but that won't happen without focus. Focus helps you dig deep. 3) Focus lifts you. Just knowing what you want to do and making an effort to chase it down, sets you apart from almost everybody else. Just by striving to become better than you are, you become elevated even if you don't accomplish what you desire, and even if others don't step aside for you. By trusting God and aiming higher, you move to a higher level.

content.title: Stay focused (1)
content.introtext:
Let's keep focused...those of us who want everything God has for us.

Philippians 3:15 TM
When you were younger did you ever sit with a magnifying glass trying to focus a beam of sunlight to try to set fire to some paper, a spider, or maybe even your brother or sister?! Its amazing what focused light can do. In fact, when light is focused as a laser beam, it can cut through steel. In the same way, nothing is as potent as a focused life. The men and women who make the greatest difference in life are often the most focused. The Apostle Paul said, 'I am bringing all my energies to bear on this one thing' (Philippians 3:13 TLB). Paul's obsession was to make Christ known. God will have a focus for your life too. If you want your life to have impact, focus it! Stop trying to do it all. Do less. Be willing to turn away from good activity to do only that which matters most. Doing lots of stuff doesn't mean you're doing the right stuff. Poet William Matthews wrote, 'One well-cultivated talent, deepened and enlarged, is worth a hundred shallow faculties [abilities]'. The first law of success in this day, when so many things are clamouring for attention, is concentration.' In other words , figure out what God wants you to do and focus. Does focus come easily or naturally? No, it's a discipline that must be practiced every day.

content.title: Don't cross the line
content.introtext:
You become the slave of whatever you choose to obey.

Romans 6:16 NLT
Walk into any newsagents and you will see loads of celebrity magazines. People who SEEM so important we want to look at pictures of them taking their dog for a walk or grabbing a latte. You've heard of Posh and Becks but have you heard of Clara Bow and Victor Fleming? Clara and Victor were one of the celebrity couples of the 1920s. They were massive news at the time and were as talked about as much as Brad and Angelina bu,t 80 odd years later, you've got no idea who they are. One of the problems of our culture seems to be an obsession with stuff that doesn't last long. 'All men are like grass, and all their glory is like the flowers of the field The grass withers and the flowers fall, because the breath of the LORD blows on them. Surely the people are grass. The grass withers and the flowers fall, but the word of our God stands forever' (Isaiah 40:6-8). We spend so much energy and time thinking, reading and talking about people who will be forgotten in 100 years (or if they're Big Brother contestants 100 days!). Isaiah reminds us that God is an amazing, powerful and awesome God who is eternal. His glory won't fade, His word stands forever. So, put down your celeb mag, pick up a Bible and get obsessed with Jesus.

content.title: Worth-ship
content.introtext:
they are the kind of worshipers the Father seeks.

John 4:23
The best talk that Jesus gives on worship wasn't at a big worship conference but next to a well with a Samaritan woman that His mates didn't even think He should be talking to! Here are just three things He said: 1) Anybody can do it! It doesn't matter where you are from, who your family is, what your past is like. If you love God you and He is 'number 1' in your life, you can worship. The Samaritan women didn't fit into the mould of a 'good religious person' but that wasn't a problem for Jesus. He was interested in her heart. 2) You can worship anywhere: The Jews worshipped in the temple in Jerusalem, the Samaritans worshipped on a mountain, but Jesus said it doesn't matter! You can be in a car, in a church, in a tent, in a field, in a bus shelter, in a bath, you can use DJs or church organs or silence; Jesus accepts your worship. Jesus said, 'True worshippers will worship the Father in spirit and truth' (John 4:23 NIV) 3) That God is actually looking for people who will do it. God created you to do the only thing He cannot do for Himself; worship! We were actually created to worship God! Think: worth-ship! How much do you value the Lord? We never get tired of talking about what we value most!

content.title: Seeing your trials the right way
content.introtext:
Blessed is a man who perseveres under trial.

James 1:12 NASB
Sitting at an exam desk with a pencil case rammed with spare pens, your 'lucky' mascot and the dreaded exam paper is probably not high on your list of good times. Not many of us like tests but they are an important part of life. Whether it's a football trial, a driving test, an exam or some kind of competition, remember how good it felt when you found out that you'd made it, you'd passed! The Bible talks about trials and tests, not the kind that will get you the use of your dad's car, but some of the tough stuff that life throws at us. Illness, rejection, disappointment, betrayal, violence are just a few of the trials that Christians, like everyone else in the world, will face. These kinds of difficulties and hardships can feel like they are crushing us and leave us wanting to give up on our relationship with God. Check out what the book of James says: 'Anyone who meets a testing challenge head-on and manages to stick it out is mighty fortunate. For such persons loyally in love with God, the reward is life and more life' (James 1:12 MSG). Passing your school exams or tests opens up new opportunities in life, if you stick at it through life's hardships God opens up what the Bible calls 'Abundant Life'; and that's very cool.

content.title: Give it to God
content.introtext:
Commit your way to the Lord.

Psalms 37:5
One day a kid playing with an expensive porcelain vase got his hand stuck in it and couldn't get it out. Before resorting to breaking the vase, his dad said, 'Son, relax, just open your hand and pull it out.' To his dad's astonishment the lad said, 'I can't. If I do I'll drop the 20p.' A lot of us are just like that kid, so busy holding onto something of little worth that we are on the edge of breaking something much more valuable; our lives! Let go of that thing you're holding onto; it isn't worth it! Let God have His way, 'Trust in the LORD and do good; dwell in the land and enjoy safe pasture. Delight yourself in the LORD and he will give you the desires of your heart. Commit your way to the LORD; trust in him and he will do this' (Psalm 37:3-5). The words, 'trust, delight, and commit' are your keys to success. Give up trying to handle life by yourself. Put it into God's hands and allow Him to work. He's not stumped by what going on in your life right now. Check His record of achievement! Do you seriously think your problem is too big for Him, or that He can't do it without your help? Come on, give it to God and watch what happens!

content.title: Trusting God in the dark (2)
content.introtext:
You do not realise now what I am doing, but later you will.

John 13:7 NIV
Mary and Martha were upset that, even though they sent urgent messages to Him, Jesus didn't arrive on the scene until their brother Lazarus was dead. 'Lord...if you had been here, my brother would not have died' (John 11:21 & 32 NIV). But instead of giving them excuses, Jesus replied, 'Did I not tell you...if you believed, you would see [God glorified in this?]' (John 11:40 NIV). When God asked Abraham to sacrifice his son Isaac he didn't understand, but later he witnessed God's faithfulness when Isaac was returned to him totally unharmed. Joseph didn't know why his brothers mistreated him or why he was imprisoned unfairly, but later he understood it when looked back and saw God's hand in everything that had happened. His father questioned why Joseph had been taken away from him, but later, looking into the face of the man who had been made governor and who'd saved the lives of the nation, God's purposes became clear. That's why Jesus said to Mary and Martha, 'You do not realise now what I am doing, but later you will.' God doesn't expect you to understand, but He does expect you to trust Him. This might feel really tough right now but you can trust God. Make sure the experience isn't making you bitter but is making you better by causing you to draw closer to Him?

content.title: Trusting God in the dark (1)
content.introtext:
If the Lord is with us, why has...this happened?

Judges 6:13 NIV
The must-have designer bling of 100 years ago was lace, and Germany's exclusive textile mills were like the GUCCI of the lace world. Each room was dark, except for the light falling from a small window onto the weaver's work. That's because lace can be made more beautifully with more special details when the weaver is in darkness and his work is in the light. Have you ever felt like Gideon who said, 'If the Lord is with [me], why has...this happened?' When life goes pear-shaped, doesn't make sense and everything seems dark, check out this promise He makes to His people, 'I will give you the treasures of darkness, riches stored in secret places, so that you may know that I am the Lord ...who [calls] you by name' (Isaiah 45:3 NIV). Like the lace makers, God can make something beautiful in the darkness. Sometimes He is changing us, sometimes he is changing the circumstances. When the Israelites faced their greatest challenge, the Red Sea, the Bible says, 'All that night the Lord drove the sea back' (Exodus 14:21 NIV). He is working even though you can't see Him. Anybody can 'big up' God in good times, but trusting Him in dark times takes that special kind of commitment that is spelt F-A-I-T-H. The best part is that the bible describes faith as a gift - a gift that God wants to give you today.

content.title: Becoming unselfish
content.introtext:
Let us fix our eyes on Jesus.

Hebrews 12:2 NIV
The Bible says: 'Let us fix our eyes on Jesus, the author and perfecter of our faith, who for the joy set before him endured the cross, scorning its shame, and sat down at the right hand of the throne of God.' Maybe you've heard preachers say Jesus is like the finishing line in a race; in the same way a runner would focus on the tape we should fix our eyes on Jesus. Well yes, maybe that's one way of looking at it. But another perspective would be that Jesus isn't just like the finish line in the race of life, He's also a fellow-runner. In His human life He showed us how to run the race like a champion; He set the world record! One of the things great athletes do is study the films of champions to discover their techniques; maybe we need to study Christ and check out His moves. Rewind and watch the tape over and over and you'll see obedience, surrender, love and selflessness to name but a few of Jesus' champion moves. Today we'll look at just one. Do you want to be like Christ? Begin thinking less about yourself. Work toward becoming unselfish. For one full day, let go of anything that puts you first and others second. On that same day, fix your attention on Jesus by surrendering in complete selflessness.

content.title: Discover what's within you!
content.introtext:
This treasure...is from God.

2 Corinthians 4:7 NIV
Do you know you have hidden treasure inside you? God put it there. It's YOUR unique qualities and gifts. This treasure within you 'is from God,' but God is a bit like those millionaires in the Dragon's Den TV programme; when He invests He expects a return! He wants you to use the investment well! Someone said the wealthiest spot of land on this planet is not an oilfield, diamond mine or treasure island; the real treasures lie in your local cemetery. That might sound a bit morbid but buried beneath those sacred stones are dreams that never came to pass, songs that were never sung, books that were never written, ideas that were never shared, inventions that were never designed. Only a tiny percentage of those who live on this planet will discover and fulfil their true potential. Do you want to be one of them? Ask yourself: 'Who am I? What is my treasure? Why did God put me here? How can I maximise my abilities for His glory?' Get the answers to these questions and life gets exciting! Don't worry if you haven't found your life's purpose yet, talk to God. 'Everything...finds its purpose in him' (Colossians 1:16 TM). Remember that before you spoke your first word or took your first step, God had a plan for your life. Keep listening to Him!

content.title: Putting off putting off
content.introtext:
Find out and do whatever the Lord wants you to.

Ephesians 5:17 TLB
Have you got something important to do that you keep putting off till tomorrow? a) its up to YOU. No matter how hard you wish, the tooth fairy isn't going to come while you're sleeping and sort this one. A Chinese proverb says 'Great souls have wills, feeble souls have wishes.' YOU need to do something! b) check out your excuses. An excuse puts the blame on someone or something other than you, which is handy, but doesn't get the thing done! Is there really a good reason why it hasn't happened or are you just starting to believe your own excuses?. Check out your mouth; zip it when you feel an excuse coming on c) focus on the upside. To get you over the hump, focus on what you'll 'get out of it' when you get it done. What is the upside? Fix your eyes on the prize! d) ask for help. One person doesn't win the World Cup the whole squad does. Speaking of the church, Paul writes, 'Each part...helps the other parts grow' (Ephesians 4:16 NLT). Often we can't do what we want on our own. It takes guts to tell someone what you want to achieve and ask their help. But the risk is worth taking. Problems become smaller when you confront them. Touch a nettle timidly and it stings you, grasp it tightly and it crumbles in your hand.

content.title: Rejection-proofed
content.introtext:
Our Father loves us, for he calls us his children, and that is what we are.

1 John 3:1
We all hate rejection and so we try different things for rejection protection: a) putting up walls. Vowing never to let anybody get close enough to hurt us again. Yeah, sounds good in theory but all our relationships miss out if our hearts get hard b) putting on our best tough act! When we feel rejected we imagine we're being attacked even when we're not. So we put on our boxing gloves and come out swinging c) pushing others away. Who needs other people anyway? As a result nobody is allowed close enough to meet our needs d) people pleasing by doing anything to get people to like us or let others treat us like dirt because we think it's what we deserve and it may be our last chance at love e) practicing perfectionism. Human standards vary so much that you'll never make everybody happy. Give it up! God already loves you unconditionally. 'Our Father loves us, for he calls us his children, and that is what we are.' And 'that's only the beginning...when Christ is...revealed, we'll...become like him' (1 John 3:2 TM). If you don't you see yourself as God sees you, what others think can cut deep. Worst of all, you'll never discover or be discovered for the unique and wonderful person God made you to be. The best rejection projection? Get a true view of you...and that's God's view.

content.title: Before you die - live!
content.introtext:
Do not boast about tomorrow, for you do not know what a day may bring forth.

Proverbs 27:1 NIV
Chuck Swindoll writes, 'The plane was headed for New York; a routine...flight. But this time it proved to be otherwise. As they were on their descent pattern the pilot realised that the landing gear was not engaging. He messed around with the controls, trying again and again to get the gear to lock in place...without success. He then asked ground control for instructions. As the plane circled the landing field and emergency crews coated the runway with foam, fire trucks and other emergency vehicles moved into position. Meanwhile the passengers were told to manoeuvre in that calm, unemotional voice pilots do so well. Flight attendants glided about the cabin with an air of cool reserve. Passengers were told to place their heads between their knees and grab their ankles just before impact. There were tears, panic and cries of despair...the pilot announced over the intercom, "We are beginning our final descent. At this moment... it is my obligation to inform you that if you believe in God you should commence prayer." So what's the message? Live each day in the light of eternity. Seize the moment and wring every drop out of it. Love and enjoy the people who matter most to you - and reach out with compassion to the people who society says don't matter at all. Run towards God's plan for your life. In other words, before you die, live!

content.title: The gift of repentance
content.introtext:
I gave her time to repent.

Revelation 2:21 NLT
When God tells you to repent, He gives you time and grace to do it. If you don't, there will be consequences. That doesn't mean that God is dreaming up some cruel punishment for you - it just means that you reap what you sow. For every action there is a reaction. If you choose to keep living life by your own rules you will reach a place where your ability to say 'no' is so weakened that you become a slave to what your habits and your lifestyle. As long as desire the rewards your sin brings, you won't want freedom from it. One counsellor writes: 'I kept trying not to commit a particular sin, praying about it over and over, only to do it again. Finally I got mad at God and cried out, "Why don't you help me with this?" He answered, "Because you aren't disgusted with it yet. You're still enjoying it." I protested, "I do not. I hate it." God replied, "If you hated it enough you'd quit it." In that moment I realised that I enjoyed the rewards of my sin more than the rewards of obedience. Repentance is a gift of love which comes from God. And until that love is allowed to work in us, touching and exposing those carefully guarded areas, we cannot change.' So, today, ask God for the gift of repentance.

content.title: Give God the reins
content.introtext:
Trust in the Lord with all your heart and lean not on your own understanding.

Proverbs 3:5 NIV
Writer Cliff Schimmels tells this story about the days before cars: 'When I was young my dad had a team of horses. One day he said to me, "Son, would you like to drive?" So I took the reins. I was in control. I was driving. But the plodding bothered me, it was too slow. So I clucked the horses along and they began to trot. Then Babe and Blue came up with a better idea. They decided that if they ran we would get home faster.... As the prairie-dog holes whizzed by I concluded that we were in a dangerous situation, so I tried my best to slow down the runaway team. I tugged on the reins until my hands cramped. I cried and pleaded, but nothing worked. Old Babe and Blue just kept running. I glanced over at my dad and he was just sitting there, watching the world go by.... My hands were cut from the reins, tears streaming down my face, frozen from the winter cold. Finally in desperation I turned to my dad and said, "Here, take the reins, I don't want to drive any more." There's always that moment when the only way out is to turn to our Heavenly Father and say, 'Here, take the reins, I don't want to drive any more.' And He will, but you've got to hand them to Him!

content.title: 'I knew you when...'
content.introtext:
Isn't this the carpenter?

Mark 6:3 NIV
Be careful around those who love to say, 'I knew you when...' in an attempt to label or limit you. You need to understand this: your decision to step out and follow God will put pressure on others and the first place you'll feel it will be with those closest to you, especially if it means you start progressing in life more quickly than them. The Bible says that Eliab (David's bro) 'was angry at him and said, "What are you doing here, anyway? Who's taking care of that little flock of sheep out in the desert? You spoiled brat!"', (1 Samuel 17:28 CEV). Before David could beat Goliath he had to beat the opinions of those around him - and you will too! Look at the life of Jesus. When He went back to His hometown they said, 'What's this wisdom that has been given him, that he even does miracles! Isn't this the carpenter? Isn't this Mary's son...And they took offence at him. Jesus said to them, "Only in his hometown, among his relatives and in his own house is a prophet without honour." He could not do any miracles there, except lay his hands on a few sick people and heal them. And he was amazed at their lack of faith' (Mark 6:2-6 NIV). Bottom line: be careful around those 'who knew you when...'

content.title: Vision (3)
content.introtext:
Slowly, steadily, surely, the time approaches when the vision will be fulfilled.

Habakkuk 2:3 TLB
When God gives you a vision, He also gives you the provision needed to fulfil it! Often He'll use something you already possess even though you don't know it. Faced with feeding 5000 hungry people, the disciples felt totally useless. They weren't in one of the big towns or cities where they could run around the local shops - they were in the middle of nowhere! But Jesus said, 'How many loaves do you have...Go and see' (Mark 6:38 NIV). God will open your spiritual eyes to see what you already have or is within your reach. He'll bless it and then get you using it! Stop making excuses, feeling sorry for yourself, talking yourself down or being intimidated by people who say you don't have what it takes. Listen to God! He's provided everything to get you to where you need to be. Paul writes, 'Now glory be to God who by his mighty power at work within us is able to do far more than we could ever dare to ask or even dream of - infinitely beyond our highest prayers, desires, thoughts, or hopes' (Ephesians 3:20 TLB). Notice the words 'far more' and 'his mighty power at work within us.' Look in the mirror and say, 'I am full of resources. God has given me everything I need to fulfil His plan for my life.' This isn't hype, pride or mind-over-matter. It's faith talk!

content.title: Vision (2)
content.introtext:
Slowly, steadily, surely, the time approaches when the vision will be fulfilled.

Habakkuk 2:3 TLB
When David volunteered to fight Goliath Saul tried to get him to go out to battle wearing his suit of armour. Dave put it on and it was too heavy and didn't fit him; he could hardly move let alone fight. Don't try to be something you're not just to look the part; if you do you'll find that you're restricted and uncomfortable because you're not being you. God made you unique and gave you a part to play in His plan for the world. Many people wear themselves out trying to fulfil a vision God didn't give them because they need to prove themselves to someone. Other people have unresolved issues that they wrap up in the appearance of a vision from God but really they're just trying to win a parent's love, or to demonstrate they're as talented as their brother or sister. Don't make this mistake or you'll end up frustrated and feeling like you failed God didn't promise to give you what He gave others. You're unique, so is God's plan for your life. If you're not 'graced' to do it, you'll wear yourself out. Maybe the grass is greener on the other side but it still needs cutting! If you're trying to do someone else's job you'll just feel pants. Every call has it's cost; but if you're doing what God told you then he'll help you handle it!

content.title: Vision (1)
content.introtext:
Slowly, steadily, surely, the time approaches when the vision will be fulfilled.

Habakkuk 2:3 TLB
Visions aren't for the immature, the impatient, or people who like life comfy and cosy; so if you still like your dummy, or if you can't get out from under that duvet, this isn't for you... but if you like adventure you've come to the right place! Listen: In the early stages of pregnancy a baby is easier to lose. It's the same when God gives you vision; you need to protect it. The enemy tried to destroy Moses and Jesus before they reached their second birthday. Why? He feared what they would become and he fears you too! When a woman is pregnant, she has to cut out things that could harm the baby; like smoking and alcohol. To see your vision become a reality will mean daring to be different, even radical; not hanging out with the neggy crowd and getting your priorities straight. Sometimes you need to choose your purpose over your popularity! If you think fulfilling a vision is easy, check the price tag! Like childbirth, it's hard work, it's painful. So before you make any snap decisions, or mess around with God's purpose for your life, ask yourself, 'Can I see this through to the end? Esther's vision meant putting her life on the line and saying, 'If I die, I die (Esther 4:16 NCV). Did she die? No, but she had to be willing to. Are you?

content.title: Shipwrecked
content.introtext:
Holding on to faith and a good conscience.

1 Timothy 1:19 NIV
In the bible Paul writes to Timothy warning him to keep his conscience grounded in God's word. Loads of Tim's mates hadn't kept a tight hold of God and because of that Paul said they had become like sailing ships that had lost their way and been dashed on the rocks! What a depressing picture! The saying, 'Let conscience be your guide,' needs a bit adding to it: '...as long as your conscience is rooted in God.' When we want to do our own thing and go our own way, we justify it by saying, 'If it feels so right it how can it be wrong?' Understand this: if God's Word says something is wrong, it's wrong; no matter how right it feels! There's no wriggle room! When you make all of your choices based on how you feel at that moment in time you could run the risk of the winds of temptation, compromise and comfort sweeping you off course and ending up shipwrecked. The Apostle John gives us an all important reason for keeping our conscience in good repair: 'If we don't feel guilty, we can come to God with bold confidence. And we will receive from him whatever we ask because we obey him and do the things that please him' (1 John 3:21-22 NLT). That's better than the seaweed option any day!

content.title: Grace
content.introtext:
I am persuaded beyond doubt... that... [nothing] will be able to separate us from the love of God.

Romans 8:38 - 39 AMP
Do you ever categorise sin? Obviously murder is a 10. Lying is maybe a 4-6 depending what the lie is; talking about somebody being their back is only a 1 coz they'll never find out! Sounds stupid, but sometimes we try to kid ourselves that God thinks of sin in the same way! No Way! In God's eyes sin is sin! That's why the whole world's been in chaos just because Adam and Eve ignored God and took what was labelled 'Not for Human Consumption'. God's standard is 'perfection' and you couldn't reach it in a thousand lifetimes. Thank God for Jesus and His grace, God's incredible favour, is the only hope any of us has! Your level of love will always relate to the level of forgiveness you've received. Jesus taught that those who have been forgiven loads, love loads! (See Luke 7:47). '...God was in Christ, offering peace and forgiveness to the people of this world' (2 Corinthians 5:19). Your whiteboard's been wiped clean. Now He says, 'Come and be reconciled to Me. Let's have a relationship. You've nothing to fear, for nothing can separate you from My love.' Listen: 'I am persuaded beyond doubt... that... [nothing] will be able to separate us from the love of God.' (Romans 8:38-39) Doesn't it blow your mind to think that nothing, absolutely nothing, can ever cause God to turn His back on you!

content.title: He's Given You the Ability!
content.introtext:
Take a lesson from the ants

Prov 6:6 NLT
If it hasn't cost you, it's not worth having! Have you ever watched an ant carrying home a piece of bread that's ten times bigger than itself? How does it do that? Even the bible points it out as an example of the kind of determination that's needed to get the juice out of life. You could put it like this: success belongs to those too small to carry what they believe in but too stubborn to leave it behind! If God the Creator lives within you, then you are 'creative'. If success doesn't come after you, get up and go after it. A young man once asked an old man, 'What's the secret of your success?' 'Good decisions,' he replied. 'How did you learn to make good decisions?' the young man asked. 'By making bad ones,' the old man replied. Once you discover your gift and identify your dream, get going! Stop waiting for opportunity. Opportunity is the breath in your body and the strength of your mind. If you use your God-given gifts wisely, there's no telling what you can do. But you must be a 'doer'! God isn't going to drop everything into your lap. A God-given dream is supposed to become reality. God will give you the power to succeed but you have to take it, get your focus right, work hard and don't give up!

content.title: Insignificance to Significance
content.introtext:
Does anyone dare despise this day of small beginnings?

Zechariah 4:10
There was this guy called Dwight, he grew up with loads of brothers and sisters, not much education and only his widowed mother to look after him. She made Dwight go to church but he couldn't get his head round all the 'churchy spiritual talk'. At 17 he left home and moved to the city to work in his uncles shoe shop - on the condition that he went to church every week. One day a bloke in the church told Dwight about God's love for him and he gave his life to Jesus. Dwight knew nothing about the Bible so people looked down on him and assumed that God wouldn't use him...But they were wrong! God saw in the heart of Dwight Moody the raw material necessary to make a communicator of His Word and a changer of nations. That's exactly what Dwight became! Every oak tree starts as an acorn. Jesus began in a stable but He didn't stay there. David was a shepherd but he became King. Joseph was sold as a slave but he became Prime Minister. Why? Because '... God was with him... gave him favour and wisdom... made him Governor over Egypt... '(Acts 7:9-10 NKJ). Whatever you have today is enough to create anything you'll ever need in your future. Just put it into God's hands and be willing to start small.

content.title: Fit for Purpose!
content.introtext:
He trains my hands for battle

Psalm 18:34 NIV
In order to get fit for the purpose God has for you you'll need to follow this training program: 1) say 'no' to negativity: be ruthless with bad thoughts 2) don't be a 'belly button Christian' (just focused on yourself) put other people's needs first 3) Eat the word: as you feed on God's word you are made strong 4) listen to the still small voice: it's unlikely that God will use a lighting bolt from heaven to get your attention every time! Don't rush your time with Him and you'll notice the difference. 5) shift to a higher gear of faith: to go faster and cover more ground you have to hit the high gears. That means gathering momentum - just like riding a bike you'll never get any speed up if you're always stopping and starting again 6) get the right friendships: God's into community not just individuals. In community you find out what people are truly made of and you can be there for each other when the tough times come. Treasure your God given friends 7) ask God to give you understanding about the place you're in. Knowing you're in training for your destiny will keep you from pulling back, following the crowd or chucking in the towel. The word for you today is: press through and get fit for purpose!

content.title: A recipe for faith
content.introtext:
Faith is being sure of what we hope for and certain of what we do not see.

Heb 1:1 NIV
Jacob woke up one morning after having an encounter with God the night before and said, 'Surely the Lord is in this place, and I was not aware of it' (Genesis 28:16 NIV). God got Jacob's attention, gave him a shake and woke up some stuff that had been snoozing in Jacob for a long time: 1. the desire above all else to hear from God 2. the courage to believe God when He speaks 3. the boldness to get out there and do it! Do those 3 things need waking up in you today? When you mix those 3 things together you've got yourself a recipe for Faith! God will speak to you but He won't force you to do anything. You have to make a choice to believe what He says and then do it. When God speaks to us He often does it through people. You are in a process of learning to recognise His voice. Don't be afraid of 'getting it wrong' Jesus knows that we're still learners with our 'L' plates on! There's one simple way to get to know God's voice - read His word! Listen: 'All scripture is God - breathed' (2 Tim 3:16) How cool is that! You've got a book of words straight from God's heart to yours! If you live by what He says about you it will change your life forever.

content.title: Talking Faith
content.introtext:
Faith is being sure of what we hope for and certain of what we do not see.

Heb 1:1 NIV
What is faith? 'Faith is being sure of what we hope for and certain of what we do not see.' (Heb 11:1 NIV) How do you get faith? Listen: 'Faith comes by hearing and hearing by the word of God.' (Rom 10:17 NKJ) There's a difference between having a positive outlook on life and being a person who has faith. Being positive will make you feel good but it won't change your circumstances; but the Word of God does! The writer to the Hebrews says that God's word is a powerful like a sword. (Heb 4:12 NIV) So imagine the breakthroughs you can be part of if you choose to believe God's word and then you speak that word over your circumstances. For example you might be having a tough time because the devil is telling you lies like, 'you're rubbish and a failure'. If that's the case then instead of agreeing with him take God's word and agree with that instead! Start today by getting your tongue around some of the awesome promises that are yours in Jesus, go on, say it out loud: 'God's word says that He has good plans for my life (Jer 29:11). With God on my side I can do anything because he has made me a winner not a loser (Rom 8:37). I was made to silence the enemy with my praises.' (Psalm 8:2) Now you're talking faith!

content.title: Attitude Check?
content.introtext:
The Lord is the judge of our motives.

Proverbs 16:2 CEV
Writer Isabel Wolseley says, 'I'm a placid, get-along-with-everybody person. But that changed when my friend and I had a disagreement. I told her I was right, and why, and others commended me for having been right. The trouble is, I didn't feel any better...I felt worse. "Lord," I prayed, "You know I was right, so why do I feel so terrible?" I stewed for several days then I sensed His answer: "Yes, you were right, but your attitude was wrong!" I asked my friend to forgive me. She did, and our relationship was restored. This happened several years ago, and you know what? I can't even remember what the argument was about.' What's more important; you're need to be right, or your mate's feelings? As usual the bible has just the right words for us in this situation: 'Be quick to listen, slow to speak and slow to become angry.'(Jam 1:19 NIV) Ask yourself, 'Why do I want to win this argument so badly? To look good, make a point or try and sound clever?' Check this out: 'We may think we know what is right, but the Lord is the judge of our motives.' (Prov 16:2) Paul writes, 'Let the Spirit change your way of thinking' (Eph 4:23 CEV). Bottom line: when you listen to the Holy Spirit He will tell you when you need to change your attitude.

content.title: Activity vs Intimacy
content.introtext:
The Spirit will take from what is mine and make it known to you

John 16:15 NIV
Activity can never replace intimacy. There are loads of people in your life that you do different things with - shopping, footie, even maybe homework every now and again! But God doesn't want to be just like a mate you hang about with, God wants to be as close to you as the hairs on the back of your neck and the lines in the palms of your hands. And he wants you to be in His will and on His wavelength. So how can this become a reality for you today? Paul gives us an answer in 1 Corinthians 2, verse 14, 'The unspiritual self, just as it is by nature, can't receive the gifts of God's Spirit.' (TM) He goes on to say that the things of God are 'silliness' to that part of us. So getting to a place of more intimacy with God means doing stuff that unlocks a deeper part of our identity. This is why Christians pray, worship and sometimes even skip meals (fasting). These are just some of the ways God has made available to get around the 'unspiritual' part of us to connect more directly with God. Intimacy of any kind is rare today, true intimacy that is, not the intimacy you can get round the back of the disco after a few White Lightning's. But spiritual intimacy, that's something really, really special and is worth giving everything to find.

content.title: Seeds and weeds
content.introtext:
An enemy did this

Matthew 13:28 NIV
Matthew chapter 13 contains an eye-opening story that revolves around a scene from a farmer's field. Like most of Jesus' parables it leaves us wondering how we are meant to understand it. Well, one way is that while God is planting wheat (truth) the enemy is planting weeds (lies). The truth and the lies are growing side by side in the same field! Imagine your life is like that field. Everyday there are loads of people wanting to plant stuff in it - both seeds and weeds! Through TV, through magazines, through the internet, not to mention your teachers, parents and friends, all sorts of mixed messages are coming your way - truth, half-truth and downright lies! Thankfully, because you have the Holy Spirit living in you it is possible to recognise when, 'An enemy did this.' The parable contains a subtle warning too, an encouragement to stay alert: 'While everyone was sleeping, his enemy ...sowed weeds among the wheat' (Matthew 13:25 NIV). We all know that the only people who talk to you while you're asleep are hypnotists. So wake up before you are conned into doing something you'll regret! Think it's no big deal? One degree off course may seem harmless enough, but stay on that track and you'll soon end up a long, long way from where God wants you to be.

content.title: Duty Calls
content.introtext:
God's gift to us is...happiness.

Ecclesiastes 3:13 CEV
All of us have to do things out of a sense of duty, not joy. You know what it's like, you go and visit grumpy uncle Fred on Boxing Day every year because he happens to be your mum's brother. Yes, his house smells and he never remembers your name but you have go, it's your duty because he's family. So maybe it's not such a big deal to visit uncle Fred once a year - but what if everything in your life was in that category - that's no way to live. And yet some people treat the Christian life like that. It's as if following Jesus has been reduced to a list of boring and annoying things that you have to do now because you're in God's family. If that sounds anything like you today you need to know that's not how God wants you to live. God has wired you to thrive through times of fun and relaxation. They're not unspiritual! Without them you become unbalanced and you open yourself to mood swings and stress-related illnesses. Yes, you're called to help others, but it's not wrong to do things for yourself, to receive from God, and those He sends to bless you. If somebody compliments you, accept it graciously; if they want to give you a gift, thank them warmly; it's your duty to receive as much as it is to give!

content.title: Are you comfy?
content.introtext:
In everything God works for the good of those who love him...because that was his plan.

Romans 8:28 NCV
Be careful you don't get too comfortable - if you do God might just stir things up! The mother eagle teaches her little ones to fly by making their nest so uncomfortable that they're forced out of it. Next they're literally pushed off the cliff edge! Can you imagine their thoughts: 'What's going on - I thought you loved meeeeeeeeeeeee!' Who and where you are at this moment in time is totally within range of God's plan - no matter what comes your way to divert, distract or disable you there's no way you'll ever be out of his sight. In His wisdom He knows that you need the challenge of certain situations to mature you. Yes, even those people who rub you the wrong way are actually making you more like Jesus! Paul says, God 'understands...and knows what is best for us at all times' (Ephesians 1:8 TLB). So instead of pestering Him to change things, thank Him for the lessons you're learning. And if you can't figure out what those lessons are take the advice of the Apostle James: 'If...you need wisdom...ask God' (James 1:5 CEV). Finally, when you're in a situation that creates more questions than answers, it takes faith to accept that 'in everything God works for the good of those who love him.' But over and over and again potentially wasted experiences will become confidence-builders and learning-accelerators if you let God into them!

content.title: Momentum
content.introtext:
I'm still as strong today

Joshua 14:10 NIV
When, at the Olympics in 1996, Canadian sprinter Donovan Bailey ran the 100 metres in 9.84 seconds he broke the world record and was hailed as the world's fastest man. After his big win experts who critiqued videos of the race made an interesting discovery: Bailey never once lost momentum. In fact, he was still accelerating as he crossed the finish line - even though he was running at over 30 mph! Over the last couple of days we've looked at events from the book of Joshua. Well later on in that story we find out some amazing things about his best mate Caleb. Check this out: 'So here I am today, eighty-five years old! I'm still as strong today as the day Moses sent me out; I'm just as vigorous to go out to battle now as I was then.' (Joshua 14:10-14 NIV). Caleb was a guy who still had momentum when he was an old geezer - don't you want to be like that! It's clear that Caleb wasn't one of life's sprinters, his aim wasn't top speed, he wanted to go the distance. And that's exactly what he did by not allowing his strength to be sapped by taking pointless detours. Maybe he inspired the Apostle Paul hundreds of years later who wrote 'I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward' (Phil 3:14 NIV)

content.title: A Word to young leaders (2)
content.introtext:
Joshua ordered the officers of the people.

Joshua 1:10 NIV
There's more wisdom for us today in this story about the people of Israel entering the Promised Land. In verse 10 God says to Israel's leaders: 'Help your brothers' (Joshua 1:14 NIV). In this statement we see an early example of what we now know from the life of Jesus to be a lifestyle of serving. At the end of every day we should each ask ourselves, 'Who got what out of the choices I made today?' If the answer is 'I got lots, God got a bit and everybody else got zip' then you aren't on the path to leadership in the kingdom of God. Jesus put it like this, 'If you want to be great, you must be the servant of all the others.' (Mark 10:43 CEV). Leadership boffin John Maxwell writes, '...live by these four simple words: add value to others. That philosophy will take you far. All talented people have a choice to make: to do their own thing and get all the credit or do the team thing and share it. My observation is that not only do talented people accomplish more when working with others but they are also more fulfilled than those who go it alone.' So here's the deal: you're only qualified to enjoy the perks of leadership when you're willing to embrace the principles of leadership, which means putting other people first.

content.title: A Word to young leaders (1)
content.introtext:
Joshua ordered the officers of the people.

Joshua 1:10 NIV
Before Israel entered the Promised Land God gave two important instructions to its leaders: 1) 'Cross over ahead of your brothers' (Joshua 1:14 NIV). If God has called you to lead, stand up and get on with it. Believing in yourself and your mission will take you further than just working harder or even working smarter. All personal breakthroughs begin with a change in your beliefs. What you believe deep down determines what you expect, and what you expect determines how you will act. In the long run, a belief is more than just an idea you possess, it's an idea that possesses you! 2) 'Be strong and courageous' (Joshua 1:6). Your life will expand or shrink as a result of the courage you display. If you're willing to take risks you'll go further than those who follow the safe path. A great thinker in the twentieth century wrote: 'The moment you resolve to take hold of life with all your might and make the most of yourself at any cost, to sacrifice all lesser ambitions to your one great aim, to cut loose from everything that interferes with that aim... you set in motion the forces implanted within you for your own development. Live up to your resolve, work at what God meant you to work at for the perfecting of His plan, and you will be invincible. No power on earth can hold you back...'

content.title: Watch your mouth!
content.introtext:
the tongue is a flame of fire.

James 3:6 NLT
One day a girl visited her gran, the only person in the world she could really talk to. Gran always listened and gave the most amazing advice. The girl was upset because she'd been spreading rumours about all sorts of people in her class and had been found out. Nobody wanted to be her friend any more. 'How can I make things right?' she asked. Gran replied, 'Take that box of tissues and drop one on the doorstep of each person you've criticised.' The girl grabbed the box and ran out to do it. Later that afternoon she came back saying, 'Is that all?' 'No,' said Gran. 'Now go, pick up them all up and bring them back to me.' The next day, the girl returned to her gran's house, but without a single tissue: 'The wind blew them all away,' she said. After a long silence her gran said, 'That's how it is with words; they're easily spoken, but you can never take them back again.' It was a lesson that the girl never forgot. Words can cut deep scars on people's emotions. That's why God takes the sins of the tongue so seriously that He devotes an entire chapter of the Bible to the subject. Read James 3 and let it sink in to your heart. Remember, 'the tongue is a flame of fire' and you don't wanna get burnt!

content.title: Living well
content.introtext:
I am sending you.

John 20:21 NIV
Gladys Aylward was just an ordinary young woman who did what she believed God called her to do. She'd read the Scripture, 'If you spend yourselves on behalf of the hungry and satisfy the needs of the oppressed...The Lord will guide you always; he will satisfy your needs' (Isaiah 58:10-11 NIV). In 1930 she sailed to China where she opened a home for orphaned children who'd been left to starve or wander the streets. She devoted her life to becoming a mother to each of them. When the Japanese invaded China in 1938 Gladys was forced to flee to the mountains with over 100 children to care for. Through an epic journey of extreme difficulty and danger she brought the children to safety. Years later when she was publicly honoured, she explained her amazing work like this: 'I did not choose this. I was led into it by God.' Jesus said, 'As the Father has sent me, I am sending you' (John 20:21 NIV). The mission Jesus had while on earth, the mission Gladys got properly stuck into, is your mission too. William James said, 'The best use of life is to spend it for something that outlasts it.' Only the Kingdom of God is going to last; everything else will eventually fall apart. To fulfil your purpose here on earth is to have lived well. You wanna live well don't you?

content.title: Discovering yourself
content.introtext:
It's in Christ that we find out who we are.

Ephesians 1:11 TM
One day a boy climbing in the mountains found an eagle's nest with an egg in it. He took it back to his dad's farm and put it under a hen along with her other eggs. When the eagle hatched it learned chicken behaviour and scratched around in the yard with the other little chicks. It didn't know any better. Sometimes it felt strange stirrings within itself but didn't know what to do with them, so it just kept on acting like a chicken. Some months later a majestic adult eagle flew over the chicken yard and the eagle looked up and saw him. In that moment the chicken realised he wanted to be like that eagle, to fly high, to go to the mountain peaks he saw in the distance. As he spread his wings he suddenly understood that he was like that eagle. Though he'd never flown before, he possessed the instinct and capabilities. At first he flew unsteadily, then with greater power and control. Finally as he soared he knew he'd discovered his true self; the creature God made him to be. This is what Paul had in mind when he wrote, 'It's in Christ that we find out who we are and what we are living for.' You were made by God and for God. Until you understand that, you won't discover your true self!

content.title: Straplines
content.introtext:
I came to give life...life in all its fullness.

John 10:10 NCV
Just do it. It's the real thing. I'm loving it! We live in a world of straplines. But what was the original strapline? Well if you look in Genesis chapter 1 you might say, It's all good! Sadly another strapline soon appears on the scene, You will be like God. This is the first lie ever recorded, it's the one the used by the serpent to con Eve into thinking her and her husband could make up their own set of rules to live by. And you know, he's still pushing the same line. You hear it in comments like: "It's OK to do what you like as long as it doesn't hurt anyone." But we all know that in reality the kind of actions that flow from that mindset do end up hurting people - mostly the people who are living by that strapline. And what about the classic "Try anything once." Well where is a statement like that gonna get you? OK, if your parents wrapped you up in cotton wool for the first 15 years of your life maybe you're feeling like you wanna live a bit but does that mean "Anything goes?" It's not rocket science to work out where you'll end up with that life strapline. So if you really want a strapline for life why not try this one for size, 'I came to give life?life in all its fullness'.

content.title: Jesus believes in you!
content.introtext:
Follow me, and I will make you...

Matthew 4:19 KJV
Jesus doesn't invite us to follow Him because we believe in Him. He invites us to follow Him because He believes in us! He says, 'Follow me and I will make you...' He knows what we can become when His grace touches our lives. Matthew, a Jew, collected taxes for the Romans who enslaved his people. That made him a double-crosser and a back-stabber, in other words he was lower than scum. Even so, Jesus knew there was potential for goodness and greatness in him. Years later Matthew would end up writing the first book in the New Testament. And if you know anything about the bible you'll know that this selection wasn't a one-off, Jesus had a habit of choosing the sort of people everyone else would leave on the sub bench. One of the mad things about the 12 guys Jesus chose to be his 'inner circle' is that after three years of being around His miracles and messages, some still had questions and doubts. But did he give up on them? No, he just shared with them this prayer, 'I will ask the Father to send you the Holy Spirit who will help you and always be with you' (John 14:16 CEV). He knew there would never be a day when they wouldn't need heaven's help. The amazing thing is that the prayer he prayed includes you too - yes you - Jesus believes in you!

content.title: A fear-free life
content.introtext:
That by his death he might...free those who...were held in slavery by their fear of death.

Hebrews 2:14-15 NIV
If you live life by your own set of rules you'd better be ready for the consequences. The what? Consequences. It's a word you won't hear very much on T4. What it means is that if you choose to act in a certain way then certain things are gonna happen as a result. If you go out and get drunk then you'll wake up in the morning with a banging head - or worse! The thing about being young is that many of the choices you make now don't seem to have any consequences - you're invincible! WRONG. You're just storing up all kinds of problems that will catch you up in years to come. Living the Jesus way ensures that you are storing up only blessings, not consequences, for the future. The original and ultimate consequence is death. This has been the case ever since the first humans chose to turn their backs on God and live life their way instead. Because of this loads of people live in fear that death is the end and there is no way to escape it. The Bible breaks this fear when it describes what Jesus achieved for us on the cross: 'Only by dying could he break ...the power of death...[and] set free all who have lived their lives as slaves to the fear of dying' (Hebrews 2:14-15 NLT). So live the Jesus way today - live fear free.

content.title: Hit the delete button
content.introtext:
Forgiving one another...as God...has forgiven you.

Ephesians 4:32 NLT
What's the worst thing you've ever done? Did you get caught? Well imagine if whatever it was you did was tattooed on your forehead for everyone to see. Not nice thoughts are they... quick, let's do some happy imagining instead! Well imagine you're walking down the busy high street in your hometown, and everyone's giving you evil looks and tut-tutting. Suddenly, a guy steps out in front of you and looks you right in the eye. He has the strangest expression on his face - it's not the judgemental look everyone else gives you - it's sort of, a smile. He breaks your stunned silence with a few softly spoken words, "Can I help you?" "Please, I want it to be gone," you reply shakily. He reaches into one of his deep coat pockets and pulls out a little make-up mirror and holds it up to your face. The writing's disappeared! How do you feel now? That story isn't about God being soft on sin. His love won't let you off - but His love won't let you go either. 'Nothing can separate us from the love of God' (Romans 8:38-39). As soon as you admit your issues to Jesus and express to him how much you truly want to change he just goes right ahead and hits the delete button on all that stuff. It's called forgiveness and it's the best thing in the whole world!

content.title: Praise your way through (2)
content.introtext:
'The joy of the Lord is your strength'

Nehemiah 8:10
Prisons in Bible times were miserable places - especially if you'd just taken a beating before being thrown inside. Amazingly though, 'Paul and Silas were praying and singing praises to God, while the other prisoners listened.' When you're down and depressed there is no way your emotions want to praise God so like these guys you have to make a faith-decision to do it anyway - soon enough your feelings will have to come in line because faith is stronger than emotion. 'Suddenly a strong earthquake shook the jail to its foundations. The doors opened, and the chains fell from all the prisoners.' (Acts 16:25-26 CEV). Just like the story of the Old Testament king yesterday it was the praise that led to the breakthrough! And it can happen for you too. If you want to shake things up, see doors open and chains break, begin to praise God in the face of all the kak life throws your way! This sort of praise isn't about sweet ballads to a gently strummed guitar. It's a screaming electric feedback connection amplified between the airwaves of earth and heaven. It's a broadband channel through which God blasts in to save your situation from the inside out. So if you're feeling tired and battered today make a faith-decision based on what Nehemiah says, 'The joy of the Lord is your strength' (Nehemiah 8:10).

content.title: Praise your way through (1)
content.introtext:
As soon as they began singing, the LORD confused the enemy camp.

2 Chronicles 20:22 CEV
There's no law that says praising God is reserved for church on Sunday. Worship is a lifestyle: at work, at school, at home, in the shower... anywhere you can imagine! Praise (telling God how great he is) brings God's reality right into our situation. The guy who wrote all those Psalms that wedge in the middle of your bible said, 'I bless God every chance I get; my lungs expand with his praise' (Psalm 34:1 TM). Praise is an expression of faith; it's a declaration that God's in control. If we rewind back to the Old Testament there's a story (in 2 Chronicles 20) about a king who sent a worship band to a battle in front of his army - was he bonkers? Maybe, but it worked! As they went forward praising God, 'the LORD confused the enemy camp? and the enemy was defeated. Here's another thing - praise isn't something you do just when you feel like it. The Bible says we're to 'offer to God a sacrifice of praise' (Hebrews 13:15 NIV). God's not daft - He knows the difference between songs sung on autopilot and the true adoration of a loving child. Anybody can praise God 'in the land that is plentiful' but the test is praising Him 'though I walk through the wilderness'. Matt Redman wrote a superb worship song all about that - but can you sing it and mean it?

content.title: Get off the guilt train!
content.introtext:
Those...in Christ...are not judged guilty.

ROMANS 8:1 NCV
The Bible says, 'We all fall short of God's...standard' (Romans 3:23 NLT). Even the most amazing Christians you know struggle with weaknesses, some huge ones probably! We all screw up and mess up and generally do things every minute that we know we shouldn't. But if you live in a giant pit of guilt you're just punishing yourself which is not how you're supposed to be living! Becoming a Christian and giving your life to Jesus doesn't mean you become perfect. You will still blow it day after day. Even Paul, who had 'the desire to do...good,' admits that sometimes he couldn't 'carry it out' (Romans 7:18 NIV). The good news of the Gospel means that whenever you're 'in Christ... [you're] not judged guilty'. You do, however, need to say sorry and ask to be forgiven! This also means if you've got things to put right, you need to do that too. Sometimes saying sorry to God isn't enough, you have to say sorry to people and admit to them what you've been up to. But remember, this automatic forgiveness deal is not an excuse to sin. Your folks will forgive you for most things but is this a reason to steal out of your mum's purse? Because she will forgive you? Of course not. We do our best out of love. Grace is there for when our best just isn't good enough.

content.title: Follow the leader
content.introtext:
One of you says, "I follow Paul"; another, "I follow Apollos"; another, "I follow Cephas "; still another, "I follow Christ."

1 Corinthians 1:12 NIV
Back in the early church Paul had to tackle an issue with people saying they were following different leaders. While the point is that everyone should have been following Jesus, it's interesting to look at these different leaders. You see Paul was a strange chap. He would have looked pretty ugly due to all his beatings and was a pretty dull preacher (one guy fell asleep during a sermon, fell out the window and died!) but he wrote cracking letters and did some seriously crazy stuff! Apollos on the other hand was a real clever guy who was known to preach a fantastic sermon. Cephas (Peter), would have been everyone's friend. We can see from some of the daft things he said to Jesus he was probably funny to be around and would've been life and soul of the party; a loving, friendly, fun bloke who everyone wanted to be mates with. These three guys would have been completely different in looks, age, and most importantly personality type. Many people look at big leaders and think 'they're so different to me; I could never be like that'. But listen, personality type has nothing to do with it! Paul, Apollos and Peter couldn't be more different but what they all had in common was a passionate love for Jesus, desperation to be used and the guts to stand up and make their life count. That's what you need too.

content.title: Learn to work with others (3)
content.introtext:
My co-workers in the ministry.

ROMANS 16:3 NLT
God works with people who know how to work with people! Using people, especially nice people, is way too easy to do. Lots of people find themselves being totally overworked and underpaid in their jobs and others just feel a bit used by even their friends at times. We could all argue that we're being used all the time; 'she's just using me for someone to go shopping with', or 'he's just using me to talk to'. Make sure that you value people and don't just use them. Paul dedicates an entire chapter to people he valued: 'Give my greetings to Priscilla and Aquila, my co-workers in the ministry...In fact, they once risked their lives for me. I am thankful to them, and so are all the Gentile churches...Greet my dear friend Epenetus. He was the first person from the province of Asia to become a follower of Christ. Give my greetings to Mary, who has worked so hard for your benefit. Greet Andronicus and Junia, my fellow Jews, who were in prison with me. They are highly respected among the apostles and became followers of Christ before I did. Greet Ampliatus, my dear friend in the Lord. Greet Urbanus, our co-worker in Christ, and my dear friend Stachys. Greet Apellas, a good man whom Christ approves...and all the believers who meet with them' (Romans 16:3-15 NLT). Bottom line; open up, reach out, sharpen your people skills!

content.title: Learn to work with others (2)
content.introtext:
We rebuilt the wall.

NEHEMIAH 4:6 NIV
When Nehemiah talks about himself, he talks openly and honestly about crying over the ruins of Jerusalem, praying, and the days when he wondered how he'd survive. But when his dream of re-building the wall of Jerusalem happened in a record 52 days, he gives the credit to others. 'We rebuilt the wall...for the people worked with all their heart.' There's no limit to what can be done when nobody cares who gets the credit. U2 front man Bono has become a world leader in speaking up for the helpless and poor. Bono has learned that to make any difference, you have to partner with others.
