He has met with heads of state, economists, industry leaders, celebrities; anyone who has the potential to help the people he's trying to reach. Rock stars are usually seen as self-absorbed, isolated, and indifferent to others. It's the reason many music groups don't stay together. Bono comments: '...people are so lost in themselves and the demands of their own life, that it's very hard to be in a band...people want to be lords of their own domain. I mean, everybody, as they get older...rids the room of argument. You see it in your family, you see it with your friends. They get a smaller and smaller circle of people around them who agree with them. And life ends up with a dull sweetness.' Learn to work with others.

content.title: Learn to work with others (1)
content.introtext:
The burden is too heavy for me.

NUMBERS 11:14 NIV
Working with other people can be a real blessing, or it can be an absolute pain in the neck! We're all made differently and we each have personalities that are as different as the colours in a kiddies' crayon set. Some colours will work beautifully together and some will just clash horribly. When we're supposed to work closely with a colour that just doesn't go, your first instinct is to run away, refuse to do it, and to be horrible to them. Maybe it's a kid at school you have to do a project with, or the know-it-all at work you just can't stand. The annoying thing is that you can't do everything yourself. As great as you think you are, it's guaranteed that the other person or people can bring something that you're missing. What you need is the grace and patience to find it! Working with others will make you so much stronger than trying to get the glory and do it all alone, even when they're O so annoying! Imagine a rainbow. It goes right through the spectrum of colours, yet the colours don't clash, it's beautiful! Every one is equal, included and has something to bring and the result is spectacular. So if you have a clash today, pray for grace and ask God to help you figure out their true colour.

content.title: The mystery man
content.introtext:
And we... are bring transformed into His likeness...

2 CORINTHIANS 3:18
Ever thought about what kind of guy Jesus was? We have our 'flowing dress and golden hair' view of course but what do you think He was actually like? We know He wasn't very tall (men weren't at that time) and wasn't very fit (Bible says people didn't like him for his looks), but something about Him meant that He could say to people 'follow me' and they dropped everything and did! Jesus was no wuss. He was scared of no one and had a sack full of killer putdowns for the bunch of guys were always trying to find a reason to kill Him. He always had loads of mates so He was probably quite a laugh yet He loved everyone, so must have had a really weird gentle side too. He didn't care what anyone thought of Him, only what God thought and never did anything just for the sake of popularity. When we look at Jesus we can see what God is like because He was God's Son. But more importantly we can see what we can be like, because He was also Mary's Son and very human. It's scary to think we could be like Jesus, most of us couldn't feel farther from it yet every time we're challenged by God He is changing us to be more like Jesus. Up for the challenge?

content.title: Stop worrying!
content.introtext:
It begins and ends with faith...those who are right with God...live by faith.

ROMANS 1:17 NCV
Some people worry about the strangest things. A man who claimed he'd swallowed a horse was sent to a psychiatrist who recommended having an operation for the removal of the horse. The surgeon agreed to bring a horse into the operating room so that when the man woke up he'd know the operation was a success. But after the operation the man opened his eyes and announced, 'That's the wrong horse. It's white. The one I swallowed was black!' Too much worry and not enough reality; it's why Jesus had loads to say about worry. Understand this. Worry: a) wastes your time and energy. Jesus said, 'Who of you by worrying can add a single hour to his life?' (Matthew 6:27 NIV). It's a medically proven fact that worry can shorten your life b) stops you from enjoying what you have. You worry about things you should be trusting God with cc) makes you forget God's promises. 'If God didn't hesitate to put everything on the line...by sending his...Son, is there anything else he wouldn't...do for us?' (Romans 8:32 TM). God knows your needs and your problems, so don't just ignore them hoping they will go away, but also don't worry. There's a healthy balance that involves seeing the concerns and giving them carefully to God. So today stop worrying and trust God.

content.title: You have access to God
content.introtext:
Let's walk right up to him and get what he is so ready to give.

HEBREWS 4:16 TM
Are you finding prayer hard work? Maybe you're not really hearing from God or you're just not 'feeling it'. Maybe God doesn't seem to be answering your prayers at all so it all just seems a bit pointless. NEWSFLASH: It's not about you! God is not Santa, a jolly chap waiting to give you everything you ask as long as you've been good. God is the great I Am, Jesus died a gruesome death, for you! He is worthy of all your praise, your time, your prayer, everything you can give Him whether you feel the tingle or not! At the same time, God is loving and does actually want to have a relationship with you. This means that when you come to Him He does listen and He does want to draw close to you. If your prayer times involve a lot of mind-wandering and sleeping, try focusing on God, not yourself. Worship Him, praise Him, and refuse to let go. He wants to take you right into His throne-room (that's the room where He's on His throne!) and once you're in God's presence like that, you won't be falling asleep! It's there that you will learn God's voice and understand who it is you're dealing with. God wants to bless you, He also wants to challenge, shape and transform you. This is going to be hard and takes discipline, but it's so worth it!

content.title: Roots of rejection
content.introtext:
Rooted deep...and founded securely on [God's] love.

EPHESIANS 3:17 AMP
Many things can make us feel rejected, even when we're not really! It may be a friend that's gone off with someone else, a relationship that's just ended or even a parent that you've convinced yourself doesn't want you. The truth is that it's unlikely that any of these are actually down to someone rejecting you. It may be that in the long run God is actually saving and protecting you from a bad relationship or if it's your parent, there's guaranteed to be a whole load of stuff going on; none of which is that they just don't want you! If your roots are securely in God, the rejections we face all around us can't affect us in the same way. If you know you're 100% loved, welcomed, wanted and cared for by the Almighty Creator of the Universe, does it really matter that you didn't get picked for the footie team? As humans we love self-pity. It's almost fun and comforting to wallow and feel sorry for ourselves. We want others to wallow with us, say nice things and get drawn into a slanging match about people we don't like. This is bad! This is a time to dig your roots in deep, look over your own pain to the truth of the situation and what God thinks about it, and you. Don't get caught up in self-pity!

content.title: 'Nevertheless...'
content.introtext:
Nevertheless David took the stronghold of Zion.

2 SAMUEL 5:7 NKJV
In 1000 BC David had a look at Jerusalem. It was a monster of a fortress (think of Helmsdeep in Lord of the Rings) and the old enemy were so cocky they even shouted 'You'll never get in here...Even the blind and lame could keep you out!' (2 Samuel 5:6 NLT). The walls were high and situation looked hopeless but did that stop David? Not in the slightest. The Bible says 'Nevertheless David took the stronghold...dwelt in [it]...and called it the City of David.' We all have areas of our life where the fight just looks too hopeless - the walls are too big and we're so small! Satan tells us we can't do it and we believe him. It might be that habit you just can't quit, the attitude you can't shake, the way you feel every single time you look in that mirror... we just don't feel good enough. But, your battles (which in the Bible are called strongholds) mean nothing to God. When the enemy says, 'You're stuck, you'll never get out,' the Bible says His 'mighty weapons...knock down the devil's strongholds' (2 Corinthians 10:4 TLB). To be like David you must do two things. Listen to the right voice; the one telling you it is possible to win and look for solutions. David won because he didn't stare at the walls, he looked for the tunnels.

content.title: The cure for loneliness
content.introtext:
Turn to me and be gracious...for I am lonely.

PSALM 25:16 NIV
One of the most awful feelings in life is that of loneliness. No matter who you are, where you live or even how many friends you have, everyone goes through times of feeling lonely. Sometimes there is a good reason and but other times there's no reason, you just do. Jesus knew what it was to feel lonely. Imagine going through life with the closeness of God as your Father, only to be abandoned as you hang on the cross; the time when you need Him most. In those moments Jesus knew what it was to feel totally abandoned and it was probably the loneliest moment anyone has ever endured; after all, even in our loneliest times God has never left our side. It doesn't always feel like it and you can't always see it at the time but looking back it's obvious. These times are some of the easiest for sin to creep in, a little peek at dodgy web sites or to drown your sorrows with a few sneaky drinks. Satan will tell you that these sorts of things will bring you comfort, make you feel better, or even that you deserve a little pleasure! But it's all lies. These are the times you need to draw closest to God. He's promised to never leave or abandon you and the lonely times can be where your strength comes from.

content.title: The Oasis
content.introtext:
Those who remain in me and I in them, will bear much fruit.

JOHN 15:5 NLT
Why is it, that even when we know what's best for us, we just don't do it? Just above the Himalayan mountains in Tibet there are miles of barren wasteland. There's nothing on this wasteland. It's brown, dry, dusty, and flat with no features, no plants, no rainfall, no rocks, not even the odd bit of anything to make it interesting. Nothing lives there, apart from the Wild Ass. Every day these donkeys trek miles and miles to an oasis, a beautiful lake of fresh crystal blue water surrounded by green grass and plants. They spend a few hours grazing here, eating, drinking, before wandering back to the baron, brown nothingness. Scientists have been baffled for years. Why don't these stupid donkeys just live at the oasis? There appears to be no reason for it, they just live in the dust, always have done, always will do. As dumb as these animals sound, so often we do the same! We know God's goodness, we've tasted the life-giving water, we've sampled His amazing grace and His unending, unfailing love for us. We know how good it is to know Him, to speak to Him, to worship Him, yet time and time again we wander back to our miserable sinful lives. Why don't we just live at the oasis? Jesus said we should remain in Him so if you're in the dust today, get back to the oasis!

content.title: Sometimes it's wise to compromise
content.introtext:
Honour one another above yourselves.

ROMANS 12:10 NIV
Compromise is agreeing to change your viewpoint to meet someone else half way. It sounds awful, but it's not always bad. Obviously there are some issues that the Bible talks about that you can't compromise on (for example it's never OK to steal), but sometimes it's wise to compromise. Without compromise arguments can't be settled. If two people are both completely stubborn and refuse to budge on a subject, you just won't get anywhere! Compromising is not about being weak; in fact sometimes it takes more strength to agree to a compromise! For example, if mum wants you in at 9 and you think midnight is more reasonable, it probably wouldn't hurt either of you to agree to 10.30! Are we saying this is easy? Or free from risk? Or that it comes naturally? No. It's much easier (and safer) to stand your ground and believe that your way is the right way. But if you do that through life, you end up alone, bitter and angry that no one wants to listen to the person with all the answers! Don't be so proud that you can't see that maybe you're wrong. And if it's not an issue of right and wrong but of opinion, does it really matter so much that it's worth falling out over? No. Learn to understand when a bit of compromise is OK.

content.title: Don't settle for a "B"
content.introtext:
I can do everything through him who gives me strength.

PHILLIPPIANS 4:13 NIV
There's a story of a professor who stood before his class of 30 senior molecular biology students. Before the final exam he said, 'I have been privileged to be your instructor this semester, and I know how hard you have worked to prepare for this test. Because I am confident that you know this material, I am prepared to offer an automatic B to anyone who opts to skip taking the final exam.' A number of students jumped up from their desks, thanking the professor for the lifeline he had thrown them and they left. The teacher then handed out the final exam, which was just two sentences. It read: 'Congratulations, you have just received an A in this class. Keep believing in yourself.' The Apostle Paul experienced more headaches and heartaches in a month than most of us will see in a lifetime. Yet he wrote, 'I can do everything through him who gives me strength.' Too many people are willing to settle for average. They have enough money to be comfortable, a nice partner they can put up with, an easy church where they can just enjoy the service, chat with other comfortable friends and go home. With Christ in you not much is easy but anything is possible! Why would you settle for a B when God can give you a seriously more exciting A?

content.title: Don't miss the boat!
content.introtext:
Then he got into the boat and his disciples followed him.

MATTHEW 8:23 NIV
There are moments, especially as a young person when you have to make life-changing choices. One day Jesus invited two people to join His team, but they both had their reasons for putting it off. One had a funeral to attend, another wanted to go home to explain his decision. That's the last we hear of them. Matthew records, 'Then [Jesus] got into the boat and his disciples followed him.' They had missed the boat! You'll never get anywhere if you don't make decisions because you're scared or you can't decide or even because you can't be bothered. In the 1870s two men worked really hard on the idea of transmitting sound down a wire. Amazingly on exactly the same day both Alexander Graham Bell and Elisha Gray planned to go to the patent office to file their idea. Unfortunately for Elisha Gray, despite the fact that he had the idea first, he was busy and sent someone in his place who got there an hour after Alexander Graham Bell. Alexander took credit for the invention of the telephone, and got very rich, and Elisha Gray missed out. If you get a God-given opportunity to do something, no matter how scary it is or how out of your depth you may feel, take it. Don't hang around, don't put it off, trust God and don't miss the boat!

content.title: The spirit of Caleb
content.introtext:
My servant Caleb has a different spirit.

NUMBERS 14:24 NIV
Caleb wasn't into 'safe living.' As a young man he came back from the Promised Land, stood with the minority and announced, 'With God on our side we'll take it!' At 85, he was still slaying giants and claiming mountains. That's because he had 'a different spirit'. Safe living is secure and straight forward but in many ways it's not really living, in fact it's quite dull! Most 'safe-livers' will look back in years and wish they'd gone for it, taken a risk and wondered what they could have done. When you're young, lots of people will tell you that you can't do all sorts of things. Maybe your IQ doesn't match your dreams or your skills don't quite match your passion. But so what? If God's called you or told you to do something, he'll give you the tools you need to do the job! Moses was given some huge jobs to do and most people would have said he was insane; he couldn't even speak properly! He went to do it anyway and God gave him Aaron to do the talking. If your mates or even your folks or church leaders tell you you're not good enough, see what God has to say. If God says yes then His opinion is the only one that counts. Would you rather try and fail, or not try at all?

content.title: Walking in humility
content.introtext:
Walk...With all lowliness and meekness.

EPHESIANS 4:1-2
When most of us think of what we would like to become, there's normally a real Catch 22. We dream of being loved, adored and famous on the outside but of course we're wise, humble and totally brilliant on the inside. To get loved, adored and famous we need to be wise, humble and brilliant first. But, if we get there then we probably won't want to be loved, adored and famous 'cos we'll know what we're really like and what we deserve! Think carefully about the words 'walking with God.' Whose company are you in? God's! Can you think of a higher calling? Yet, the higher your calling, the lower you must become in your own eyes. That doesn't mean thinking you're rubbish, it simply means we need to understand just how amazing, mighty and awesome God really is. The more we see God for whom He really is, the more we realise we're so not God! When the apostle John saw Jesus standing in the midst of the seven churches, he wrote, 'And when I saw him, I fell at his feet as dead' (Revelation 1:17). Those who big up themselves are humbled by the Lord. Those who humble themselves before the Lord are the ones God raises up. Humility doesn't mean thinking less of yourself, it just means thinking of yourself less.

content.title: Taking responsibility (5)
content.introtext:
I have a great sense of obligation.

ROMANS 1:14 NLT
Taking responsibility means giving back what was given to you. Reading this you may be thinking of all the things you have; a great family, a nice home, plenty to eat. On the other hand you may think of things you're missing; maybe a parent, enough money or a good church. The truth is if you're reading this as a Christian today, you have everything you need in Jesus. You've been saved from death, you're loved and you have a great hope and a future ahead of you. Everything you have comes from God, and still belongs to Him. When we try to keep what we have for ourselves, that's called being Self-serving. Self-serving people think of their talents and resources as something they own and try to keep these things for themselves. Serving people understand that all they have comes from God and that they have a responsibility to use it in the best way possible. If someone came and handed you a £50 note your first reaction would not be to say 'thank you' but 'what do you want me to do with it'? All we have comes from God but we often forget to even say thank you, let alone ask what we should do with it! Why not make a list of all you have; resources, skills, abilities and ask God today, 'what do you want me to do with it'?

content.title: Taking responsibility (4)
content.introtext:
Each of us will give an account of himself to God.

ROMANS 14:12 NIV
The newspaper editor sent a reporter to cover a sports game. He returned to the paper with no report. 'What's the story?' asked the editor. 'There is none,' replied the reporter. 'What? And why not?' 'Because there was no game,' replied the reporter. 'No game? What happened?' quizzed the editor. 'The stadium collapsed.' Unable to believe what he was hearing the editor asked, 'Then where's the report on its collapse?' After an awkward silence the reporter replied, 'That wasn't my assignment, sir.' Needless to say, that was the end of his career. The Bible says, 'Each of us will give an account of himself to God.' What does that mean? It means you have to pretty much explain yourself to the almighty creator of the universe! He's going to ask how you got on with the job he gave you and let's face it, any excuses you try to come up with that day are going to sound pretty lame! God has given you a great assignment, an important role in his plan for saving the world he loves so much. Are you going to be a wally like the reporter who gets to the end and has nothing to show? Or are you going to use your brain so when you give your account, you can be proud that you did the best you can do?

content.title: Taking responsibility (3)
content.introtext:
Now, a person who is put in charge as a manager must be faithful.

1 CORINTHIANS 4:2 NLT
If you want to be successful you have to take responsibility. Most people have big dreams of great things they'd like to achieve but sadly lots of people won't come close to achieving their dreams. Whether your dream is to run or own a business, become a doctor or lawyer, write great music, go into outer space or do one of another million great things, to achieve it you must take responsibility for your own life. Everyone has dreams; some people even have a plan to make their dreams happen. But unless you put the plan into action, your dreams will stay just that; dreams! You can think about them, write about them and even talk about them with everyone you meet, but if you're dream is to be a famous author, you better get writing! If you want to be an athlete, you better get training. Your dreams won't just happen when you reach a certain age. If you want to be at a certain place by the time you are 25, you had better start down that path now. Get some focus, be disciplined and understand the need to take responsibility. If you keep God right at the centre of all you want to do and don't get distracted with other things along the way then your dreams can become a reality. Why not ask God today to help you as you take responsibility for your future?

content.title: Taking responsibility (2)
content.introtext:
A man reaps what he sows.

GALATIANS 6:7 NIV
In 2002, Edward Brewer sued Providence Hospital for $2 million. He claimed that the hospital was negligent because it had not prevented him from raping one of its patients. We live in such a bizarre blame culture that in this case it wasn't even the female rape victim blaming the hospital security for this awful incident, it was the rapist. Talk about not taking responsibility for your own actions! Fortunately in this case the judge had a bit more sense and ruled that any damage Brewer suffered due to his crime was his own responsibility not the hospitals fault! Although it seems crazy, this is an extreme example of what we can do everyday. If we break something we claim the item wasn't strong enough, we burn something and blame the cooking time on the packet. Late for school? Bus's fault. Forgot homework? Mum's fault for not waking you up in time. News flash: Being young does not give you the right to blame everyone else for everything. If your uniform isn't clean, clean it. Phone credit's run out? Stop texting nonsense. Late for school? Set an alarm and stop relying on people to drag you out of bed. There comes a point when you can't keep blaming other people and that point is not when you've grown up or when you're a parent, it's right now.

content.title: Taking responsibility (1)
content.introtext:
Much is required from those to whom much is given.

LUKE 12:48 TLB
Responsibility is a word many of us don't like. When you're young, free and single often the last thing you want is a bunch of stuff you HAVE to do, places you HAVE to go and things you HAVE to face up to. You want to do WHAT you want, go Where you want and not have to give a second thought to anyone else! But guess what, life's not like that. Like it or not, you do have responsibilities. You're responsible for your own behaviour, for your language, for your school work, for making the right decisions, for the way you treat people, and that's just a few examples! When you have responsibilities, all the excuses in the world won't let you off the hook. You can blame others and shout and get mad and refuse to accept responsibility all you want, it won't make the smallest difference. Your problem isn't your friends, or your job, or your girlfriend, or your parents or even the government!. Be honest, your biggest challenge in life is you. You may feel hard done by or picked on but if your life's not going the way you want it to, you are responsible for changing it, and God will help you if you turn to Him. But you must want to change, decide to change, and work each day toward that end.

content.title: What's that you say?
content.introtext:
Speak, Lord, for your servant is listening.

1 SAMUEL 3:9 NIV
God had big plans for Sam, he would become a great priest who would hear from God and help the Jews understand how to live as God's people. But right now Sam is a young lad, and he hears someone calling his name so He thinks it's the old priest, his boss, Eli shouting out for some help. The Bible says: Eli said, 'Son, I didn't call you. Go back to bed' (1 Samuel 3:7). This all happened before Samuel knew God for himself. It was before the revelation of God had been given to him personally. After this happens a few times, Eli cottons on and tells Sam to keep listening to the voice, because it's God Himself who is trying to get Sam's attention. Next time Sam was ready to listen and do whatever God said. Jesus said: 'My sheep listen to my voice; I know them and they follow me'. He also said 'The sheep follow him because they know his voice (John 10). Learning to recognize God's voice doesn't just happen overnight, because He speaks to us at different times, in different settings and in different ways. Through the Bible, a talk, a mate, a dream...be ready to hear from Him. He wants YOU to know Him personally, to know Him for yourself. Oh yeah, when you hear Him get ready to obey!

content.title: Looking good
content.introtext:
His Spirit in your inner being.

EPHESIANS 3:16
You've seen the Ads on TV, 'Because you're worth it', 'The Lynx effect', and all that. These kinds of companies spend billions trying to get us to decorate a shell that's in a losing battle with Mother Nature and Father Time, and we can fall for it too. In our rush to create what we think will attract others, we spray, we squirt, we dye, we gel, we wax and maybe succeed in turning a head or two, but it has zero ability to win a heart or mind. No amount of diets or press-ups will help, and neither will being seen in the right place with the right people. If you want to earn people's trust, respect, and real friendship you'll have to start sorting out the inside not the outside. That's not an excuse to totally let go! It's important to look after the body God gave you, but when you become obsessed with your 'looks' alone, you become shallow and superficial. Others will quickly lose interest because they discover that although the box you came in is beautifully wrapped it's empty! The only real appeal we have is 'His Spirit in your inner being'; illumination on the inside, buzzing in your body, fizzing in your physique. That's what ultimately wins hearts and attracts the right people to you, for the right purpose, at the right time.

content.title: No fear
content.introtext:
When I am afraid, I will trust in you.

PSALM 56:3 NIV
There's a company called 'NO FEAR' that makes a packet selling T-shirts to people who are into dangerous sports; or people who are trying to pretend they're into dangerous sports! Well we all know that just getting out of bed in the morning can be a risky business (especially if you're on the top bunk) so how do we live and enjoy our lives fully without being a prisoner to fear? In one of his poems David said, 'When I am afraid I put my trust in you'. Some people want a cast iron guarantee that everything will go according to plan, before they step out to do anything new. More often than not progress involves risk; and often risk involves fear and fear distorts your view of God. It tells you you're not in safe hands; that He's not big enough to take care of you. DON'T LISTEN! You need to walk through your fears to discover what God has for you on the other side? If you give in to fear now you'll just end up in a comfy chair vegging in front of your telly wondering, 'What could have happened, if only I'd trusted God more?' ONE MORE TIME; 'When I am afraid I put my trust in you'. So get moving! Don't let the voice of fear rob you of your destiny!!

content.title: Now you see me - now you don't
content.introtext:
Blessed are those who have not seen and yet have believed.

JOHN 20:29 (NIV)
We read about Jesus in the Bible but because we've never seen Him here on earth our minds can play tricks on us or our mates can make fun of us saying, 'Doh! You think Jesus is alive?!? You think the Hoooly Spirit talks to you?!?' Well, think about this for a minute before you give in to that stuff 'how much of this life is actually made up of things you can see?' Think about it. Where are your friends right now? Can you see them? Do you start to doubt that they exist when you can't see them? When your mum shouts from the bottom of the stairs that your tea's ready do you get all spooked and start thinking that you're hearing voices in your head just because you can't see her but you can hear her voice? Don't be daft! Then there is the air you are breathing right now or what about the feelings you have, and the memories; all that's invisible but it makes up a massive chunk of your life. Faith is when you believe in the stuff that you can't see, and the Bible says it's impossible to please God without faith. So just because you've not seen Jesus you're not at a disadvantage; Jesus said, 'Blessed are those who have not seen and yet have believed'. He loves it!

content.title: Want to stand up, step down
content.introtext:
The greatest among you will be your servant.

MATTHEW 23:11 NIV
We are used to hearing about celebs who turn up with 'their people'. Security, stylists, PR guys, assistants. The bigger the entourage, the bigger the celeb. Lots of people dream of 'making it' and most of the dreams would include servants and staff running around at their beck and call. So what does Jesus mean when he says 'The greatest among you will be your servant'; didn't He mean the greatest among will have servants? Nope, check out the verse again in The Message translation 'Do you want to stand out? Then step down. Be a servant. If you puff yourself up, you'll get the wind knocked out of you. But if you're content to simply be yourself, your life will count for plenty.' Remember how Jesus introduced Himself? 'The Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give his life' (Mark 10:45 NIV), and He practiced what He preached. Jesus is God; if anyone should get VIP treatment it was Him, yet we read about Him washing the disciples' mucky feet. That's like the star striker cleaning the B team's boots. So who you can you serve today? You might not have to untie their trainers or get a flannel out but how could YOU put others first? Do you want to stand out? Then step down; BE A SERVANT

content.title: Rescued!
content.introtext:
The Lord...redeems your life from destruction.

PSALM 103:2-4 NKJV
On a winter afternoon Harry de Leyer returned from an auction with a big grey horse that his children promptly named Snowman. He was a good riding horse, but when a neighbour offered Harry twice what he'd paid for him, he agreed. Right away he regretted his decision; so apparently did Snowman. And that's when his hidden talent was revealed! The neighbour's fences were high, but Snowman repeatedly jumped them to be with the master and family he loved. Finally Harry bought the horse back and the rest is history. Snowman kept winning championships and shows and was named 'Horse of the Year' two years running. But not because he was a good runner but was an awesome jumper. Nobody would ever have known had it not been for the fences that separated the grateful animal from his loving master. Of course unknown to the champion horse, Harry had arrived late at the auction that day after the best horses were sold. Snowman was rescued from the only other bidder...a man who intended him for the glue factory! 'The Lord... redeems your life from destruction.' The word redeem means bought for a price and collected. God rescued you but unlike Harry, God rescued you knowing what you can become. God knows that you were heading for destruction but now can be a champion. God knows; but do you?

content.title: You have to give it away
content.introtext:
Give, and it shall be given unto you.

LUKE 6:38
Legend has it that a man was lost in the desert, dying for water. He came upon a shack and saw a rusty old water pump. He began to pump up and down. But nothing came out. Then he noticed a nearby jug with these words, 'My friend, you have to prime the pump with the water in this jug. PS fill the jug again before you leave.' Now he was faced with a decision. If he drank the water in the jug he could live. But if he poured it into the old rusty pump it could make it work, giving him loads of fresh water. Reluctantly he poured all the water into the pump. Then he grabbed the handle and began to pump...squeak, squeak, squeak. Nothing came out! Squeak, squeak, squeak. A little bit began to dribble out, then a small stream, and finally it gushed! To his relief fresh, cool water poured out of the old rusty pump. Eagerly, two times he filled the jug and knocked back great mouthfuls of water. Then he filled the jug for the next traveller. He filled it to the top, popped the cork back on, and added this little note: 'Believe me, it really work!.' If you're generous not greedy, giving not grabbing; you could wonder 'what if I miss out?' Jesus said 'Give, and it shall be given unto you.'

content.title: Big Brother
content.introtext:
Son you are always with me and everything that I have it yours.

LUKE 15:31 NIV
This is one of Jesus' most famous stories. We can all identify with it; growing up, wanting to be your own person, a bit of independence. Then the realisation that when the fun inevitably comes to an end, is anybody really there for you? In this story Jesus is saying a big fat 'yes'. God, the No One true dad, is there for all who want to come back home to Him with a party waiting to happen. But the story has a twist; big brother wasn't about to celebrate little brother's return. Listen to him: 'Did you ever, ever throw party for me and my mates? No! But when this waster comes crawling back, oh yes, he gets the full treatment. Well thanks for nothing!' (Luke 15: 29-30 STREET). When you're jealous you can't enjoy the party! Can you identify with that? Have you ever found yourself feeling like you deserve a bit of love and appreciation more than those who are getting it? Careful, jealousy is deadly. It leads to bitterness, which is a bizarre prison because only you can lock yourself in it. What's going on in your life right now? Maybe God is telling you to chill out. You're God's child and nothing can ever change that! Enjoy the party. There's space for you. Listen: God is saying, 'Child you are always with me and all I have is yours'.

content.title: Read your Bible
content.introtext:
Continue in...the Holy Scriptures, which are able to make you wise.

2 TIMOTHY 3:14-15 NKJV
Three reasons to get into the Bible more: 1) We'll understand it more! We hear someone preach a great sermon and think, 'When I read it I didn't see that!' That's because the pastor spends hours praying over it and studying the Scriptures! The more time we put in the Bible the more we can understand it! Ok so you've got stuff to do but what could you cut down on (school isn't an option!)? 2) We learn to hear God! It's easy to become satisfied with hearing ABOUT from somebody else rather than hearing FROM God ourselves. Sometimes we can miss out on the buzz of discovering great truths from God's Word unless we get stuck into His Word 3) It tastes good! Bible study is hard work. There are no shortcuts to it. It takes time, effort, concentration and persistence. Most of its great truths don't lie on the surface; we have to dig for them. Dr Howard Hendricks describes the three stages of Bible study: a) the 'castor oil' stage; we study the Bible because we know it's good for us, but it's not too enjoyable b) the 'cereal' stage; our Bible study is dry and uninteresting, but we know it's nourishing c) the 'peaches and cream' stage; we are really feasting on the Word of God. Bottom line? 'Continue in...the Holy Scriptures, which are able to make you wise.'

content.title: 2B like JC (3)
content.introtext:
We become more like Him.

2 CORINTHIANS 3:18 NLT
Boffins say that the human mind is geared up to remember things in threes so we'll look at this really important subject at becoming more like Jesus one more time... You're young and you've got your life ahead of you, opportunities to do all sorts of cool things. What matters most is that whatever you do, you do it like Jesus would do it. Remember being like Jesus doesn't mean being a geek. Just don't become so well adjusted to your culture or fit into it so well that you can't un-fit yourself when you need to. So how do you do that? God uses His Word, people and circumstances, to bring out the best in us. God's Word provides the truth we need to know, God's people provide the support we need to grow and our circumstances provide the environment we need to show Christ's likeness. Make sure that you get into God's Word, connect with Christians regularly, and learn to trust God in every situation and you become more like Jesus; it's a guarantee. We all like to fit in, but fix your attention on God. He'll change you for the better, from the inside-out; unlike the world around you, changing you for the worst, from the outside-in. Check out this promise: 'He who began a good work in you will carry it on to completion' (Philippians 1:6).

content.title: 2B like JC (2)
content.introtext:
We become more like Him.

2 CORINTHIANS 3:18 NLT
Eight times in the New Testament, we're told to 'make every effort' 2 B like JC. You don't just veg out on the sofa and wait for it to happen. Our mate the apostle Paul explains our three responsibilities in becoming like Christ: 1) Changing our habits. Your character is made up of the sum of your daily habits. Listen: 'everything... connected with that old way of life has to go. It's rotten through and through. Get rid of it!' (Ephesians 4:22 TM) 2) Changing our thinking. The Greek word for transformed - metamorphosis - is used today to describe the amazing change a caterpillar goes through in becoming a butterfly and is a superb picture of what happens to us when we allow God to shape our thought life. As we spend time to chill with God, talking to him and reading his word, we take on the beauty of Christ's character; we leave behind those caterpillar limitations. Paul says 'be transformed by the renewing of your mind' (Romans 12:2) 3) Changing our clothes. God's word says, 'therefore, as God's chosen people, holy and dearly loved, clothe yourselves...' (Colossians 3:12). Most people wouldn't go to a party in a school uniform; you need to dress yourself in the right gear to make the most of the moment. So in life put on the right things '...clothe yourselves with compassion, kindness, humility and patience.'

content.title: 2B like JC (1)
content.introtext:
We become more like Him.

2 CORINTHIANS 3:18 NLT
Becoming like Jesus Christ isn't like Evan Almighty! You won't start growing a beard (good news, eh girls!) but you will grow character. Magazines and TV programmes talk a lot about changing your style, your waistline and even your bra size but they never say anything about transforming your character, even though it is your character that enables you to make the most of life, long-term. Character, not comfort, is God's first priority in your life. If you get frustrated and start wondering 'why is all this happening to me', you need to remind yourself that living life to the max isn't about avoiding extreme situations, it's growth in the midst of them, and victory over them. As how does character change happen? 'As the spirit of the Lord works within us, we become more and more like him' (2 Corinthians 3:18 NLT). His spirit lives inside you and anything is possible! So then, don't sit on your backside until you feel capable or confident. Get up and in faith do the right things in spite of your fears. We choose to do the right thing and then trust God's spirit to give us the oomph, the passion, the faith, and the brains to do it. That's how you co-operate with the Holy Spirit. That's how 2 B like JC and see true character developed in you.

content.title: Learn to benefit from criticism
content.introtext:
Whoever learns from correction is wise.

PROVERBS 15:5 NLT
There are two kinds of criticism: 1) criticism we don't deserve. One day Henry Ward Beecher stood up to preach. He noticed that someone had left on the pulpit some paper with the word 'fool' written on it. He knew someone was having a go at him. He lifted the paper for all to see, then he announced, 'Generally I receive letters from people who write and forget to sign their name. This letter is different. The person has signed his name but forgotten to write the letter.' Jesus said, 'Offences will come' (Luke 17:1). So expect them. You're getting noticed. You're making a difference. So when you are criticized unjustly, forget it and move on. Jesus did! 2) Justified criticism. Criticism that's justified is the kind with a measure of truth in it. An old Arabian proverb goes like this, 'If one person calls you a donkey, forget it. But if five people call you a donkey, buy a saddle.' Dr James G Kerr, a management psychologist, points out that we don't grow or learn about ourselves if we don't listen to anything about ourselves that isn't flattering. Stop hiding from the truth. Every one of us can improve what we're doing and the way in which it's being done. As they say, 'The largest room in the world is room for improvement!'

content.title: Chain Reaction
content.introtext:
One generation will commend your works to another.

PSALM 145:4
One day a Scottish farmer called Mr Fleming saved the life of a nobleman's son who was sinking in a muddy bog. The next day the boy's father visited the farm and offered to repay him, but the farmer wouldn't have it. Just then farmer Fleming's son came to the door and the nobleman said, 'Then let me pay to educate your boy to the same standard as mine, and if he turns out to be half the man his father is, we'll both be proud' Fleming agreed and his son attended the best schools, eventually graduating from St. Mary's Hospital Medical School in London. You've probably never heard of farmer Fleming, but I bet you've heard of his son. Sir Alexander Fleming, the man who discovered the miracle drug, Penicillin, saving gazillions of lives. And check this, years later when the same nobleman's son developed pneumonia, guess what saved his life? Penicillin! And what was this nobleman's name? Lord Randolph Churchill. And his son's name? Sir Winston Churchill, who helped save Europe from the horrors of Hitler! That's mad isn't it?! We don't know how much God was involved in engineering those events but we know this: God has connected our life and destiny with many other people around us. The whole of the Bible tells of the chain reactions that happen when people follow through with the connections He makes for them. Who's life can you affect today? Could you start a chain reaction?

content.title: Anybody can do it!
content.introtext:
Encourage one another.

1 THESSALONIANS 5:11 NIV
Pastor Chuck Swindoll writes: 'The ski slopes were in perfect condition. I struck out on my first attempt at skiing with a positive attitude, thinking, "I'm going to be the first person who learns to ski without falling down". It's doubtful anyone ever came down a ski slope more ways, or landed in more positions, or did more creative things in the air before landing. Working with me that humiliating day was the world's most encouraging ski instructor. Never once did she lose her cool, or laugh at me, or say "You are absolutely impossible. I quit!" That dear, gracious lady helped me up more times than I can number. She repeated the same basics time and again; like she had never said them before. Even though I was colder than an explorer in the Antarctic, irritable, impatient, and under the snow more than I was on it, she kept offering words of reassurance. That day God gave me a never-to-be-forgotten illustration of the value of encouragement...What is true for a novice on the snow once a year is all the more true for people we meet every day. Harassed by demands and deadlines; bruised by worry, adversity and failure; broken by disillusionment and defeated by sin, they live somewhere between dull discouragement and sheer panic. All of us need encouragement, and the beautiful part about encouragement is this: anybody can do it!'

content.title: Dare to be yourself
content.introtext:
EVERY ONE OF US WILL GIVE AN ACCOUNT OF HIMSELF TO GOD.

Romans 14:12
You have to be up for a dare if you're going to follow God. That doesn't mean that He wants you to join your local bungee jumping club but He may direct you to do things that people around you don't understand or agree with. Insecure people tend to feel safer doing what others do; they are fearful of breaking the mould or standing alone. Anytime you step outside of the boundaries of what others think is cool or normal, you risk rejection, but you can't allow that to keep you from fulfilling your God-given purpose. Confronting criticism becomes a little easier when you remember that ultimately 'everyone of us shall give an account of himself to God'. Yeah, it stings when you're criticised, but if you're to succeed at anything you must have the same attitude that Paul had. Listen: 'I care very little if I am judged by you... it is the Lord who judges me' (1 Corinthians 4:3-4 NIV). Secure people can handle being the only ones who dare to do something - not in a showing-off kind of way, and not just being random and stupid out of total boredom - but daring to live a radically different life - like the Jesus we follow. Be a revolutionary! For ideas of how to dare to live in a way that makes a difference check out www.hope-revolution.com

content.title: Testifying without a touch
content.introtext:
Blessed are those who believe without seeing.

JOHN 20:29 NLT
Asking for proof before you believe something, can stop you from receiving what God wants you to accept based on His Word. Thomas watched Jesus die. That's a tough image to forget. He was majorly shook up. When your faith has been shaken, you tend to cling to things that are basic, close and reliable. Stories of ghosts didn't fit in that category. But Jesus was gracious to Thomas and allowed him to touch his risen body saying, 'You believe because you have seen...Blessed are those who believe without seeing.' Thomas' problem wasn't lack of faith, it was misdirected faith. He trusted only what he could process on a human level. Sound familiar? By contrast, when Mary Magdalene met Jesus at the tomb He told her, 'Don't touch me...But go find my brothers and tell them' (John 20:17 TLB). Mary was in an emotional state and just wanted a hug from the faithful friend she thought she'd lost forever. But Jesus needed her to start trusting His Word and not His flesh. Sometimes we feel 'the touch of Jesus' calming us, strengthening us, reassuring us that He's in control. That touch has often kept us from giving up or going over the edge, but sometimes He asks us to simply trust Him at his word. That's faith at its highest level. So what's he saying to you today?

content.title: That is how much He loves you!
content.introtext:
I could ask my Father for thousands of angels...and he would send them.

MATTHEW 26:53 TLB
Isn't it just bizarre how the cross has become a fashion accessory? After all, nobody would wear an electric chair ring, or a hangman's noose earrings! But even though a lot of people have forgotten what the cross means that doesn't mean it's lost its power. There will always be something uniquely special about the cross. And what better way to remember how much Jesus loves us. Beyond all the blood and the nails there is a simple shape, a horizontal beam showing how wide his love is, and a vertical beam showing how high and how deep his love is. John's gospel says, 'God loved the world so much that he gave his one and only Son so that whoever believes in him may not be lost, but have eternal life. (John 3:16 NCV). It doesn't say God loved only the famous or the fabulous or then we'd all be in trouble. No, if you live in 'the world' you're included by God! Jesus didn't have to die, He chose to! He told His captors, 'I could ask my Father for thousands of angels...and he would send them instantly...' As Max Lucado says, 'The force behind the hammer wasn't an angry mob...the hand squeezing the handle wasn't a Roman infantryman...the verdict...wasn't decided by jealous Jews. Jesus himself chose the nails...' That's how much He loves you.

content.title: Can't we love each other?
content.introtext:
God put his love on the line...while we were of no use whatever to him.

ROMANS 5:8 TM
We all know that war is a nasty business, and becoming a prisoner of war can be a death sentence. During the Second World War Ernest Gordon was captured by the Japanese army who forced their prisoners to work for them like slaves. One evening a guard noticed a shovel was missing. Insisting a prisoner had stolen it, he screamed for the guilty party to step forward. Then he prepared to kill them one by one until someone confessed. Suddenly a Scottish soldier spoke out and said, 'I did it.' The guard beat him to death on the spot. A few minutes later the shovels were re-counted. The guard was wrong. None was missing! What kind of person would take the blame for something he didn't do? 'This is how we know what love is: Jesus Christ laid down his life for us. And we ought to lay down our lives for our brothers. (1 John 3:16 NIV). At the cross Jesus stepped out and offered himself as the punishment for our sins. Unlike the Scottish soldier in the story who was innocent, humankind was very definitely guilty. Unlike the Japanese Guard, God had a right to demand the ultimate penalty. So, having lived the life we couldn't live, Jesus took the punishment we couldn't escape. Now the question is: if He so loved us, can't we love each other?

content.title: WHERE'S YOUR CONFIDENCE?
content.introtext:
Blessed is the man who trusts in the Lord, whose confidence is in Him.

JEREMIAH 17:7 NIV
Samson was a heavy dude in the old days of Israel, a dread-locked hero who had amazing physical strength but a weakness for women. He kept the secret of his strength to himself, but eventually he got cocky and blabbed to his girl; bad move. Judges 16:19 says 'She called a man to shave off the seven braids of his hair...and his strength left him'. The consequences for Samson were disastrous; he tried to fight like before but got absolutely battered. His ego had become bigger than his faith. He was no good to anyone. Jesus said 'Apart from me you can do nothing' (John 15:5). So be careful. Make sure you trust more in your bended knees than your metaphorical muscles (the stuff you are good at) 'Blessed is the man who trusts in the Lord, and whose confidence is in Him. He will be like a tree planted by the water that sends out its roots by the stream. It does not fear when heat comes; its leaves are always green. It has no worries in a year of drought and never fails to bear fruit' (Jeremiah 17:5-8 NIV). With God you are strong; without Him you are weak! Think about the things going on in your life and ask 'Should I flex my muscles or bend my knees and pray?' You know the answer!

content.title: P R A Y
content.introtext:
Look to the Lord and his strength; seek his face always.

1 CHRONICLES 16:11 NIV
Talking to God sometimes feels tough does it? You run out of stuff to say or your prayers end up as list of things you want or need. Just remember P R A Y: Praise. Don't hold back, Big God up. Plug in your ipod and let rip. Rap, sing, write, draw, dance. Use your own words or find verses in the Bible; check out 1 Chronicles 29:11-13. Repent. When we start to spend time with God we quickly get a good idea of the attitudes, habits, selfish behaviour and lack of love that clutter our lives. It's important that we spend time asking God to forgive these sins but also to ask Him to help us turn away from them. Repentance is when we choose to change. Ask. This is the easy part! But sometimes we stop asking when we don't see quick answers. Don't give up. Prayer does have power. Sometimes you see the effects quickly- like switching on a light. Sometimes it takes longer- like a kettle. Sometimes your prayers are changing you rather than your circumstances. Jesus had a story on prayer about a women who didn't give up asking . Have a read of Luke 18:1-8 Yield This old fashion word just means give in, let go, allow God to do whatever he wants in your life. He's the boss! He is LORD

content.title: The Abba effect
content.introtext:
"OUR FATHER IN HEAVEN."

MATTHEW 6:9
Praying is amazing. We can talk to the Creator of the universe just as if we've got a 'Hands Free Kit'. Jesus taught His friends to pray and He began by helping them to understand God in a way that was new for them; as a truly loving Dad, or in their language 'Abba'. Author Max Lucado once visited Israel with his family. He had an awesome time and wrote about it in his book, 'One afternoon in old Jerusalem, I found myself behind a Jewish family; a father and his three little girls. The 4-year-old fell a few steps behind and couldn't see him. "Abba!" she called. He stopped and immediately he extended his hand and she took it. He held her hand tightly as they descended the ramp. When they stopped at a busy street, she stepped off the curb and he pulled her back. When the signal changed he led her and her sisters through the busy road. In the middle of the street, he reached down, swept her up into his arms and continued their journey.' Who'll take our hand when we're weak? Who'll guide us through the hectic streets of life? Who'll swing us up into His arms and carry us home? God, our loving Dad, our Abba. No matter what you're facing today just whisper, 'Abba,' and He'll be there for you!

content.title: You said!
content.introtext:
I am watching over My word to perform it.

JEREMIAH 1:12 NAS
Are you struggling with a habit so stubborn that it has a life of its own? Getting our heads round the promises in the Bible can make a big difference. 'I am watching over MY word to perform it' (Jeremiah 1:12.) In other words God says: 'trust me. I'm on it'. Sometimes the strength we need comes when we remind ourselves and God what He has said. So begin each day by praying: 'Lord, the Bible says that if I call on You, You will answer me; You will be with me in trouble' (Psalm 91:15). You said that the power of the Holy Spirit deep inside me would set free from being endlessly caught up temptation, sin and failure (Romans 8:2). You said if I fully commit my life to You, I'd have the strength to stand up to the devil and he would flee from me (James 4:7). You said You've given me the power to deal with the wrong thoughts and ideas that peck my head (2 Corinthians 10:5). You said that my self-worth would be based solely on Your love for me; and that You would do immeasurably more than I could ask or think because You are at work in me (Ephesians 3:14-21). Today I thank You for helping me to overcome this habit. In Christ's name, amen.'

content.title: Learn to relax
content.introtext:
[Stop allowing yourselves to be agitated...disturbed...and unsettled].

JOHN 14:27 AMP
Picture it: Monday morning, the alarm doesn't go off. Skipping breakfast to try and make the bus, you see it pull off in the distance. As you start walking, the heavens explode, reducing your nice new hairdo to a wet squelch on your forehead. Passing cars race through puddles like Lewis Hamilton, drenching your crisp uniform and turning it muddy brown. You think about a snack from the local shop, but then realise your pennies are in your other pair of trousers at home; which means no money for dinner either. When you finally make it in, your teacher informs you that as this is your fifth late mark this month, you've collected the grand prize of Thursday night detention. What's your reaction: a) you pick up the nearest year 7 in the corridor and launch them like an Olympic winning javelin throw b) the vein in your neck pulsates, your fists clinch, your blood could boil potatoes, but you do nothing more than stew inside, or c) you go with the flow; you've learned how to control your reactions in stressful situations. OK, so anyone who answered C is a liar. But actually, that's what Jesus wants us to learn; to stop losing peace over every stress and strain, and to work on our reactions instead. Once you've mastered yourself, you're ready to master situations. Not easy stuff, but next time you miss that bus try it.
